text: Skipped the hour-long wait and got a spot at a bar table for brunch! A little disappointed that they put nuts on top of the hotcakes and don't mention that on the menu. I understand you don't want to list all of the ingredients, but you should definitely mention if they are completely covered in nuts. Also, maybe don't look so surprised when I ask for new ones. Otherwise, the food was good.

I stopped by for lunch in the middle of the week and they had a line of people already formed outside waiting for them to open. We were able to snag one of the last tables out on their sidewalk. We decided on the queso fundido, grill-roasted elote corn, the feature fish with tomato-morita and watercress and the grill-roasted shrimp tostada. The queso fundido was a decent sized portion and was served with warm tortillas. There were plenty of onions, peppers and chorizo. And make sure to use their salsas! Don't be afraid to ask for extra tortillas when you run out! I wish the serving dish was able to retain it's heat better so the cheese wouldn't harden up so quickly. The elote was okay. The corn was huge and super messy. The topping were good, but the roasted corn was a little over cooked and could have tasted fresher. The rockfish was really good. The meat was moist and tender, the mashed potato with chives and crema was the best I've had, the watercress was refreshing and the sauce was smoky and a bit spicy. The roasted shrimp tostadas were ok. I missed the part where it said the toppings were cold, so that was a bit of a surprise. The flavor was good and it reminded me of ceviche. The salad that came with it was unfortunately over-dressed and pretty spicy.  Overall, lunch was decent. My rockfish dish was exceptional, but everything else was just okay. Luckily, the menu is quite large so there are plenty of other dishes to try. I'd definitely skip the elote next time.
Great food, great service. They serve late. The vegetarian options are excellent. Highly recommend the mushroom Quixote. Also, don't skip out of the guacamole.

I've had a drink at the bar here before, but I've never had a full sit-down dinner until now. Whoa, have I been missing out! It was as good as I'd hoped. We were on the way to the theatre, so we were on a tight schedule, and our server was so friendly and accommodating, taking our entire order at once, for example, but still managing to space out our appetizers before our entrees. We had the queso (unbelievably good), the cheese quesadillas, the goat enchiladas, the poblano cream cauliflower, and a pork tamal between us, and everything was so nuanced and delicious, even the small things, like the side of black beans with the enchiladas were spectacular. We also had tasty drinks. I'd go back in a heartbeat.
Amazing service and delicious food!!! Always a great time!! Bar seating is the most fun!
Love RICK Bayless' food. Every time we have dined here it has been a memorable evening! Food, service and ambiance is excellent. Hard to get a reservation. It worth the patience.

Having been to Xoco last time we were in Chicago, this time we opted for Rick Bayless' James Beard awarded restaurant Frontera Grill. As I was in a soup mood, we shared their famous tortilla soup ($9) and the carnes al carbon para tacos ($20). The soup was a dark broth with pasilla, grilled chicken, avocado, artisan Jack cheese, homemade crema, and crispy tortilla strips. It was hearty and delicious - the perfect soup for whether you're cold or just need a warm hug inside. We opted for the skirt steak tacos, but our server made a mistake and brought us portobello mushrooms at first. He was nice enough to comp us for the mushrooms, and we ended up having both the steak and mushroom tacos for the price of one. The steak was marinated with garlic and a variety of spices, while the mushrooms were marinated with garlic, agave nectar, and spices. Both were delicious and packed with flavor. I wasn't even that hungry, but the tacos made me eager for more.  For less than $40, we had a very satisfying meal at Frontera Grill. We would absolutely come back here (or any of Rick Bayless' restaurants to be frank). There are a lot more options on the menu that we haven't tried, and we'll just have to come back to Chicago soon to get our Bayless Mexican fill.

5 stars for the food, 2 stars for the service, I'm averaging that out to a generous 4 stars. The food is world-class. You will likely never eat food with that sort of attention to detail anywhere else for what you pay. It's meticulous, incredibly delicious, filling and clean tasting. My biggest issue is the two times we've been we've had underwhelming service. This past time they completely forgot to give me my tortillas for my tacos and completely neglected a large portion of our dessert order until we bothered them about it. We were met with lame, made up excuses like "the peach empanada takes a bit longer". Yeah. Okay. Sure. All-in-all you'll (eventually) get great food that you can't get anywhere else.

Another awesome trip here. This time we got: - Guacamole - Salsas - Tortilla soup - Tacquitos banadas - Ceviche trio - Fish tacos - Grilled chicken tacos The tacquitos and tortilla soup were incredible (again), as were the ceviches, although I think next time I'd be fine just getting the yellowfin tuna ceviche, which was easily my favorite. The tacos (which you have to compile yourself, as they're build-your-own) were good, but not my favorite. One disappointment was that they didn't have the incredible Mexico City-style quesadillas on the lunch menu -- probably makes this worth a dinner trip just for those.

The hostess's were extremely professional and personable and they were able to get us a table much sooner than we expected.  The food was incredible.  And overall the staff was beyond exceptional.  What killed the experience and ruined our night was the waiter.  He was inattentive and dismissive.  To the point after ordering appetizers and drinks he never checked in or asked if we wanted to order entrees.  As a result we didn't and were anxious to leave and the only way we got his attention was to motion we wanted the check.  Every other experience at Frontera has been amazing (including going the night before) but unfortunately the experience with the waiter tonight was not.  His attitude ruined the mood of the night and is the reason we will not be going back.

I came here specifically for the steak salad. IT WAS AMAZING. I have now had it twice and it only got better the second time. The portion size is huge! I can't stop thinking about it. Thin strips of steak cooked it your liking accompanying crisp lettuce covered in a tangy mustard dressing and cheese with croutons that are so buttery. I would HIGHLY recommend. I wish there was a location closer to my house !

Frontera Grill was pretty disappointing, For all the great reviews and the raved about Rick Bayless high-end Mexican restaurant, the food was a little disappointing. The food is ok to great but lacked consistency. The service was mediocre. We arrived an hour early, had a snack next door and arrived on time.  We were seated in a spacious booth seat.  We ordered the ceviche trio ($ 24), carne asada brava ($ 29) and enchiladas de cochinita pibil ($19). The ceviche trio was the best part of the meal. The tropical ceviche was mango tuna with red onions. This was refreshingly sweet and delicious. I also liked the Frontera ceviche with Hawaiian albacore, lime and tomatoes.  The enchiladas were ok. Unfortunately the "slow-cooked suckling pig cochinita pibil" was dry and lacked many of the flavors of cochinita pibil such as cinnamon, cumin and orange flavors. It just tasted like a slightly dry roasted pork.  The carne asada brava was flank steak, which was a perfect medium rare with grilled knob onions. The green onion part was wrapped into a knot. The flavors were ok but a little bland. This is something that could be made at home. The best part of this dish was the sweet corn tamales. They tasted of sweet fluffy corn cakes.  Unfortunately, the service was not great. One of servers tossed my plate in front of me like a frisbee instead of handing it to me or placing it down in front of me. Some of the servers were great- explaining a dish while placing it on the table. Our waiter was very nice.  All in all, there are much better Mexican restaurants that you can spend your money on. Brave your own path to better Mexican food.

Worth the wait. The staff will text you when your table is ready. Best Mexican food in Chicago. Great service. Patio seating.  I had enchiladas. I inhaled them. The others in my party had meat heavy dishes. Delicious. "The Best" Margerita really is the best.   I can wait to go back.

This was one of the best meals I ate in Chicago. Try a little of everything (aka share plates with your friends). Don't miss out on the tortilla soup because it will blow your mind! Great, friendly staff. Great atmosphere. Great menu.

Wow, what a disappointment.  I'm a fan of Tortas Fronteras in O'Hare and was excited to try many of the upscale Mexican fusion dishes here.  Food ranged from average to just plain mediocre, but at very high prices. And the service was awful. It was the first time as an adult that I did not leave a tip for poor service (well, actually, I left a penny to send a message).  We had an amazing experience at another upscale Mexican place the night before. This pales in comparison. The chips were too salty and tasted like they came straight from a bag. Salsa and guac portions were stingy. My enchilada was average but it still set me down $19.  My friend ordered what he thought was a vegetable heavy dish only to receive something that was more like a mozzarella stick. He returned it and exchanged it for something else, but the waiter was not apologetic.  He ordered several side dishes instead. One of them was pretty much raw cauliflower in a cream sauce. Are you kidding me? You're charging premium prices for cauliflower and you're not even cooking it?? When we pointed out that the dish was not to our liking, our waiter did not flinch. I told him we'd like to have it deducted from our bill and he didn't even acknowledge my request--that's how I decided he didn't deserve a tip. The guy simply didn't care!  Frontera is such a joke. I honestly should have asked to speak to the manager, but I hope management sees this review and the note I left on the receipt ("mediocre food, LOUSY service, not coming back!").

I am a big fan of Rick Bayless. My husband and i decided to stay at chicago for few days and try this place out. The service was great and the food was really authentic mexican place like no other I have been into.   My favorite plate was enchiladas pork pibil and the tacos arabes. We also order tacos al carbon steak with delicious beans and carnitas tortitas. To drink i order Paloma and my husband Michelada even tho they dont have it on the Menu. the server was amazing. He said that he will make it for him.  Love it! If i go back i will order one more time the enchiladas rojass pork pibill!!! Yum
Unbelievable outstanding one of the best restaurants I've ever been to. Although we had to wait it was definitely worth it. It is a must for anybody who is going to Chicago.

We are in town, and our friends were excited for us to try the place for lunch.  I had no really expectations.  Unfortunately,   this was just really average food.  The ingredients are fresh,  and the tortillas are house made,   but the flavors are just not special.  The guacamole is guacamole-good but average.   The salsas are good but nothing special,  and they serve a VERY small amount of them. The poblanos were non-existent in the mushroom quesadillas, and they could have used some sauce or moisture. The same for my friend's chicken quesadilla. My husband's sliced pork with mole was good and the sauce had a good depth of flavor.  Lunch for 4 with tip topped $200. I expect more flavor for that.
Loved our meal here.  They were able to accommodate our two kids no problem, and the kids meal portions are huge. We still talk about how good the ceviche trio was.

This place is wonderful and the Baja tacos were really good and done properly. I would come back again and other something new to try. This is a really good place to come. Great for lunch. Mexican food done right.

Visited Chicago last week and made reservations way ahead of time.  Big fan of Rick Bayless from Top Chef Masters.  great ceviche and sangria.  However, my skirt steak tacos ordered med rare was iced cold.  Sent it back came out warm but well done.  They comped the entree but so disappointed.  I expect that from an inferior chain but not from a Rick Bayless caliber restaurant.  If it wasn't for that I would have given a better rating

Man...I so wanted to love the Frontera Grill. Quick trip to Chicago and have always wanted to try here. People line up an hour before it even opens in order to get a table. We stood in line for like 5 minutes and got a time to come back for dinner. I wish that I didn't come back. To be honest, my experience here was below average. The food was...meh. I got the skirt steak tacos. They were undercooked, bland, and just pretty much run of the mill. My dining partner got the fish and she said that it tasted like something from a musty aquarium. Pretty disappointing. In all fairness, the guacamole was really good. All in all just pretty disappointing and average.
Best place to eat in Chicago hands down. Whenever we go it's always the ceviche trio, guacamole, and our own entrees to share.

Overall:  Pretty underwhelmed by my experience at Frontera.  I've eaten at Red O in Newport Beach a couple of times (Rick Bayless is the culinary director for Red O) - and it has always been a totally memorable / unique experience.  I don't feel that way at all about Frontera, despite its fame & hype. Wait Time:  The best part of our experience here - the opportunity for a (party of 2) to sit at the chef's counter.  At 8:45 PM on a Wednesday evening, the wait time for a table was 2+ hours...but we were able to sit immediately at the counter!  I was starving and grateful for this option.  Plus, it's always fun to be in the thick of a busy kitchen watching chefs at work. Drinks:  I had the Oaxaca Tropical ($13) which was rimmed with an excessive amount of salt to the point that at first, I could only describe my cocktail as "salty" - it was overwhelming and totally took over the flavors of the drink.  When my tastebuds did recover, it was a great drink, with lovely presentation.  Later, I had the Moody Tongue (local brewery) sliced nectarine IPA. Food: This is where things really get hazy.  We shared the Chef's Choice guacamole - I pulled up the restaurant menu in the hopes to remember what the ingredients were, but a different guac is listed on the site right now.  It was pretty boring, and tasted like...normal guacamole.  I had expected to be wowed with flavor that could stand up to the "Chef's Choice" description, but those flavors fell flat.   As for my entree, I had a grilled shrimp dish - but I can't remember how it was prepared or what the flavors were.  It too was unmemorable and just "fine".  Nothing to write home about. Service:  Another highlight!  Our server was totally energetic and enthusiastic, and he was quick.

I've been to Rick Bayless' two restaurants in LA and really loved both, so when I saw Frontera Grill was near my hotel, I knew we had to go. We came Saturday morning and stood in line before it was open for brunch. Thankfully, even without a reservation we were able to get in and were seated immediately. Since it was a nice day, we opted for an outside table. Service was excellent throughout.  I had the Mexican hot chocolate, which was better than any I'd ever had, and my running partner had a cocktail. He had the chilaquiles and I had the famous tortilla soup and the taquitos banados. Both were excellent choices. I'm so glad I had the opportunity to eat at one of the original restaurants... excellent meal and a wonderful experience.
The worst Mexican food ever. Tasted like it was commercially prepared and reheated. Tourist trap for sure.

Hello,FOOD SNOB here.  Simply put, Best Mexican food I ever had. Best Ceviche. Great environment. Great service. Great Appetizers too. Again you cant really go wrong when your downtown. Everything good here.

Yikes. Presentation was way off. I also like spicy food,  but the enchiladas were just spicy without any flavor. The black beans were good but the chicken was rubbery and every other bite had cartilage and bone fragments. The five people I ate with were similarly disappointed. I was really looking forward to a wonderful meal. Now I'm just hoping I don't end up puking the next three days.

Would give zero stars if possible. This is one of the worst restaurants I have ever been to. The food was disgusting. Seafood was nasty and fishy taste. Enchiladas looked like someone did  diarrhea on them. Chicken was rubbery and filled with bone and cartilage. All of the food was not hot. Spicy when we were told not spicy. When all six people you are eating with don't like their food, something is not right. Seriously awful. Overpriced. Tourist trap. Go elsewhere.
First let me say, David was our waiter and he was Great (with a capital G).  We had a group of 7 and all of our food was simply delicious - ceviches, enchiladas, tamales, tacos, and dessert.
Simply is the best Mexican food .And the waiter was absolutely outstanding he recommended margaritas and it was so good. Anybody from Chicago or outside should go there at least once a year.

Yup this is definitely a Rick Bayless restaurant with the many mezcal options, and smoky/spicy flavor profile within most dishes. Reservations are hard to come by (I think mainly because they save only a limited number of spots for reservations), but if you decide to make one (which I recommend unless you want to wait an hour) be prepared to still wait a few mins for your table, which is what we did. The space actually isn't huge so it was understandable I suppose. The ambience is pretty loud and bustling. I could hear the people next to me but not one more person over (was in a group of 7). The service was good. For drinks I ordered the house margarita which was delicious (albeit kinda small). It packed a punch though and I would get it again. For food I got the cheesy quesadilla/empanadas which was good! (But I mean it's cheese...so of course). And for my entree I ordered the halibut. The dish was cooked perfectly and the portion was generous. I like that corn tortillas are served for the table to share as well. The green rice that came with it was delicious and the green sauce was good, and definitely had a kick to it. The complimentary guacamole w/ chips and salsa was great (prolly my favorite part of the meal honestly). All in all everything was good. But I think for me personally I'm not in love with the smoky spice flavors that Bayless knows and loves. And I'm also not in love with the hype around everything having to do with Rick Bayless and subsequent prices and wait times associated with that. I'm glad I checked it out but onto the next for my future dining out endeavors.

I think people let their expectations get the best of them. This was really good mexican food. Simple and well prepared with a few modern twists. You really can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Came for Sunday brunch and had an excellent meal. A bit pricey for the portion sizes. But hey, this is downtown Chicago and a celebrity restaurant. Drinks were perfect and service was friendly. What more can I ask? We had a great meal and left perfectly satisfied.

My family is low-key obsessed with Rick Bayless (we didn't have cable so we spent a lot of time watching his cooking shows growing up) so I was excited to get a chance to dine at his restaurant when I was in Chicago for the first time as an adult. The Palomas are worth the money - my favorite Mexican drink any time of day - and the food didn't disappoint. My dad had the pork tacos and I had the fish special. The sauces are flavorful and have a little kick, but not 'burn your mouth' spicy. The atmosphere in the dining room was just what I expected - good music, lots of people having fun, and an excellent, attentive waitstaff. I am looking forward to returning!

This is absolutely one of the best Mexican restaurant I've been to. The quality of food and flavor is exquisite. Drinks are great, the sangria and the mango paleta: excellent! And don't forget to ask for the queso fundido to start. Out of this world!!!

Our waiter quickly came by to give us our menu and a bowl of spiced nuts. Although it looked really spicy, it actually tasted quite mild. To start, we decided to get the guacamole and house-made tortilla chips. The dish came with two types of salsas. I also tried the Frontera hot sauce with the chips. Even though the salsas and the hot sauce looked very intense, they were also very mild. For our mains, I went with the "tamale of the day" while my girlfriend went for the chicken enchiladas. Both of the dishes came with different types of mole. The mole on the enchiladas was a bit spicy and the chicken was cooked well. The "tamale of the day" was braised goat with mole poblano. The mole was a bit sweeter than the one on the enchiladas. The masa around the goat filling was a bit thick and was very filling. The goat, on the other hand, was very tender and delicious. The dish weirdly came with arugula salad. The dishes offer diners an introduction and a good stepping stone to authentic Mexican cuisine. A very solid spot in the city.

Solid Mexican with really fresh, quality food. Love that the menu details where all the produce and ingredients come from. We ate at the bar and to be honest I wouldn't wait for a table if I could help it. Service was excellent. The bartender was super busy but kept coming back to check on us and refreshing our tortillas. We got the queso to start and then shared the trio of tacos. Everything was really tasty and very fresh. I really loved that the tacos were DIY so we could fill the tortillas exactly how we wanted to. My only gripe is that I wish the tortillas were served warm. We also got the Paloma style drink and a margarita. Both were good, nothing spectacular. Even though we were stuffed, the bartender showed us the dessert menu and I couldn't resist a mezcal hot chocolate! It was good but I don't think I could truly enjoy and appreciate how good because I was so full.
Completely disappointed - called and they said no wait...arrive 10 mins later and it suddenly became 90-120 min wait...Suspect!
Try to eat there for Mother's Day and got the worst service ever!! End up leaving the place.

F****** love this place. Line at the door at 5, get your name in and go get a margarita at the bar and get ready. This trip unfortunately I ran into one of those tourists that has used the Frontera Sauce packets from the store and decided to go and try the restaurant while in town. The gentleman half knocks me off my bar stool because he was too uncoordinated to get on his own. He then proceeds to order a wine and tells the bar tender he doesn't want a  foo foo drink like we had. Well we had splurge margaritas and the mental midget couldn't understand that's what you get at Mexican restaurants. He sent back 2 of the wines saying they sucked, I was waiting for the bar tender to assault the guy with the automatic rim salter. Anyway minus that douche, great food as always. Skirt steak tacos, trio of ceviche, chicken tacos and that bad ass pecan chocolate pie, all so good. Plus it's summer and you can sit outside, awesome!!

Don't get me wrong, the food was good. But what's with the hype? You have to reserve a month in advance to get a decent reservation time? Small dishes, big prices, and a small bathroom; that's another story. Let's get right to the food. Like I said, it was good, but there wasn't a lot of it. And for our ending tab, was wayyyy disappointed. Now, my girlfriend and I were celebrating her birthday so it's not like we were trying to make an economic dinner, we were just out having a good time. Shrimp & Scallop Ceviche Verde (2/5) --- Personally, I don't like raw fish or sushi, or even anything that sounds similar. I, myself didn't mind this appetizer, but my girlfriend really seemed to enjoy it. She said it's exactly what she was expecting and that it was prepared very well. Honestly, I was just picking at the mini shrimps, and putting them on the tortilla chips that came with. Shrimp & Crab Empanadas (4/5) --- Not what I was expecting when I think of empanadas. These were like little dough puffs with some mexican fillings and salsas. There wasn't a lot of texture throughout the piece, just more of an overall chewy feel.  Tacos Arabes (4/5) --- N/A Halibut, Green Garlic Salsa Verde (4/5) --- The fish was good. The green rice was good. I also ordered a side of mashed potatoes because mashed potatoes can make or break a meal for me; those were also good. My order was pretty awesome, when it comes to the taste. Although half the plate was vegetables, I don't think there was an unfair portion control. It all went together pretty well.  Summary: Overall, this dinner was special, unfortunately not because of the dinner itself though. Our waiter was good, our food was good, the overall service and experience was good. I am a strong believer in quantity over quality so I was just taken back by how much everything was when it felt like there wasn't that much food. For a glass of margarita and chardonnay, ceviche, empanadas, steak tacos, halibut with potatoes, I paid $110+. I guess it was nice to have "Rick Baylee's" food, but for a shaky table, delayed appetizer, and a little over priced entrees, the hype was too much.

Service was top notch but the food was disappointing.  We were very excited to visit Chicago and try this restaurant, as we are fans of the chef.  The seafood (fish, shrimp, seafood enchilada special) were all very fishy and clearly not fresh, the taquitos for my nephew off the kids menu were even terrible and tasted freezer burnt.   Sad because I don't believe this is representative of the chef's true culinary talents.  It is his dishes botched by line cooks.
I'd come to Chicago just to eat here. Incredibly fresh food with amazing, nuanced flavor. The ceviche was amazing. The even had a kids' menu to keep my son happy.

Very loud and crowded. The ceviche was overpriced and not that great.  The duck enchiladas were very good and the service was top notch.  I like Rick Bayless and wanted to love it, but I probably wouldn't return.
Good food but the owner is too politically profound. I don't like or agree with his political views, which I am sure he don't care. The food is great. So there will always be a line to get in.
Tasty meals and exceptional customer service! I tried shrimp tamale and it was delectable. I also bought apple cake and it was ordinary. My time here was nice. I will probably come back here.
This place is really excellently. The staff are so knowledgeable and friendly. Even the location in the airport is fantastic. Love it

I had been wanting to visit Chicago just to eat at this place. I was VERY afraid that my high expectations would disappoint me! I was by no means disappointed!!! Authentic Mexican flavors which you rarely get in the US. We got there around 1:30pm on a weekday and while it was busy it wasn't overly packed. We got seated right away. There were 6 of us. We ordered margaritas to start. All I can say is WOW! Those were the best margaritas I've had in a while! We got a queso fundido for starters. Rather than chips which is an old and tired way of serving them, this queso came with nice tortillas. The queso had some chorizo in it which made it that much better. One thing I will say is that I thought the portion was slightly too small. Not really enough for six if you wanted more than one big queso bite. I asked the server if I should get the tamales (the day's special) or the chicken enchiladas with mole. She strongly recommended the enchiladas and she was oh so right!!! I've been a fan of mole, all kinds of mole, for as long as I can remember. To me, if done right, it's a practically perfect food. This one was practically perfect in every way. It was sweet with a hint of spiciness but was not overpowering.  I also had my daughter's meat since she wasn't eating much. I could tell the meat was not only cooked to perfection but it was also a great cut of meat, high quality. Not cheap, hard meat.  I don't have much of a review for the other dishes on the table but at least what I had was nearly perfect. I wish I could go back over and over again.

I ordered the mole enchiladas which were delicious! The salsa and guacamole were very tasty. The portions were perfect, we went on a thursday around 1pm and didn't wait more than 15 min when they said the wait would be 45 mins.

Me me no likey. Not sure what the hype is about, and the need to make reservations a month + in advance. Guac was good, hence the 1 star. Outside of that, I suggest eating elsewhere. Really, anywhere else around River North. Wanted to love it, but me me not a Frontera Grill boy.... - Kreg Youths Sr.

Our lunch for four today was superb. The flavors in the triple ceviche appetizer were subtly melded into indescribable deliciousness. Each one made me think it was the best while it was in my mouth. The guys had hot cheese, chorizo and chilies in warmed tortillas with two salsas. They liked it a lot. We tried two varieties of Margueritas. I truly was skeptical of any little cocktail being worth that price tag but it was the best waste of Tattinger I've ever tasted. The other Marguerita used an aged tequila and was equally delicious. The main courses were the fish dish of the day and the steak dish of the day. No one was disappointed. The shared dessert,"dos tres quatro " was beautifully presented and tasted almost as good as it looked. Excellent, unobtrusive service and great atmosphere.

Most un-Mexican looking Mexican food we ever ate in our lives. It was a great first Frontera Grill experinence for our group of 12. Drinks, apps, entrees, and dessert were delish and prices not too bad. Our hostess Irene and server Lugo made the afternoon a memeorable one. And real cool Mr. Bayless was in the house and stopped by to say Hey!
Probably one of the best Mexican restaurants I've been to in Chi-Town. Good Service even when busy. Good food with great flavors. Didn't disappoint.

Service was great, the food was great and I didn't have a single drink I didn't like. I enjoyed it so much that I placed an order to go for lunch the next day since they wouldn't be open. When I had it it was great until I was almost through the chicken when it stated to get really salty, I took out the last few pieces and found a couple tablespoons of salt at the bottom of the container and it destroyed my experience.

This is one of my must-visit places to eat while in Chicago. I had a perfect experience sitting at the bar for lunch (and I don't say that easily!). The fish of the day: amazing. Wonderful service. Tino (not sure of the spelling) and the bartender with the great mustache (Why can't I remember his name? He's fantastic!) guided me through yet another fabulous meal there.  Try to visit at off-peak times if you don't want to wait for a seat, because it's going to be packed at peak hours (because it's awesome).  I'll be back the next time I'm in Chicago.

Totally struggled with this review because I generally am a fan of Bayless and all things in his empire, but while lunch here was fine, this probably won't be on the list for a return trip...  Had the shredded beef enchiladas and seafood tostada...  Enchilada had good depth but some sweetness to it that I didn't really care for, and not enough sauce/cheese that my little Texas heart was craving  The tostada was more tart than flavorful, enough so that the third tostada wasn't touched... Although fresh enough that I would pick at it... I thought dessert (tres leches) would be chocolate overload but was had less chocolatey flavor than expected... Service was fine (friendly if a little inattentive) and the salsas were authentic....
The wait staff were excellent. My wife had been there with a friend a couple of years ago. The food was as beautifully prepared and as tasteful as my wife had predicted!
Possibly the most over-hyped restaurant I have ever been to. Great margaritas, but you will find better Mexican food at any authentic Mom and Pop shop at a third of the cost.

Frontera does not dissapoint.  It was taco Tuesday and we were in dire need of finding a Mexican restaurant with some edge.  We walked in around 5-ish and the joint was already packed.  Lots of working professionals in need of a margarita or five...  It was about an hour wait to get a table so we decided to go to the bar area and grab some drinks and guacamole.  Let me tell you the guacamole was superb.  You really cant beat fresh guacamole.  And it was filling.  I really didn't need to eat dinner with the tasty adult beverages and chips but I did!  I ordered ceviche trio and then made my partner in crime order dessert.  We got the basics... vanilla bean ice-cream with thick yummy chocolate amazing-ness.   This place has been around for many years and is still very popular. Good job Mr. Bayless.

Visiting from California, where good, authentic Mexican food is easily available, my husband and I were disappointed in this meal.  The standout was the "famous" chicken tortilla soup, which had great umami and smoky flavours, and I hope to recreate at home.  The rest?  Tasted like high-end Chevy's designed for a non-Mexican crowd.  Paying the bill kind of killed me, even though it cost what I had expected to pay, because the meal was nowhere near as good as we had hoped for.

Very refined Mexican food.  The Guacamole was simple, creamy, and delicious as it should be.  The Sopecitio Rancheros made for a wonderful appetizer.  The braised chick filling was rich and well-seasoned.  Everything at the table was excellent.  The margaritas were a standout as well.
Had brunch here. The sopes with meat appetizers were really good. Their steak tacos and chicken tacos are good too. Not a huge fan of the duck tacos.

Whether in downtown Chicago or at O'Hare, you must eat at Frontera. We arrived right when they opened, were seated outdoors and enjoyed the trio of ceviche. Sadly, it's been so long, that I forgot what else we had. Upon departing Chicago we got tortas for our flight. Can't wait to return!

Food was delicious but I must say the waiter name David (so he said) was terrible. He walked pass my table multiple times without asking how our food was or anything.  I would go back but hopefully I get another waiter with a more friendly attitude.

Ignore the hype seems to be right on for this place. Finally got a reservation in after three years and very disappointed. Appetizers were the only good thing about the whole meal and our server was okay. The hostesses made us work for their attention and didn't set a very welcoming experience , never saw a manager after our food had to be taken back, and the menu prices are outrageous for the quality. The tamales were dry and had the consistency of grainy cornbread, the tacos were okay but had absolutely no flavor to the meat and veggies. As we were finishing the whole staff was basically congregated and hanging out behind the bar while managers sat at the bar eating and all of the employees soon followed and sat down to start eating at tables around other eating customers while they were still in the establishment. I don't know if I'm just not used to that but I work in the restaurant industry and have for the past seven years and one of my biggest pet peeves is this scenario. There has to be somewhere else like an empty part of the restaurant or break area for employees to go to enjoy lunch too especially while there are still people here. Still got charged for food we sent back as well. Won't be coming back.

Overall good. Abalone ceviche; great flavors. The best I have eaten. Guacamole with red and green salsa: good. Chips are more crispy and thicker. Gordita with Chicharonnes: okay. Lack the pork grind flavor that the name promised. My husband didn't like it. Is okay for me. It was stuffed with pork and scrambled egg,  Steak taco was cooked just as I asked, good flavor. Bean side dish was good. Not as great as I would expect from a James Beard winner.

The food was good (excellent ceviche and sopas, slightly above average tortilla soup and my husband was disappointed with pork loin), the Tequila was excellent, but the service was terrible. Felt rushed from the moment we sat down and felt pushed out the door after our meal was over, to the point of rudeness.  I get that they want to turn tables (I too was a server at one time), but we are customers too, that dropped a good amount of money, and I won't be back.

I was traveling alone and figured I would try and snag a place at the bar of a nice restaurant for a Saturday night dinner! I love Mexican and had a great torta from Frontera in the airport, so I was very excited to try the restaurant! I arrived at 5:05 PM and the bar area was already packed! The hostess assured me that things would clear out around 5:15 when they started seating in the restaurant. That was indeed true, but I had to be vigilant to snag a seat as people cleared out, as many had the same plan as me. I sat at the bar and received absolutely wonderful service from the woman at the bar. This was better service than you would typically get at a restaurant, which was impressive. I started with the fresh tuna tostada. The amount of fresh tuna was impressive, although it did make the tostada a bit difficult to eat. I hoped for the dish to have some spice, but it was a bit bland. Perhaps I should have gone with the ceviche. For the main course, I enjoyed the skirt steak tacos. The steak was cooked perfectly. The salsas were good but, again, not very spicy. My favorite part was probably the beans - I don't typically like beans very much, but these had a smoky delicious flavor. The price of the food really isn't bad. It is the drinks that get you!! But damn, they are some good drinks. I highly recommend the Blue Agave Margarita!

The tortilla soup is to die for! They bring all the ingredients separate then pour the liquid into the bowl. One of the tastiest meals on the menus no doubt. The guac is not worth it since they don't give you enough for the price.

Ignore the hype - This was a bad experience from the start. The front of house staff could learn some lessons in customer service. The hostesses were rude and on a complete power trip. . It was difficult to get any wait staff to stop to ask a question or place an order; they just rushed by and ignored us. We were forced to wait over an hour despite numerous open tables. It seemed highly unorganized.  The music was loud, making it necessary  to shout to have a conversation. With all the tables doing this, it was annoying. Just turning down the music a bit could make it a better place to eat. And the tables are so jammed together you get bumped by the wait staff as the go by, but you may appreciate the body heat because the temperature control was horrible. It kept going from warm to very cold, so bring a jacket.  The food was way over-priced. $20 for tacos is outrageous, even for downtown Chicago. And you will pay more if you want a small basket of chips, which is free at most other Mexican restaurants. The food was mediocre. The beef came out cold and unevenly cooked. Some slices were well done and some were barely seared. The guacamole had no flavor; it was smashed avocado with a few bits of tomato. Highly disappointing. The one good aspect was the tortillas. Hot and delicious.  A colleague recommends the ceviche trio. The choco layer desert was yummy, BUT you better crush on nutmeg or skip the ice cream. Overall, I expected better and was disappointed. Not worth the wait or the price.

Huge fans of the Rick Bayless cooking show, we had to pay a visit. Absolutely no regrets! The ceviche was done of the best we have ever had. The Trio offering is the way to go. You get to taste the fish,  and the shrimp ceviche.  We mentioned to the bartender that we were huge fans. The next thing we knew, we were invited to meet Rick in the kitchen! What a great experience!

OH.MY.WORD!!! We have eaten excellent food all over this weekend but THIS IS THE PLACE. It is DELICIOUS AND FRESH and makes me wish I lived here. Being from Texas, I was hesitant to eat Mexican food somewhere else but I'm so glad I did!! AWESOME!!

Mezcal and tequila selection that is just... dangerous. So much variety. Funnily we've dined at almost every other Bayless restaurant but only recently made it to the original one that started it all. No one is resting on their laurels here - authentic and creative and generally crazy delicious.
Rick Bayless is simply the bomb.  For an American, he is certainly killing it in the world of Mexican food.  Each time I'm in Chicago, i make it a point to visit one of his establishments.
Over the Top. Great food great lunch. Had the Tortilla soup.. best ever and the Shrimp. WOW! Will not disappoint.

After trying to make reservations for some time now, I finally was able to get a "decent" dinner time this past Friday (4/28/17) at 8:30pm.  I was very excited to come try Bayless' creations, melting of flavors...I was very disappointed. FOOD: I had the Enchiladas de Pollo, Puebla style.  When I cut into them, the tortilla opened up, it wasn't cooked well.  It was cold, usually when a tortilla does that, it means it's cold.  The mole sauce was savory and yummy.  The beans were decent too. DECOR: I was very disappointed with the decoration of the restaurant, it had a "fast food" joint feel to it & it was crowded....tables really close to each other. I had the pleasure of eating at Frontera Cocina last summer when I was out in Orlando, FL.  That restaurant was beautiful, big, open...the pation was cozy and beautiful.  The food was delicious.  I guess having tried the Frontera Cocina made me have high expectation of the food and venue.  I am sadden to say, I wouldn't go back again.

I had to make reservation months in advance. There was 6 of us so I understand that is never easy when dining with a bigger group at a very popular restaurant. Sometimes it is crazy to me to think this place has been around for so long and still before opening this place has a line out the door.  This past Saturday my family and I went to Aladdin and then had reservations at 6PM for 6 people. We got out of the play early and thought maybe they could take us early. There was a line out the door before opening at 5PM. We decided to grab a drink at bottlefork which is just next door. At 5:40, we walked next door to Frontera and walked in to a packed Frontera lobby/bar area. I walked up to the host stand and was welcomed by polite staff and escorted to our table.  We sat in the basement which is a lot different than the upstairs. I prefer the downstairs, more quiet, not as chaotic, a little chillier but personal opinion a better experience than the craziness that is upstairs. Some people want that energy but I liked the subdued basement. Our waiter was pleasant and refilled water/soda glasses, and got our drinks promptly, as the rest of our food. Here is what we ordered: Starter: -Basic Guacamole- delightful comes with a handful of chips, bowl of guacamole, and two salsas. I could of ate the whole thing myself, but best served for about two people Entrees: -Cauliflower Steak- Take a cauliflower slice in half and roast it. Top with black beans. It was a lovely somewhat healthy dish -Pork Tacos- good, basic  -Pork Enchiladas- good, basic -Smoked Chicken with the skin with sweet corn sauce- chicken is sliced and served over a sweet corn heavenly sauce, mashed potatoes and green beans. Super good if you like chicken and cream sauces.  -Carne Asada Brava- really good, thinly sliced steak, and the tamales that come with it are amazing  Sides: -Mash Potatoes-thick creamy heaven -Fried Sweet Plantains- topped with crema which was subtle and amazing -Traditional Black Beans- Frontera's black beans are my favorite black beans ever. Thick, served in a mini cast iron skillet. sooo good.  Dessert:  Mexican Chocolate Ice Cream with a side of Chocolate Sauce- good for one to two people. Chocolate creamy ice cream. With a silky side of chocolate Mexican Vanilla Ice Cream- tasted more like sorbet than ice cream. Sweeter and light. It was good.
The best food I've had in Chicago out of all my trips here!  The Carne Asada was amazing and our server, Panch, was fantastic!  Worth every minute we waited and every dollar spent!

The service here is exceptional. The waitstaff is so helpful and has some great recommendations. I enjoyed everything - the quesadillas, the margaritas, the poblano enchiladas, the rice. Everything is delicious! No complaints.
Food was overhyped. Would not come back. Tomato soup was good and chicken tacos were good. Everything else was relatively disappointing. Very cold and service not amazing.

All I need to say for this "Gringo" to be knocking it out of the ball park...Effen fantastic! Brought the family of Five and they all enjoyed their food selections!  Pricey yes, worth it, no doubt (not the music group). Have to try it at east once...Dammit! Enjoy,  Cheers!!!

Rick Bayless we love you!! This was of course our first stop in Chicago.  Rick really knows what he's doing and we have been following him for years on PBS.  Some people might think, "well how does this white dude know how to cook Mexican?' Don't listen to them!! We are from San Antonio, Texas and my husband is from Mexico and this is authentic cooking.  I would normally not dine out for Mexican when I'm out of town, but for this I make an exception.  Frontera is in the middle of prices not super cheap but not super crazy expensive, be prepared to spend 20-30 on a dish. Inside the bar area is decorated with beautiful Oaxacan colorful artwork, (we only ate in the bar area - so not sure about the dining area).  Tables are a bit on the smaller side in the bar area so make sure to tell the hostess what you prefer.   We started out with the trio ceviche, presentation was beautiful as well as the taste, a very shareable plate.  Main dishes were the shrimp macha - it had some great spice to it and was very generous on the shrimp portion.  The mango halibut was also good size (two large fillets), a great sear on the fish and flavor again on point. I really love that Frontera is sustainable in their food choices, so the menu is always changing. I've even heard that they have a rooftop garden that they utilize for his restaurants.  I'll for sure be back again!
OMG!!  A favorite stop when in Chicago.  Great food!  By the time I'm done with tamales, guacamole and other apps there's no room for an entree - oh, well!  Sangria is good, too. Nom, nom, nom...

Overrated & over-hyped. I was disappointed with the street food, main course & dessert. The splurge margarita was the only impressive item & that was $35. Service was nice..not worth the price..won't go again. Frontera Fresco in Macy's food court is surprisingly better by far as others have mentioned.

This place has been around for ages (at least ages for me) and its only reciently that I finally got around to go to it! I thought it was going to be good, but not really knocked my socks off.  I was wrong, my socks were knocked off!  Our table was not ready so I went to the bar for a tasty margarita. Tasty indeed!  I came during restaurant week which might have worked to their advantage as I got an appetizer and dessert. The tamale was great and flavorful as a starter. I paid the upcharge and went with the carne asada. Wow! So good! I finally finished with a chocolate mousse with nuts and it was phenominal. Of course, Bayless is known for his sauces which I have to say were top notch.

This place already has a lot of great reviews, and they are all well deserved. The staff is friendly, and they are very good at gauging their customer's spice level tolerance.  But of course, the most important thing is the food. It was spectacular. I had the duck in apricot mole. It was complex, it was a perfect blend of spicy, sweet, salty, warm, and the duck was a perfect medium rare. Truly amazing food.

They lost my reservation but thanks to them texting me to confirm the night before, was able to salvage it and was seated within 10 minutes. Joint was jumping full throttle on a Wednesday night. Service excellent. Food excellent. Bus boys (men) who are busting their chops to get things cleaned off and tables turned over. Delicious REAL Mexican food at reasonable prices. I will be back again and again.

Delicious everything. Took my native Mexican father in law here and he was very impressed. I'd say that was a great compliment. My kids devoured the quesadilla and rice...Also a huge compliment. My wife absolutely loved it, the food, service and the music. This place has quickly become one of my favourite spots.

An amazing restaurant with delicious food/drink (Jamaica sangria!) The service is impeccable. Alejandro is top notch in customer service. I make reservations here everytime I know I'm going to be in the area. I highly recommend dining here.

Honest review: idk why there are so many bad reviews of this restaurant.The food is amaizing and authentic.I understand that its pricy,not the biggiest portions,and the service sucked, having a bad experience doesn't mean this place sucks.You also cant just order two menu items and say the food sucks when u just tried two things Service:i hated the service called for reservations they said its to packed came n there were alot of tables open.When i got there they said 1 hour wait n when this person left a new person came n was like oh i can sit u now?Idk why restaurants do this if i wasnt hungry i would have left so rude to lie to customers to make it seem like ur busy is pathetic.Then are server was a dick.we would try to ask for things n he would jus run by us?If i was the manager would fire the employee.Get:pozole,ceviche ,tamal, steak,toffee pudding, tres leche Butternut squash Bocoles 10$:supper tasty! The chicken was supper tender and flavorful, the salsa was nice and spicy and smokey. I liked the cheese cut down the spicyness. Didnt taste the butternut squash the sweetness would have been good. It is kinda like a gordita.  One thing it needed was some crunch, and a wow factor. It was good but not as amaizn as everything else.  Ceviche trio ofof24$: must order!!! Shrimp scapllop ceviche verde (green one in the middle) amaizin!! The seafood was really tender it was a lil spicy and the sauce wasnt to acidic this was my favorite one the cucumber and the jimica added freshness to cut through the richness. Like nothing overpowered the seafood. Tropical tuna: this was my second favorite. Its like a guac with tuna and papaya amaizin. The guac is spicy and acidic n the fruit is really sweet complimented the tuna perfectly. My only complaint is the tuna was to soft add something crunchy or pick seafood with texture. Classic: this is like a fancy version of what people are use to. Its really acidic n the fish wasnt over powered really tasty. I would recommend getting the unique ceviches. I would love if u could pick which ceviches u want in the trio that would be awesome! Tamal colado $9: best tomal i ever had. The tamal was supper tender i hate when their dry. The tamal was sweet so it paired perfectly with the savory dish. The turkey was supper tender and flavorful. The broth was supper rich so decadent so much depth of flavor. Just pls add more broth. The onions on top were so spicy i loved it!! I would order this again Shrimp pozole $28 sorry abuelita rick bayless pozole is better then urs! The broth is so rich and full of depth! The only issue put more broth plz!! N it was spicy yes! Couldnt stop eating. The reason why its so expensive is because there is so much shrimp. The shrimp was cooked perfectly and was so flavorful. I liked that they used cabbage instead of lettuce way more flavorful. I loved the radish adds a nice fresh note. The harmony was a little to hard for my taste wish they could do something more inventive like fry it that would be cool. Wish instead of grilled tortillas they would have gave us chicharon had it once like that cont go back! Then give me a lemon not a lime plz i would order this in a heart beat Oaxacan carne asada $34: expensive but best steak youll ever have. Served with tortillas eat it as a taco with everything! The ribeye was grilled beutifully and seasoned so good so flavorful. Cooked perfectly. The reason why this is one of the best steaks is instead of just putting salt n pepper it has other delicious components that work well together. The sauce is supper rich and spicy like i wish i could drink it. The plantains added a nice sweet note to cut through the richness. The guac was creamy and acidic and the raw onions cut through the richness. Then black beans yes black beans taste the best makes the taco the best my only complaint wish there was something crunchy and add more tortillas plz! Sticky toffee tamarind pudding $9: (its like a moist cake): the cake was really moist, the tamarind sauce was really acidic which cuts through the richness of the dish. The menu said it was infused with chili put more plz because it would cut through the sourness and sweetness and make it a better dish.goat cheese ice cream was amaizin perfect texture but more goat cheese plz couldnt tell it was goatcheese.the bacon was amaizin love sweet and savory omg more desserts need bacon just needs a less smokier bacon would order this again  Dos tres cuatro cake $9 omg it was amaizin and i hate mexican hot chocolate. The cake was supper moist n not to sweet. Its chocolate on chocolate the top is like chocolate brittle then theres candied nuts the texture of this dish was amaizin! Loved the merangue so tasty!! Then theres chocolate icecream!!! Omg if u love chocolate order this must order only complaints just wish there was something acidic, savory, or spicy but i loved it. Chocolate pecan pie 8.50$: amaizin but not as good as other

I have eaten dinner at Frontera Grill twice now and it is one of my favorite restaurants. Rick Bayless designed a menu of familiar Mexican dishes with simplicity and panaché that I truly enjoyed. The first time I visited, I had a reservation for myself, which had been secured more than a month in advance. The second time, I ate at the bar alongside the kitchen without a reservation. Both times I began with ceviches from the raw seafood bar along with a draft Negro Modelo, that wonderful example of Vienna lager.  For entrées, I have tried the carne asada brava, basically flank steak with tamales and corn, and the next time I ate the carnes al cabron with duck breast medium rare, which are duck corn tacos covered in habañero salsa. The duck tacos were truly memorable and I still think about trying to replicate them in my own kitchen. After eating, be sure to enjoy a sipping añejo tequila as an digestif. I will certainly return to eat here again.
Waited three months to get in only to experience a curt hostess, an indifferent server, luke warm food, and noise that made it difficult to talk. Not likely to return.

Been meaning to stop in for a while now, we finally did. My margarita was fabulous, one of the best I've ever had. We had the Classic Frontera ceviche to start and it did not disappoint. Wonderful lime flavor, and the way it was served was very cool. We were a little let down by the mole sauce on our entrees, but every place has an off night now and then so I'm not one to let it affect the whole experience. Overall, it was great. I will return next even if only for the bar area because those margaritas were damn good.

Horrible service poor quality food, not authentic Mexican food, lemonade was to sour, they could not split the check the system is very outdated, the waiter was not friendly don't feel he liked his job. It a real shame they no idea what is good restaurant details are very important.

Ok people, listen closely and repeat after me. "Tourist Trap." No doubt this was ONCE a great restaurant. But no longer. Bayless....no. Just no. I went in tonight after several times trying but 3 hour waits. I was alone so a spot at the bar would be great. First impression was cold, unfriendly bartenders.  I would even say rude at times - friendly when the bill came.  The food in my opinion was Chipotle level. I had sopacitas and the "little boats" were hard and tasteless. The beef average. Also had quacamole. Average. Granted I live in Los Angeles but come on... Marguerita poured from a pitcher that was seriously worse than a pre fab mix from the grocery store.  I cancelled my future reservation that I made weeks in advance. I will not subject honey to this.  I've learned my lesson and sticking with the not so famous places but that are packed for all the right reasons!

This is the best restaurant in Chicago. All fresh, often organic and full of taste. The staff are fun and nice. The art and decor is beautiful and colorful. Ilike to eat at the bar as well as the dining area.

I went back and forth between 4 and 5 stars. Ultimately, this is probably not an exciting restaurant anymore, but everything that comes out is top quality. One of my favorite things to order here is some kind of braised meat that comes with an infinite amount of tortillas (actually six I think). Given that you could easily split this dish between two (I was in Chicago for work and sat at the bar and ate the entire thing alone like a sad, crazy person), this is not an expensive restaurant.

I have been trying to get into this place for 5 years because of all the hype and FINALLY we get in after putting our name down and driving around for two hours.  However I have no clue what all the hype is about, really it is uber expensive and the food is not good even at standard prices.   Food - We got taquitos and ceviche as an appetizer.  I can honestly say i like the taquitos in bulk from Costco better, as they have more flavor and aren't dry as a bone.  The ceviche had this horrible overpowering sour taste, the scallops had scallop consistency but tasted like "sour patch kids."  For dinner I ordered the carne asada.  Meh, nothing great.  It was near 25-35 bucks though.  Steak was dry, sauce was decent, came with this weird latin biscuit thing that was like eating sand.   Service - took near 2 hours  Not returning, huge let down, the hype is not real
A Chicago stalwart.  Great food, better service.  Birria special on Tuesday is a must.  Brunch is also fantastic.  Buen provecho!

Over a decade of patronage and I can't get enough. Fresh, authentic.... better words and description are posted throughout by people who make it their job crafting words. Believe everything written that is positive!  Brunch is fantastic and I love eating it outside in the summer Staff are some of the hardest working people I've ever ever seen and attentive. Full of life this place.
None of the six distinct drinks ordered by my party were drinkable.  Terrible bar.  Would not return.

4-4.5 stars.  Came here for Restaurant Week with a large group (split into three tables).  At first our table (that had a reservation) was told that they wouldn't seat us until everyone was there (I was running about 5 minutes late), but then it became clear that our table just wasn't ready.  When it was ready, they had it set up for 8 (our group had 9), and they originally just wanted to squeeze an extra person in the booth (but later brought a chair), and we were seated about a half hour past our reservation time. Once we got past that, the food was pretty good.  The Rosa Mexicana cocktail was delicious (not too sweet), the ceviche was my favorite of the night, the Chicken Pipan was well-cooked and flavorful, but there was a little too much heat for me to fully enjoy it (I am a bit of a wimp when it comes to heat, though), and the sopa di frutas was good, but nothing outstanding (and kind of on the small side).  The service seemed on the slow side, as it took us a full two hours for the meal. Overall, I'm glad I finally got to experience a Rick Bayless restaurant (and apparently he was there that night, as some of my friends got a picture of him).  The food was good, but the service left a little to be desired.  Maybe it was because it was Restaurant Week, so I might be a little forgiving, but that kept it from being 5 stars.

Overall: A Rick Bayless (and Chicago) staple, Frontera is a solid option for a classier Latin experience. The good: Obviously, the food is the highlight. Restaurant week had some great choices. The ceviche was awesome, really hearty and flavorful. The chicken pipian was spicy and flavorful, but I wish I would've gotten my friend's skate wing even more. Service was friendly and the atmosphere is colorful and exciting. The not-so-good: Some of the food elements fell flat. The crunchy tortilla in the pipian was stale, the dessert (sorbet) tasted great but was just simply too small. The music was surprisingly annoying, they played pop music instead of more authentic vibes. Atmosphere: 9.5/10 Service: 8/10 Food: 8.5/10 P.S: I've been to Topolobampo and it's WELL worth the money! I don't care what the Yelp reviews say
Excellent salsa, tacos , drinks , and it is a true Top Chef  restaurant as Rick Bayless is fantastic. Food 5  Service 5 De'cor 4

Frontera Grill my son's choice for a very long time we finally made it here.   I was so surprised to be seated right away.  No waiting and right afterward we got seated it got so crowded.   I like to give compliments to the cooks the food was so delicious.   We order three appetizers and the ceviche trio was out of this world.   I was so surprised that the food was very authentic and spicy and to see that all the people around us truly enjoyed the spiciness infusions.   The shrimp pozole was so neatly decorated with huge grilled shrimps and small hand made tostaditas on top garnish with shredded cabbage.   My son ordered the carne Asada this stake was a huge rib eye stake tender and juicy with a side of black beans and garnished with queso fresco on top and the most delicious soft fried plantains bathed with crema simply splendid.   My mom had a agave margarita it was very good.   I asked my server if he could bring me some spicy Habanero sauce little did I know that it was extremely flaming hot and delicious .  I had been taking theraflu for three days and I still was feeling sick a few drops of this amazing Habanero sauce "y Dios Mio". I can hear and smell and I fell better.  Warning  very hot.   All the server are very courteous and sweet.   I will be coming soon.  Gracias amigos

Went with family and we all ordered something different and shared. Everything was amazing but the carne asada was the winner at out table. The red snapper was a close second. Service was great and we were seated within 2 minutes of our reservation time. Fantastic dining experience in a really cool atmosphere.

Super disappointed! I came here a few years ago for graduation dinner and I thought the food was so much better! I'm not sure if it's just me, but I also feel like the portions got way tinier and the entrees are not big enough to fill anyone up at all. I ordered the steak tacos which were $20 and it came with the saddest looking baby pile of skirt steak :( I could barely make 3 tacos out of them. The guacamole was flavorless and I was sad. My boyfriend got the duck mole with plantain dumplings and it was equally as small and disappointing. We also got the tamales as an appetizer and it somehow ended up being the biggest dish.. But they were dry and sad also. The best thing was the horchata. Our server was also super sweet, but that was about it for highlights. What happened to you Frontera?!

Super super delicious! I love ceviche and sadly the dish  I wanted to try shrimp and scallop I believe was out. I instead went with the house ceviche and it was lovely. The drinks were very well made as well! Will certainly be back next time I'm in the neighborhood.

I have had a bit of an obsession with Rick Bayless since I discovered Xoco and watched him win Top Chef Masters season 1.  I had high expectations but the food at Frontera did not disappoint.  The only reason I didn't give it a 5 was because not every part of the food was a home run, and the ambiance was loud. Food - butternut squash bocales- delectable! The salsa negra was fantastic and the corn masa cakes were crispy and delicious  - trio of carnes al carbon- the chicken was the best, followed by steak, followed by duck.  If I redid this order I would skip the duck.  The entire platter was very tasty, loved the salsa, guacamole and shishito peppers- that's what made it unique.  The trio is a ton of food for 2 people.  We were very full since we also had an app. -dos, tres, Quatro cake- I ordered this when we were full thinking we could take it home.  Did not last more than 5 min on the plate.  Talk about innovative take on tres leches, tasty! Drinks  -old smokey- like an old fashioned but not special -rosa mexicano- this was special! Great flavor  -Paloma- unique with the spicy kick -oaxacan gold- special and tasty Service -excellent, attentive and gave good recommendations Ambiance -love the authentic decor - too loud

Have wanted to come here for such a long time. I really want to go to Topolo, but its outside my price range. I've been to Xoco, and had a torta from Frontera at O'Hare, but wanted to try the restaurant. My sister made reservations for lunch, and we had a huge party--nine people! The space was a little cramped for nine, and it was noisy- difficult to hear the people at our own table, but I was just glad to be there.  I tried the pork/chorizo/plantain enchiladas with the black-bean sauce. I tasted sweetness, but no definite bite of plantain. I am addicted to beans, so I loved the sauce and want to pour it on everything I eat from now on. We also shared a flan, which was just fine, as I'm not a fan of flan. Now after this meal, I really want to try Topolo!

Food is great! I love all the dishes I ordered. My server was very arrogant though and wasn't willing to serve me. I sat down he asked if I would like to order a drink, I told him that I would like to start with a hot water. Immediately he walked away and ignored me, he proceeded to take order from the table next to me. After a while I tried to asked him what's good in the menu since it's my first time there, his reply "everything is good" then walked away. After waiting for 20min my hot water has not arrived yet and he also don't show any sign to want to serve my table. Probably he thought I was cheap to not order a margarita or something and just ask for a hot water. I decided I should try ask another server. Luckily The restaurant manager saw me, he was great! He explained the menu, very kind and polite. I ended up ordering a sparkling wine(cava) which was delicious and A ceviche also a chicken mole. The server that was supposed to served my table sees that and suddenly become very friendly, started coming to asked if my food was ok and asked if I would like to order any dessert? Anything I would like to know? I told him No, I would like to have the check. I know the restaurant manager put the table under his serving so he would get the tip, I was thinking to actually leave no tip since he didn't serve me but after a while I decided I should tip since the restaurant manager did help me and he was great at explaining all the dishes.

Went in to celebrate my fiancé's birthday - was not disappointed. Warm and friendly ambiance - not pretentious as you might expect from a high end restaurant. Had the chips and guacamole to start with - delicious. For entree - we shared the taco platter - more than enough for 2 people and highly enjoyable. Highly recommend it.

I'm late to the party. I finally tried this place after having heard so many people rave about it. The logistics of planning ahead to eat here where reservations are hardly taken were made easier when I found myself dining solo. Bar area is first come first serve, and there were 2 seats opened.  The Old Smokey was a Mexican take on the old fashioned. It was fine, just fine. I asked the server's recommendation between the Classic Frontera Ceviche, Tropical Tuna Cocktail, and Hiramasa. He suggested the first, and so I went with it. It was a little too acidic/citrusy/sour for me. I went with the Feature Fish, Veracruz Style. It was a grilled whitefish and the sauce was also just fine. The fish was a little too overcooked, IMO. It wasn't hard and dry by any means, but fresh fish should be grilled until *just* cooked when the flakes are still soft and juicy. The 2 best things that came out of this meal: 1) the housemade tortillas served on the side was the best I've had, and 2) I can finally say "Yes, been here, done that."

Outstanding New Years Eve menu last night but what impressed me the most was the excellent service.  Every staff member greeted us and wished us a Happy New Year from the coat check ladies to Rick walking through the bar area.  The beautiful decor and artwork, service and food made for a special evening out with friends.
Outstanding drinks. I am not a mixed drinks guy but this was awesome! Highly recommend to get their special of the day. Enjoy! Best Mexican food

Basically the only restaurant my food-loving sister told me to go to while in Chicago, so I made it a point to come by here. She also mentioned she wasn't able to get a table because of a 3-hour wait during dinner time and she didn't have a reservation. Cue coming here for lunch! We got here around 12:00pm on a Friday, and there weren't too many people, maybe just a couple of other tables of people. By the time we left around 1-1:30, the place was packed! I was originally thrown off by the $$$ sign on the Yelp page, but there were quite a few affordable items on the menu.  The lengua and chorizo enchiladas were a bit on the cheesier side, but the chorizo managed to cut through that - could hardly taste the lengua though. The chips and guac were impeccable and the ceviche trio was really, really good!  Our waitress was amazing - she even threw in some free tequila shots at the end and was an absolute sweetheart explaining the menu to us.

A few years back, we were gifted a gift card to the Rick Bayless restaurants. Being that we just confirmed my pregnancy and I wanted to truly enjoy a well-made margarita, we decided it would best to hold off and go after our baby was born.  Fast forward to nearly two years later (because newborn/baby life is hard), we made our escape to the city and finally had the meal that we were craving for a few years.  It was definitely crowded when we arrived, which is was the typical lunchtime hour at just around 11:30. Since there were no immediate tables, there was bar-style seating available. We are not picky people, and since our stomachs were already churning with hunger, we decided to indulge in a true Cantina style.  We ordered the appetizer of queso fundido, and I might just have introduced my husband to his new addiction. Whoops! I ordered the mole enchiladas and my husband ordered steak and egg enchiladas for our entrees. All were absolutely delicious and I could eat 10 more plates if I had more room in my stomach. The drinks, my margarita and my husband's beer, were also equally delicious but not of utmost priority as the food took the main stage.

Second time here for an event, in the small event room downstairs. Very good Mexican inspired food. We had typical fare - guac & chips, carne asada, some had the shrimp dish. Served with warm tortillas, refried beans, all the good stuff. There was a dessert sampling with a pecan chocolate tart, a couple of flans and a tres leches cake - overall good. Did not see the prices so don't know how good a deal it is, but it is definitely tasty Mexican food!
I had the Friday lunch special, mole negro (pork), and a) I never liked asparagus until today, and b) it was Fabulous.  Especially after a warmup with the tortilla soup.

I really enjoyed this restaurant.  Honestly, I was seriously afraid of this restaurant being overhyped, but I was super pleasantly surprised and ended up loving it.   Before I get into anything else, the decor is so nice.  My wife loved it.  Just thought I'd get that out of the way. I secured reservations for this place about 5 weeks in advance.  The earliest seating I could get a for a Friday night was at 9:30pm, which was a little disappointing.  Me and my wife were in the area and decided to stop in at 7:30pm and see if we could get put on a wait list or something like that, and they ended up seating us immediately!   Hurray!  Unfortunately, I was really disappointed when I found out that the SUADERO AHUMADO 20-hour-smoked beef brisket w mole was sold out (It's the Friday special.... try to book a friday early to get it!!).  Sold out by 7:45pm when we ordered!!!! SOOOO DISAPPOINTING :(    That's ok though, the menu is robust enough with tons of other great options.   We ordered: CLASSIC FRONTERA CEVICHE - Delicious.... classic flavors with just enough kick to it.  SOPECITOS RANCHEROS - The star of the dinner honestly.  The sopecitos were perfectly crispy and the braised beef inside was so delicious. OAXACAN CARNE ASADA - This was a quality steak with a nice rub.  I wouldn't say that it was too unique.  The rub was quite nice. Comes with fresh made tortillas for some way too good DIY steak tacos. PORK, MANCHAMENTELES - This was also quite tasty.  Not as flavorful as the apps, but so good regardless.  DÚO DE FLANES - our dessert.  just some standard good flan. The total was not unreasonable at all.. less than $80 for the 2 of us, for this quality of a meal.  We loved it!!  Would love to come back to try more stuff, but unfortunately, we live thousand miles away.  He's opening a Red O near me in San Diego though,which I can't wait to try.

This was the highlight of my recent girls weekend in Chicago. Tiffany C is the only person I know who has a love affair with Mexican food like I do so coming here was a must. I secured reservations about a month in advance and still the earliest seating was 9 PM. And it was crazy busy still at that hour!   The host stand was a bit nuts and we waited about 10 minutes to be seated. Led to our table for 2 we were sat closely between another table of 2 and a rather loud obnoxious table of 4. We ended up talking briefly with both of the parties next to us, that's how close we were. It didn't bother me, I'm a friendly person but keep this in mind if you don't enjoy that. Might not be the best place for a romantic date but perhaps you can request a more private table.  On to the food, the wonderful food. I'm just going to disclose now that we ordered way too much food!  We started with the guacamole and chips and salsa. The green Verde salsa was amazing. The guac was good and the chips were fresh and tasty. Tortilla soup is one of my favorites and I have to say that Bayless does it better than anyone. The presentation is fabulous and the broth has so many layers of flavor. It's a large portion and I was sad to see it come to an end. I chose the fresh fish selection and it was a light and flaky snapper that was melt in your mouth delicious in a wonderful and unique mushroom sauce. Tiffanie ordered the special of the day (Friday) which was the brisket and was disappointed when they were out of it (darn 9 PM reservation!). She asked our waiter to choose her entrée and let him know she wanted something unique. Her entrée ended up being the duck and she loved it. We had initially talked about dessert but we were both too full to think about it.  I would recommend this place to anyone who wants to try modern Mexican food. Just make your reservations far in advance and for Pete's sake don't try to order fajitas like the loud guy at the table next to us did!

Were I to become any sort of professional chef the kind I'd most desire to be is one whose resume looks a lot like that of Frontera Grill owner, Rick Bayless.  His is a deep, anthropological dive into the cuisines of Mexico involving many years of culinary research.  The mere idea of learning - then being able to execute - the wide variety of regional Mexican cuisines strikes me as fascinating and worthy of attention.  As a result, dining at Bayless' original restaurant, Frontera Grill, while visiting Chicago was a no-brainer.   Frontera Grill is one of 3 Bayless owned restaurants sitting in a row on N. Clark Street.  He's got all ground covered with an inexpensive torta shop (XOCO) and a high-end, Michelin star venue (Topolobampo).  Frontera Grill fits the mid-slot quite nicely, specializing in Contemporary regional cuisine with special emphasis on the region of Oaxaca.   Lunching at Frontera was fun.  For starters, they seated us in the bar area, a section which appeared reserved for women who do lunch.  Small 2-3 person tables dominated this area - filled with females - with a gleaming full bar sitting across a narrow walkway.  I honestly never missed seeing the main dining room.   With small tabletops it's easy to fill them and there's no pleasure so fine as a table overflowing with a wide variety of excellent Mexican fare.  My dining companion was thinking of ordering an entree until I persuaded her of the benefits of ordering exclusively from the "Appetizers", "Starters", and "Sides" section of the menu.  If you're adventurous and want to try a whole lot of different flavors this is how I'd recommend approaching the menu.    Begin with one of 6 Margaritas ranging in price from $11-$30 then sit back and watch your table fill up.  Ours was a Bacchanalian orgy of riches:  Classic Queso Fundido ($8, fabulous), Taquitos Banados ($8), Frontera Guacamole ($9), Sopecita Rancheros ($8), Fresh Corn Tamales ($7), and a couple of additional small specials.  I'd be fibbing only a wee bit if I told you we ate it all.  A few bites were left on only a couple of plates; the rest were practically licked clean.   It's true that there was nothing I tasted here that I've not tasted elsewhere but the flavors here are true and pure, the result of using the best ingredients possible.  Frontera's menu reads like one from a top San Francisco restaurant:  "organic", "sustainably raised", "local", and "artisanal" are words that can be found all over it.  And they know what to do with these top ingredients.   Frontera has been around for a long time and felt not at all like it was resting on any laurels.  Without reservation I can say that, if you're anything like me, you'll leave here quite delighted by the experience.

In Chicago for a conference and so happy we were recommended to this restaurant.  The staff and food were excellent,ceviche and oysters for apps,coupled with some delicious cocktails was just the beginning.  Our waiter has been at this establishment for many years and now I know why.  He was attentive to our table with great food recommendations.   The place is a bit noisy but I didn't go there to talk as much as to enjoy the food, which was accomplished with flying colors. Make a reservation and you won't be disappointed.
