Got here at 8 on a Wednesday without a reservation and were seated around 9. We ordered one of the ceviches and it was mediocre - a bit oversalted. I ordered the fish which was very good, but my friend was not impressed with his duck. Service was good but ambience was lacking.

Steak was great(medium rare) fluke was ok. I ordered it because I haven't had fluke since 2002. Wasn't so good. REAL PROBLEM : fruit flies hovering around our $100 bottle wine. Fruit flies in this kind of establishment is not ok! Clean your taps.

The steak was cold, and we sent it back. They just reheated and gave it back- not what I would expect if I'm spending 100 bucks on dinner.  Chicken enchiladas tasted really bad and I ate just a bite, had to leave the entire dish. So we're the starter taquitas.
Frontera Ceviche and  Ceviche Verde were very nice, as was Grilled Shrimp Quesadilla, and Savoury Shredded Beef Enchiladas, do make a reservation before hand as the place is quite busy

I am a chef groupie and I was so excited to try this place but it did not live up to the expectations, especially for the price. I started with the a Mescal drink which was smokey and tasty and the sopes. They were good but not great. The salads that came with the chips has some good flavors. I had the Oaxaca Carne Asada which was good but it did not blow me away. The Pan de Muerte was tasty. The only thing that was truly amazing was the Hot chocolate. The flavors were rich and complex. I will definitely be wanting another cup.

Came here because we love Mexican food and trying out new interpretations. I knew the wait can be long so we arrived at 430 because they don't open until 5. Once the doors opened we were allowed in after a woman took our name down along with my cell#. We were told we can sit at any black table and even eat because it's first come first serve. Well that was not our plan as we wanted to enjoy the food in the dining area and I thought since people ahead of us started ordering food and cocktails the wait would not be so bad....so we waited (we brought 2 kids with us since it was a mother daughter night kind of a thing). I don't know if it's because we didn't order anything that we were not seated for what seemed like eternity. It was a Sat evening so I knew other places would already be packed too so we waited. It was not that busy so we waited further. .....it wasn't until 15 mins to 6 that I asked the hostess for an update. I was reassured we are next in line and will be seated at 6. It was going on 6:20 and another lady came by and told us they called my phone and even texted. I triple checked my phone and no calls came thru nor texts. They could have left a vm but I never received any either. One lady who I can assume was another hostess apologized and explained some carriers somehow have issues receiving the calls or texts so I told her I have TMOBILE after she asked. We were finally seated downstairs which looked like the basement and smelled like one too. We sat down at almost 645. I was still willing to give this place a chance since the reviews were pretty good and the kids were now restless and tired. The food was just okay though the sauces were pretty good. My brother in law is Mexican and when his mom flies in from out of town she cooks for the entire family.....yes, that's when I come over to partake. The steak (Brava) was cold and I had ordered it medium but was actually on the med well side. The sweet corn mass was good .....that was actually the tastiest thing on my plate. We also ordered the shrimp dish.....not bad. We ordered a side of the onion bulbs and it was undercooked and cold so that was a disappointment. All in all it was a disappointment. .....we wasted 2 hrs waiting. We got a room for the night planning other activities so this was not a good start. I wouldn't go back.

Oh how I love this man, Rick Bayless.  His anthropological touch to the culinary world is exactly how food should be experienced for those who care for an ethical and sustainable approach to the culinary arts. Perhaps because of my expectations, I came away slightly disappointed with the food, at least in terms of value.  We were pleasantly surprised with what was brought before us, and loved the experience, but I found myself thinking that Xoco had better food for the dollar.  My suggestion would be to consider Xoco as a much, much cheaper alternative, or step up to Topolo which I think is really the experience we should have gone for if we had been able to land a last minute reservation (our trip here was spontaneous).   Walking in on the dawn of Trump's election, it was pleasantly comforting to find that the entire brilliant staff was of Mexican and I'm guessing other Latin backgrounds--a welcome reminder of the contributions of our hard working immigrants from the south in a restaurant industry that usually keeps them off the wait staff and hides their significant contributions in the kitchen.  We ate at the chefs table, which actually doesn't show you much of the action, but it meant we had no wait, and I enjoyed being closer to the wait staff and away from the crowds.   Four stars for the food, and five for the experience, people, and groundbreaking approach to cuisine. Bravo, Rick, I wish you and your revolutionary approach to food tremendous success--our world needs more artists and entrepreneurs like you.

Fantastic food.  Fun, imaginative decor, great atmosphere, comfortable seating.  The food was at least as good as I had hoped it would be.  Only wish I could have tried everything on the menu.  Hope to get back there someday.

Came here for lunch, ordered the Carne Asada. Food - Honestly, the steak tasted like it just came off the Mongolian grill at my local chinese buffet. I had asked for medium rare, but one half was completely blue. Steak was very tough and had lots of connective tissue and fat. Not to mention they blast AC vents right onto your food, so the steak was cold within 10 minutes. The beans and plantains were good, though. Definitely not worth the $40+. Service - No complaints, nothing special. Ambiance - Tables were very close together, you can tell they tried to squeeze as many heads as possible into this place. The table next to me was so close that I could have grabbed their plate without moving out of my seat.

Came today at about 7pm and was told there would be a 45 minute to an hour wait. The rude girls at the front didn't bother to check but insisted we had to wait. Fine. I ask that they put us on the waitlist while we went to explore the neighborhood bars. We decide to cross the street, sit, and order a cocktail... which took less than 5 minutes... tell me why in get a text telling me my table at Frontera grill was ready.  Hmm, no thanks.  I called to tell them that I would be 20 minutes and the same rude girl told me they couldn't guarantee me a seat. Please!!
Loved the cocktails and the food.  They quoted a wait time of over an hour and ended up being about 45 minutes - enough for a drink and apps at the bar.

I was so excited to go here on a recent girls' weekend in Chicago. We went with no reservations fully ready for a long wait. We were told two hours and we happily headed next door to get some drinks. Our table was ready in a little over an hour. Sounds great, but then we were led to a table in the basement. A pathetic room - too bright, decorated like a sad hallway - with no ambience. Service was slow, especially getting our drinks, and while the food was fine, it certainly wasn't worth the price considering we were sitting in a sad basement. Looking back, I wish we had complained that night but we were all so stunned we didn't even know what to say. I'm a fan of Bayless but have no desire to ever go back here. Even my friend who has had great experiences here said she would never go back. So disappointed.

A little on the pricier side but the food is excellent, the service is excellent and the location is quite nice. If you are looking for a nicer sit down meal and are craving Mexican this would be an excellent choice.

Pretty good place. The food come very fast but the wait is long. It took 1 hour 30 mins for the wait but the nice about them is they will text you when the table is ready. There is couple dishes are must order: seafood cocktail, beef brave, and taco trio. Those are very good and especially the beef grilled with good charcoal flavor. I also order the duck breast but the duck here is not impressive. I ordered the pecan pie and is good. The pecan is ground and some smoky flavor. Is a must order dessert.

The least inspiring lunch in Chicago.  Great decor.  Great location.  My lunch order of chicken tostadas felt more like a tapas "small plate" option - certainly not worthy of a lunch portion and over priced based upon the portion size.

I went here first of all because I had tried their salsas from the grocery store and they were delicious. Knowing that they were bottled and shelf stable and still delicious and fresh tasting made me want to try the restaurant even more! I had a type of pork taco, I don't remember it's exact name right now, but it was one of the best pork tacos I have ever had. Just as I had hoped all of the sides and meal tasted very fresh! I can't wait to go back and try them again. My mouth is watering and stomach is growling now just thinking about them, and I just ate dinner!

In the beginning, there was a man who learned how to fish. Fast forward to the present, there is a man, Rick Bayless, who knows how to transform fish into a delectable treat for your palate called "Frontera Ceviche".  Highly recommend. As if I were livin' "high on the hog," I was drawn to the Pork Carnitas.  Chunks of crunchy and succulent pork with roasted onions and black beans hit the spot!  The salsa verde was an excellent accompaniment - bright, thick, and delish!  And, if that weren't enough, I had to try the Pumpkin Cheesecake!  Oh my word -- AHHH-MAAAA-ZING!  Pumpkin puree, fresh figs, and these tasty nuggets of crunchy goodness...perfect end to a wonderful lunch. Moreover, the service was top-notch. One would think everyone pools there tips the way everyone ensures you every need is addressed.  If you are in Chicago, definitely weave your way to the Alley and enjoy a fantastic meal.

We had a couple of different friends tell us about Frontera Grill. I got the Asada, and my wife got the flank steak tacos. But we're good. Great quality meat, and very filling. The price range was 20 to 35 bucks. The environment was alot of fun. The service was a little slow, but it was a Friday night and we were not in a huge hurry, but if they were able to speed up the service, then they could turn their tables faster. So would be better for them. I would recommend for a higher end Mexican place but would not eat at very often

I travelled to Chicago this past weekend and had to checkout one of Rick Bayless' awesome restaurants. I was able to get a reservation to Frontera Grill a week prior. When we arrived, we were seated immediately. It was very busy so we did not expect quick service, but were a little disappointed when the people next to us who were seated after us were attended to first. No biggie, I was't going to let that ruin my experience. We did have menus so we were able to review the entire menu while waiting. We ordered the Jamaica sangria which was pretty good, but kind of strong, which wasn't a bad thing in our case. We ordered appetizers and chips and guacamole. The chips were ok and the guacamole was good. The salsa was good but not spicy at all and the carnitas and beans were amazing! I particularly enjoyed the queso fundido. Overall, I loved the atmosphere and the waiters did come and check on us considering the place was packed. Rick Bayless was there and I asked if I could take a picture with him but was told he was busy tasting next months menu, but I could wait if I wanted to.  After waiting for over an hour, I decided it was time to go when I realized they had closed already and would later reopen for dinner. One of the waiters mentioned I could come back at dinner time to see if he was available, but when I came back, I was told he was gone. I'm a huge Rick Bayless fan so it was a bit upsetting, but its ok, there's always next time!
Had dinner in the bar. Had 2 great margaritas. Service was superb. Staff was very friendly.  Food options were excellent.

Ok, I've been wanting to make it here for years. I finally made it this trip to the Windy City. First off I appreciate that they carry real Mexican beer. Second, the green ceviche was pretty darn good. Now for the mole. I am a bit of a mole fiend, and theirs is not too bad. It is mild in overall flavor, but deep with complexity. The down fall was serving it with the duck. Which, by the way was cooked to perfection! The problem, it felt like two separate dishes. It just didn't Jive for me. Could be the fattiness of the duck, but it really didn't work. Like I said individually they were both excellent. And their home made tortillas with the mole was awesome! Just not the duck. I'll be back for sure and try something else.

Was looking forward to giving this place a try. I pushed passed the attitude the Caucasian hostess gave me, but after waiting at the chefs counter for 10 minutes with no service I got up and walked out. Very disappointed. 20'people passed me on 10mins and no one stopped to say hello take my order. Maybe they were having a bad day. Who know. But I'm glad there were several restaurants in the area.

Instant energy as you walk in and enjoy the bright colors and incredible margaritas. We arrived without a reservation around 4:45 and sat to eat around 5:20 in the basement. We ordered the duck carnitas for two and some lamb appetizers. The sauces really pack a punch and really put the dishes over the top.

Having lived in Texas my whole life, and visited Mexico multiple times, I came here with high expectations. I have been a fan of Rick Bayless of years. PS HE WAS THERE!!!!!!! This was our first stop in Chicago during our brief visit. We started with cocktails, I got a Margarita, and my husband got (I can remember the name but I know it had the word Gold in it) his drink. I have NEVER NEVER NEVER had a better Margarita. Even in Mexico!. We started with the guacamole and Frontera sampler plate with quesadillas, ceviche, and taquitos. Thea guac was exactly what it should be, but it didn't taste any different from what I've had in Texas. So I was slightly disappointed. However, the sampler plate was a different story. I would come back (all 1,000+ miles) for the cocktails and the ceviche alone. I find it so hard to fine authentic mexican ceviche and Frontera Grill's was OUT OF THIS WORLD! The quesadilla was more of an empanada which was delish. I then got the daily special with was a Mexican version of pork milanese. It was a religious experience. My husband go the duck tacos, knowing that Rick Bayless' favorite taco is the duck taco. He found them underwhelming. On our next trip to Chicago we will try more things but if you are here, please try their cocktails and ceviche. It'll be one of the best you've ever had!

This place is just ok. Honestly it felt a little stuffy and in the words of Peter Griffin I feel like "It assumes too much". The explanation for why they couldn't make anything from the bar other than what was on the drink menu was that it was "100% Mexican Restaurant". Yeah ok but I see all the ingredients for a Tom Collins right there so...eh...never mind just get me a beer.  Though the vibe the staff gave off was a little stuffier than it needed to be, they were still nice and gave great service. Also the interior design of the restaurant caught my attention and was very well done.  So I get that it's supposed to be interior Mexican as opposed to Tex-Mex which I can appreciate. But the food was honestly just ok, and a highly priced ok at that. Honestly was expecting a lot after looking at the reviews and it fell very short on the food end. We had the fish, Ribeye, and tacos. The meat for the tacos was seasoned well, everything else was on the bland side. Maybe they tone down the seasoning because they think Chicago folks can't handle the heat?   When one of the members of our groups asked if they had sopapillas for dessert, guess what...soooorryyy...100% Mexican restaurant. But hey here's our dessert Menu. Ummm. Apparently pumpkin cheesecake is of Mexican origin???...haha callin bs on that one.  I will say that the plate presentation of the food was very nice and the one thing we all enjoyed were the plantains. But at the end of the day we came for amazing food and will probably not be back because of the just ok food.

service at the bar was hit or miss. one bartender was great, other was a real dick. duck in mole was outstanding and a great value. nice crunch, great depth of flavor, duck was cooked really well. dish was really well composed
Hello Everyone  I enjoy great food and they have good food! Service at the bar was one star but service in the dining room was 4 stars.  The wait wasn't worth it!

I've been to this establishment before, but never wrote a review before.  The food here is very fresh and good. I like the Poblano Chili corn chowder, Guacamole(you can choose the toppings)and fresh squeezed juice of different kind(I recommend Mango Lime). On my last visit, I had the garlic shrimp torta(pressed like a Cuban sandwich)which was very good. They also have breakfast until 11am. They offer variety of different items on the menu as well. Something for everyone. When you are in Chicago, you should definitely try this place.

I came in here for lunch at 1 pm because I have successfully failed to eat here for dinner due to the popularity and packed house normally.  I started with the ahi tuna ceviche followed by the crispy fish tacos with fresh Serrano peppers and a medley of fresh salsas.  I ended the meal with an appropriate fall classic of pumpkin cheesecake.  Everything was fantastic.  5 star

Pretty interesting dining experience. Had to get here right at 5 to get a reservation for a party of 8. I was given a reservation of 6:30 but they made us wait until 7:15 or so. The manager came over, gave us some complimentary apps, and had great stories to tell about the cuisine. The drinks are STRONG (blue agave margarita is great) and the fundido is terrific. The spicy green beans are NOT edible, and their chocolate dessert is bitter and not sweet, just fyi. The rest of the food I had was delightful and the presentation was a show in itself. Great bonding experience, since the meal took a while to come out, but it's small, exclusive spot, so it is to be expected.

I finally had a chance to try Rick Bayless creations. It was very good. Felt like I was back in California. I ordered the tortilla soup and was surprised there was no avocado? Funny thing the restaurant at airport had avocado but no sour cream?  All the appetizers we ordered (3) were my favorite part of meal. I can't wait to come back and try Topolabampo.

I am visiting Chicago for the first time and Frontera grill was the place I was most excited to check out - my girlfriend's dad really hyped this place up. The hype may be responsible for the 4 instead of 5 star review I am giving this place. The mole enchiladas were decent, the mole was a little too sweet and the chicken a little tasteless. I did try the duck with mole though and that was incredible! The wait staff wasn't super personable and my party had to wait a good amount of time before we received food.  There was a somewhat famous actor having dinner there bough which gave this joint some credibility. The duck really made this place worth the wait.
Over rated (clap clap clap clap clap) Love Bayless as a human being. But this place is above average in taste and sky rocket in price. Making cash money on reputation and not delevring in food. Pass

We attended the Rockin Lobster Bash on 8/31 and after having met and tasted food from Rick Bayless there we had high expectations for Frontera.  We came in for a late lunch and had a short wait without reservations for 4.   The food - was very good.  Everyone at the table all got something different, then we all wished we had gotten the mahi enchiladas.  Somehow the summer grilled chicken salad (special) was not as good after a bite of mahi enchilada.  I also sampled the old school trio and the tacos arabes.  Get the mahi! The drink - After a night of partying at the lobster bash we had a craving for Bloody Mary and Bloody Maria's.  Neither of them were very good and in fact we sent them back in favor of wine for the ladies and straight tequila for the gents.  Good selection of both. The service - was as good as you would expect of a Rick Bayless restaurant, though we did feel the drinks took too long to arrive each time. I would go back, though would not necessarily put at at the top of the list with the amazing foodie scene in Chi-town.

Everything perfect until the bald waiter with glasses demanded a 45% tip. Those were clearly his words, at least 45%. Whooa! 25% wasnt enough? It was a table of 4, 2 of them children. No words. Simply left speechless.
Worst enchiladas ever!! The chicken tasted likes it's been refrigerated for 2 days and the mole was tasteless. Besides the price was high for the quality of the food.

I've only been here once, despite my numerous visits to The Windy City. That mistake has now been rectified and I'm adding Bayless' flagship joint to my MUST HIT places whenever I'm back in town. I had lunch, so it was a fairly simple meal, compared to some of their main entree fare. Even so, the tacos, quesadillas, taquitos, rice and beans were all elevated miles higher than your average Mexi food places. Everything was excellent. I'm not a fan of black beans, but I would eat these particular black beans for every meal. Every item I tried has amazing flavor and texture combinations. Some were exotic, and others were exactly what you'd expect from Mexican fare. I loved every bite of every dish. The service was great and the ambiance is very cool. There's a sort of old-school Mexican restaurant decor, feel and charm to here. I can't wait to go back for dinner and margaritas!

I called to make a reservation a week from today for my dads birthday the girl on the phone said that they were full on reservations but keep a ton of empty tables open for walk-ins which would have been fine but she then continued to say that you have to line up outside and wait in a line and they don't even let you start to come in until 20 minutes after they open but that you can line up an hour before they even open. I have lived in Chicago all my life and have never been to an upscale restaurant that makes their guests wait in line like cattle! I told them that my father is elderly and we are going there to celebrate his birthday but they didn't care. My father can't stand for a long periods of time I guess this is how frontera grill likes to treat it's VETERANS make them wait outside even though they have tables available! My boyfriend works for two brothers beer and his company helped create a beer for Rick Bayless's restaurant and he told me that he was an ARROGANT JERK and was rude to the staff! I guess the people who work for his restaurant are the same!

had my first frontera meal at o'hare. been lusting since. have a cabinet full of the salsas and packets for home-cooking. i've had everything on the menu and my only regret is that i don't live in chicago. it's a must have when passing through. what a crazy surprise - chicago for the best mex in the u.s.

This week I took my youngest child to college. After 3 days of shopping, moving, orientation and then saying goodbye, my thoughtful husband made reservations at Frontera Grill for a nice dinner before leaving Chicago. He made a reservation specifying that one diner is Celiac and requires Gluten Free for medical reasons. My husband researched the restaurant and although it does not have a separate GF menu, many GF bloggers wrote that GF was not a problem at Frontera and that accommodations could be made. Long story short....if you are GF, I would not spend my money at Frontera Grill. I was looking forward to a nice dinner after saying goodbye to my son. Instead I was so frustrated that I couldn't wait to leave. Many beers on the menu but not one GF. Would you like some guacamole & chips? No chips here because they can't spare a fryer that is separate for GF items! Hey Rick, could you run down to Whole Foods or the local bodega and pick up some plain corn chips for the many GF diners who come to your 4.5 star restaurant? Many of the dishes I wanted to try I was told I couldn't have. I am so disappointed in Rick Bayless' exclusion of GF people. Just one GF fryer and a Red Bridge would have made a world of difference.

Secured a late reservation on a busy Thursday night for 3. Service was quick and attentive throughout the meal. Margaritas were strong and had good flavor.  We ordered the summer guacamole (nice flavor and some spice), eggplant garnachas and mushrooms tacos to start. Standouts were the guacamole and eggplant.  Ordered the torta de elote, shrimp and carne asada as mains. The shrimp was the standout dish from the meal.  Solid meal with some good dishes. I felt the portions were generous.

I have learned so much from watching Rick Bayless and using his books, and his restaurant held up to my expectations. We came for Saturday brunch upon a local friend's recommendation, queued up for the 10:30 opening, and were welcomed exuberantly upon opening by their terrific hostess and staff. I had the huevos bajios. Delicious, earthy, fantastic texture from the masa base, and perfectly poached eggs to tie it all together.  My husband loved his carne asada tacos, served with large portions of fresh guacamole, two great salsas and plenty of freshly made tortillas.  We enjoyed sampling each other's dishes, and mixing it up a bit.  I wanted to try everything on the menu, but will just have to revisit, as well as trying Topolo.  As I would expect, the restaurant made me happy with the food, the great service and the fun décor.  Made me really want to go back to Mexico...but this food was better than most anything I've had there.

Once again, in the endless search for tantalizing Southwestern cuisine, I convinced JB we had to eat at one of Rick Bayless' spots because, when are we going to be in Chicago again?! On the fly, we booked it over to Frontera Grill. Happy hour was ridiculously full lol but it must be worth it, right? We waited probably 20-30 minutes for some seats to open up and eventually just one did on the end, but it was enough for us to set up house in the corner with one person standing egads! Server is very attentive, immediately drops menus for us, but then takes about 10 minutes to come around and take our order and then it's probably another 10-15 minutes before our drinks arrives. He shakes them in front of us, we both take a sip of our own, and then do the usual couple-switch (Blue Agave and Xoco Margarita). We had to order the ceviche trio and also got the mole trio. JB was in love --- he said it's the BEST margarita he's ever had. But this is my review, not his. The food is pretty pricey. However, the portion size is quite decent for the price. Some drinks and tapas at happy hour prices would've been great, though lol.

Have been to Topolo and Xoco already on previous trips to Chicago, so finally got a chance to try the middle child of Rick Bayless family this time around. I made a reservation online a couple of months in advance (they only offer up limited seats to reserve ahead of time, otherwise all first come first serve).  The decor is awesome here, lots of traditional art as well as costumes. The dining room is essentially lined with tables on 1 side (the reservable part) and a long bar (with lots lots of tequila on the wall) on the other. Cocktail menu is tequila and mezcal focused and look fantastic. It was lunch time, so I went with a glass of sangria. Wow let me tell you... Pretty much 95% of the sangria I've had in my life thus far taste like juice, and I can down 3-4 glasses easy. Even though I had breakfast earlier that day already, this is potent stuff and I was getting buzzed on 1 glass. And that's a good thing folks. The menu is extensive, and we were slightly overwhelmed with all the choices, so went with the sampler options.  Starter: Old School Frontera Trio - 2 each of Mexico City style corn masa quesadilas (love the corn and the cheese was so creamy on the inside), chicken taquitos (cripsy and on a mound of super fresh guac), and albacore tuna ceviche (nice and zesty). This was a very good start. Entree: BIG wood-grilled tacos al carbon trio - Comes with skirt steak, duck breast and chicken breast, shishito peppers and onions, and of course home made tortillas. Grilling meat to perfection is not easy, but doing all 3 so well (especially chicken) is mad skills. And gosh by BIG they really weren't kidding, this combo easily serves 2 realy hungry to 3 slightly less hungry adults. The bottled Frontera sauce is already quite good, very savory up front but watch out for the kick afterwards! Overall, another fantastic Bayless experience. Where Topolo is modern and inventive, Xoco is fun and casual, Frontera Grill fit the middle perfectly with well executed traditional dishes that feel homey and comforting. Only regret is not coming with more people so we can try more dishes!

Service was great but that is the only reason for 2 stars. Ordered steak dish that was served ice cold, my husbands shrimp dish was also cold.. When you are spending $30.00 for a few slices of meat or a few shrimp the least they can do is serve it warm! Portions are very small and if you cannot have a lot is of spice there is really no point in dining here.. I think the only draw is the famous owner, otherwise do not think it would be as successful.
Excellent Service, Excellent Food, Margarita's and some of the best service I have ever had at a restaurant. Will definitely frequent again when I am back in Chicago.

I was so unimpressed. We were treated very warmly and made to feel welcome. Our server was very nice. But our food was cold.  I don't want an ice cold shrimp quesadilla. We paid $100 for 2 people for lunch.  I'm happy to pay that for excellent food.  After the first few bites of the cold quesadilla, I felt almost sick.   Rick, please be sure the food arrives hot.   If you don't know how to make that happen, please visit Topo Gigio on Wells in Old Town.  Every single bite comes out piping hot. Even every single bite of pasta! I think Frontera Grill should be ashamed of serving cold food, especially because we paid $100 for 2 people for lunch. It's absolutely terrible to pay $100 for lunch for 2 people and be served an ice cold quesadilla.

This place, as well as Rick Bayless, is exceptional. The food (and I hesitate to call it food, more delicious art) is unreal in flavor, and spectacular in presentation. My family had a 5 course meal in the tasting room, and each course was paired perfectly with a wine from the staff sommelier, who was more than helpful in explaining the characteristics of each wine and why it went so perfectly with the food. I actually had the opportunity to meet Rick and watch him cook a bit, and he is as good a person as he is a master chef. I recommend this place to anyone looking for a superb dining experience in Chicago. DO NOT leave without trying any one their special margaritas- they are phenomenal!! It is pricey, but you absolutely get what you pay for. The atmosphere is very nice and would make an excellent spot to bring a date you aim to impress. Everything here is masterfully done and the staff is friendly and very knowledgeable. You will not be disappointed here.

I had called their phone number repeatedly starting around 4pm-6:30pm on Tuesday August 23rd, 2016 to make a reservation.  The phone kept ringing and was never answered, so we proceeded to go to the restaurant at 6:45pm only to learn that there was a 1.5 hour wait and were advised that we should have called beforehand to make a reservation....

It was a great lunch, but was it worthy of 1 Michelin Star, not based on the menu and service we had. I really don't have any complaints (outside forgetting to bring my ceviche dish, and then the server seemed to insinuate I never ordered it), the prices were reasonable, salsa was average, but the pork guajillo was excellent. There was just nothing that clearly separated it from many other similar, really good quality places serving the same cuisine.

We really enjoyed everything here and thought it was well worth the wait.  I started off with the Jamaica Sangria waiting on a table (I waited too long to make online reservations).  For appetizers we had Frontera Guacamole and the Old School Frontera Trio. Our favorite of the trio were the Mexico City-Style Quesadillas filled with queso. The chicken in the taquitos was smoked and so tender, I could just eat it alone.  I love ceviche and thought it was very lime infused without being drowned in the juice--how did they do that? In addition, we ordered the Fresh Corn Tamales--they were divine! The masa was so good and moist, it didn't even need a filling. For dinner, we shared the Big Wood-Grilled Tacos Al Carbon Trio.  It was amazing.  The beef, chicken and duck were awesome! Our favorite was the duck; it was so tender and fatty, we couldn't stop eating it.  With dinner, I had a Topolo Margarita and it was yummy and very limey. I wanted to order dessert, but we were so full we knew we weren't going to enjoy it. We will definitely be going back on our next trip to try more dishes!

Had a great time. Managed to get great seats at the bar, so avoided the wait. Had some inspired drinks, with Mescal. Shared a bunch of street food Mexican food. Had a great night. Was pleased it wasn't super expensive.

What a pleasant festive experience it was.  Rick Bayless does well with his restaurants - authentic and original.  Service was a little lax as our server had too many guests to attend to.  Food was divine, especially the grilled yellowtail.

My friend and I went on a Tuesday afternoon right before they open for lunch and there was already a large group waiting outside. Good news is there were still plenty of seats after all the groups were seated, but I can see the reason why everyone waits after eating there. My friend and I shared: Corn on the Cob Ceviche Trio Corn Tamale All of the food was very good and I would absolutely want to go back. I would suggest smaller groups are better for the place, between 1-4 people. The service is great and very attentive.

First impressions are not great. We made a reservation several weeks ago but upon arrival they could not seat us until they set several other groups. When they finally set us they chose to give us a very poor table stuck between a wall and a large group.  The restaurant is extremely noisy. There is nothing to absorb sound so a full restaurant makes it difficult for any conversation. Service was reasonable.  However, the principal waiter knew little about the preparation of the various food items. We ultimately decided to eat 4 stater items. I had really come to try a Rick Bayless mole preparation. But upon reviewing the entree mole perpetrations they seemed uninspiring.   The four items we settled on were the Corn Tamale, the Old School Frontera trio, the mole enchiladas, and the Grilled chicken, mole almendrado. None of the dishes were inspirational. Generally the dishes with chicken were lacking in flavor. The chicken was dry and under seasoned. The mole sauces were singular. I expect a richness and layering of chiles, nuts, seeds, spices and other elements.  Not these moles. If I had experienced mole the first time at Frontera Grill, I probably would not like mole sauces. The best dish of the night was the ceviche tostadas. The albacore was fresh and the citric was not overly acidic for eating.  In my opinion the restaurant is overpriced and overrated from my observations.

This is my favorite restaurant! I love it!  The flavor of the food is unique, fresh, and delicious.  Rick Bayless has made food here that is perfection.  The drinks have unique and great taste.  It is place you would pay more because the detail to the ingredients and presentation are hard to find!  Love, love, love it!
This place is very average, I would say it did not meet my expectations. The execution is off, the temperature of the food is too cold.
Bajia eggs are good as well as steak and egg enchiladas!  The chocolate cappuccino is to die for!! Service is quick and good.
From start to finish the dining experience was great. Dishes are interesting, delicious and full of spice. Definitely make a reservation! You got to try the horchata. Super yum!

Frontera Grill may be my favorite restaurant in the entire City of Chicago. They always impress me with the freshness of the ingredients, monthly tweaking of the menu, friendly usually efficient service, and really special Mexican flavors. The food energizes me with beautiful ingredients and both unique but relatable flavors and preparations. However, I would say this is a "hit or miss" establishment, as I'm not always completely pleased with every dish I order, so it's wise to know the consistent stand-bys if you're not in a more adventurous mood. For example, sometimes they have a chiles rellenos which is truly a stuffed chile, and not like the battered type. Eh. And once I tried one of their aguachiles, and was greeted with a very fishy odor when they brought me my plate. And sometimes the appetizers come a little cooler than I prefer. A more common complaint for me however is the truly extreme saltiness of some dishes. Randomly, like the brunch chilaquiles and sometimes their non-chicken enchiladas taste like they must have individually salted every single component of the dish, rendering a final dish where every mouthful seems like there must be a 1/4g of salt. If the kitchen fixed the inconsistent extreme saltiness of their food, then they deserve 5 stars on yelp. But as they have sent such salty food out for quite some time, it indicates the cooks need to do more tasting please. I know they want to be held to the highest standards. Brunch corn pancakes are recommended with the real maple syrup! More hearty texture then regular buttermilk pancakes. Yum. I wrote this review to share my second experience with the Frontera Grill chiles rellenos. The battered type. To even have the privilege of tasting one of their limited quantity chiles rellenos specials, you must basically be in the first seating, and order yours immediately. The velvety texture of the souffle batter with the chewy cheese filling, and rich well seasoned tomato sauce combine nicely. And the white rice and black beans are the best rice 'n beans I've ever tasted in any Mexican restaurant. Slightly al dente rice grains have a great texture to contrast the chiles rellenos, and the soft slightly mashed black beans help with the (apparently unpredictable) level of heat with the main dish as well. My server said their chiles rellenos can either turn out not very spicy or very spicy. Mine were moderate/very spicy this last time. You used to only be able to order these if you knew to ask. I guess they used to only make five orders of the chiles rellenos each day in the past, and you had to know to ask the server because it was never on the menu. And it apparently usually sold out within the first couple minutes of service. While I agree as an entire dish it is the best chiles rellenos I have ever tasted, is it worth $24 or the hassle of ensuring you are the first person in the door to get one? Eh, maybe once, but I wouldn't necessarily stress out over it. For those who like spicy, Frontera Grill offers an off-menu habanero salsa. It has the signature habanero light, fruity, innocent scent almost reminiscent of passion fruit, but definitely adds significant heat with every literal drop. The flavor is both delicate but intensely spicy. Desserts are also one of my highlights at Frontera Grill. Perhaps the best most tender flan I've ever tasted. Chocolate pecan pie with Kahlua whipped cream is always dependable. And their current tres leches cake rendition is usually excellent because they seem to always incorporate the maximum combination of amazing flavors and textures (crispy, chewy, soft, crunchy, moist, cold, salty, sweet, bitter, umami).

Been meaning to get to Frontera if I was in Chicago again and did this week for lunch. Love risk Bayless' passion for Mexican cuisine.  Salsas are very good with smokey freshly made taste.  Had the chicken tortilla soup based on Yelpers recommendations.  Excellent and I am a bit of a soup snob.  My son had the pork tortillas which had a mango hot sauce and it was the best he's ever had.  I went with the street food trio- very yummy.  Thoroughly enjoyable meal and the service was excellent. Disregard the comments about small portions.  Each dish is a wonderful mix of flavors and you do not need to gorge yourself to feel satisfied.

Great staff, love the ambience, good drinks. Food was okay. Had twist of modern Mexican. Not authentic. Reminds me of fo-fo Mexican food. Under cooked steak skirt and over spicy pork. Won't come back unless it's just for drinks.

I love Frontera grill for appetizers and drinks. The entree menu, from what I have had, has been OK. But the apps have always been amazing! Plan ahead when you visit Frontera grill to get there about 45 mins-1hr before you plan on eating. There is always a wait and they don't take reservations.

It was an amazing meal. When we got there, we were told it was an hour wait, but suddenly they said that we could be seated immediately. That was like out of a movie, but there was no name dropping. Our waiter made it a very memorable experience, one of the most personable waiters we've ever had. The menu changes monthly, so not sure how much the meal helps in a review, but we both got the Friday special, a beef brisket with black mole. My wife said something afterwards that I'd never heard her say before. "They undercharge for that meal." We didn't get dessert, as after that meal and the chips & guac we got, we were stuffed. Only negative, it was quite loud as we had a very boisterous table near us. Over all though, it was a meal to remember.
Best chile relleno! The sauce is just spicy enough, the the egg coating is fluffy and crisp at the same time.  From the guacamole, agua Fresca and the chips are all delish.

I've tried Frontera Grill for both Brunch and Dinner and had goodexperiences both times. Their service is on par and their food is very good. One negative about Frontera is their prices. They definitely price their options towards the higher end for Mexican and the only thing that will help make you feel like they are not too high is by looking at the prices of the connected restaurant Topolobampo next door. (Those are even higher) That being said, the food here is very good. For brunch I HIGHLY recommend the Chilaquiles with Guajillo. It's not that big of a portion so it's easy for one person to take down but I loved the sauce on here and it was very very tasty.  Their guacamole here is very good, but similar to my brunch option the portion was a little small.  Maybe I'm just used to the American way of giving wayyyyy to much food and stuffing my face but since that's what I'm used to that's what I expect. For the main dish I tried the Oaxacan-Style Carne Asada With keeping with the theme of everything else I've had here it tasted very good but was more on the smaller side (and expensive) Overall Frontera is a very good place and I'd recommend it for upscale Mexican. Just note that the portions are a bit smaller and the prices are a bit larger than other Mexican options in the city but then again you're paying for the name Rick Bayless.

What a disappointment. After years of hearing about this restaurant, I can honestly say that I had a better food experience at the Chicago airport outpost of Rick Bayless than I did at Fronterra Grill! First of all, do not come here if you actually want to hear what the other person at the table has to say. We took some Londoners here as a fun experience and unfortunately no one could hear anyone else at the table speak because this restaurant is so incredibly, shockingly loud. Then there are all the busboys and waiters who do not care that you are eating, they bump into your chair and stand there and touch you on the back while they are talking to the table behind you, because all tables are so close together. And yes, I live and dine out in New York City, so I am used to close tables. However, I am also used to people who respect personal space and don't touch other diners. This was just weird. Then there is the food. I can honestly say that this food is bland. Bland Bland Bland!! Even if you don't like things hot and spicy, you can still have a tremendous amount of flavor in the food. I would make better Mexican food at home!   And the portion size of everything? Tiny. There was another reviewer who talked about the size of the sides that are ordered. She wasn't joking... The black beans are $6 and you get about 4 spoonfuls of beans. The rice is $5 and you get the same size: 4 spoonfuls of rice. I am talking about a size smaller than the smallest Chinese takeout rice container!  This is just a pathetic mark-up. Especially when there is nothing special about the rice or the beans. The beans were meant to be garlicky, and they just tasted like they were black beans out of the can. Rice was... Rice.   Boo :( I also ordered for our table of six people the chicken taquitos. I asked the server how many pieces came in one order. He held up three fingers and said three. I said that I would like to have two orders and he gave me a weird look. I said that I wanted each person to be able to try 1 taquito so whatever I needed to do to get just six pieces, that's what I wanted. He came back to me with two orders, each of them had six pieces. So, 12! And yes, we were charged for that. I mean, dude, know your product! The dessert options were very disappointing. If I am in a Mexican themed restaurant, I do not want the pecan pie or the strawberry shortcake pushed on me as the desserts that are the best here. The waiter just kept telling me to order those things. At least have something beyond flan that I can choose from. An interesting sopapilla? Creative churros?  Nope.. We skipped dessert and just got the hell out of there. I will not be going back and I will not be recommending this restaurant to anyone I speak to. So very disappointing!!

Fabulous restaurant, met the gracious Rick Bayless who cooks with love.  Enjoyed the not too hot raspberry habenero guacamole,  margaritas, brisket, Carne enchiladas (mole was very smooth and creamy).  Staff was helpful and knowledgeable from the man in the suit on the front end to the waiter.   It was a memorable experience!

Wow, so bummed that this didn't meet my expectations! It was about an hour wait on a Friday night, so we put our names down and got a drink. The nice thing is that they will text you once the table is ready. It took a long time for our food, and none of it was very impressive. I enjoyed the ceviche trio, but it really tasted like any standard ceviche. Mole trio was okay, felt underseasoned, and it was a pretty small portion considering the price. We ordered a side of rice and beans too. It was literally portioned for one, which is ridiculous considering the price of the sides. The rice was good -- might be the Carolina gold rice?  I also echo some of the other reviewer's comments about the service. We hardly saw our waiter, but the bus boy came by frequently and would interrupt conversations to ask if an empty dish needed removal. When we said yes, he would then leave (without taking it?!). The restaurant is LOUD, and my table was right by the walk-way, so other guests would frequently bump into my chair.  Come back Rick to bring some quality control into this. :(  The nice thing is Xoco is right next door, so we actually ordered and picked up a churro while we were waiting for our food..

We had been waiting years to make it to Chicago and go to Frontera. I made reservations months in advance. The food was just okay. Certainly they had some unique dishes, but they were not fabulous tasting.

Another Rick Bayless gem. A few colleagues and I went to have dinner. The mezcal margaritas, pescados are amazing. So is the service.  We took a seat outside on a summer evening. Soaking in the hustle bustle of the city, while enjoying fine company and delectable drinks are tailor made for a hectic work week. While you are in the area, check out Xoco as well sometime.
Customer service was poor. Asked many time for water and then straws. Food took 50 min to come. And horrible food. Never recommend.

As soon as I finished my meal and wiped my mouth with a napkin, I began to think about what kind of rating I would give this place. The Girlfriend and I are huge fans of Rick Bayless' show and his guest appearances, we really wanted to love this place, even if every other high end Mexican restaurant experience had always disappointed us. Maybe Rick would pull it off. Le sigh. First strike: The tables are way too close together for a large dinner group, and at first I was told not to move the surrounding tables to make more room. Anyone who knows me knows I don't hide my feelings very well, and clearly the waitress could read my face. Eventually she just walked away and let me do whatever I wanted. Now that we had some space to move around and talk at any volume we liked, I felt more comfortable about my dinner experience to come, albeit a little perturbed that our waitress would even think to oppose me when she's supposed to be our server. The Girlfriend was clearly embarrassed and assured her mom and dad that everything was okay. Her dad looked a little uncomfortable and I nodded in agreement. Hopefully the food would be better.  Wrong. The dishes were bland and mediocre, good food for other restaurants that don't carry the Bayless banner. I ordered the mole and chicken and was surprised to taste how conflicted the chicken seasoning mixed with the sauce, creating a flavor profile that was wildly inconsistent and disappointing. This was all after an unfruitful trip to the paint store looking for a color for our bedroom, not wanting to pick anything that HuffPo said reflected negatively on our love life. I was hoping dinner would remedy all this. I was wrong.  But what really soured the whole experience was our busboy, if you could call a balding grown man that. He constantly circled the tables, never saying anything, refilling our water like every five minutes, literally interrupting conversations to reach over the table to fill someone's water, without saying please or excuse me or, I don't know, anything! The Girlfriend's saying something to her parents about feeling like she's not reaching her fullest potential because she read an article about a nine year old who knows twelve languages, but I can't jump in because this guy keeps coming over, spreading his nervous energy around. Like if he doesn't speak English or feel comfortable talking to customers, why have him on the floor at all? Just the look of this guy in his forties, with his white polo slightly blousing out of his pants, looking around for cups to fill and refusing to speak, took away my appetite. I literally could not finish my meal with him standing anxiously in the corner, waiting to be of use. I think The Girlfriend sensed my discomfort and said let's just go. We paid and no one even thanked us. Feeling really disillusioned now.

The only thing I knew about Frontera before going, was that friends who had been claimed it was absolutely incredible. I've gone to hyped up places before where the biggest thrill is standing in line only to be met by disappointment when you overly pay for mediocre food. Still though, we were excited to try it and made sure to keep open minds.   I didn't look over their menu ahead of time which isn't like me. I prefer to go in knowing exactly what I'm getting, that way the decision making part is over and I can simply relax and enjoy the meal.  We got there ten minutes before they opened and had to stand in a long line, but it moved quickly once they let us inside. The whole wait from street to table was 15-20 minutes tops.  Because it was a gorgeous day and we were on vacation, I threw caution to the wind and ordered the first thing to catch my eye which was the street food trio. Everything on the plate sounded foreign to me, but it's a James Beard award winning establishment after all so how bad could it be?  I also wanted a margarita but noticed none on the menu were frozen. I asked our server for a recommendation and he brought me the Topolo margarita. I still can't tell you what's in it, but it's shaken table side and goes down as smooth as water. It was easily the most refined and refreshing margarita I have ever had.  We also started with their freshly made chips and salsa. You get a roasted red and a green salsa (the green was by far our favorite). We wanted to bottle it so that we could take it home and put it on everything.  When my trio plate came out, I nearly laughed at how small the portions were for $18. One bite however completely changed my outlook. I have never had such delicious food. The seasonings were spot on, the complimenting sauces perfection, the meat tender, lord have mercy it was superb! Even more surprising was that I truly was full afterwards. My husband got a trio as well but the old school one with taquitos, ceviche, and Mexico City style quesadillas. He too was left full from the smaller servings, and he has a large appetite. We spent close to $100 for lunch, but in this case it exceeded expectations and was 110% worthwhile.  If you get the chance you need to RUN not walk, and try this gem out for yourself. I'm now convinced there is nothing chef RB could make that I wouldn't love. Mushrooms? Sign me up. Goat cheese? Let's do this. A shoe? Bring it! If he's cooking it, I'm eating it.
Great Wednesday special, patio was nice atmosphere, excellent service. Will absolutely come back!!!!

Super great service and the food was great. Highly recommend even though the overall place is loud and crowded. I ordered the chicken mojo and I would order it again.. the homemade corn tortillas are soft and fluffy. Will definitely return.

My bf (who is a Mexican food lover) and I finally tried Frontera...And it lived up to what I had expected. We sat outside on a chill Tuesday night, loved the Latin music, and overall Mexican style. Service was excellent. Every bite was flavorful...the sopes, pork with queretano mole, tacos al carbon, and desserts were perfect. We had a three course meal with drinks and the price was reasonable. Loved it!!

I have waited years to eat here, and finally got the opportunity yesterday. The service is amazing. All of the waitstaff is very attentive, and really on the ball. We started with an order of guacamole, which was tasty. (As we ate our last chip, a server dropped a full basket on the table) I had the carne asada brava, and it was cooked perfectly. My friend had the brisket in mole special, which was amazing. It is loud, and the place is always full. They do take reservations, but you have to make them months in advance. Otherwise, you will be a walk in and could wait an hour or two in peak times.

I've been longing to try one of Rick Bayless's restaurants that isn't in an airport since seeing him compete on Top Chef Masters. While traveling for work, a group of colleagues and I finally made the trek and I'm so glad we did.  Our meal started off with guacamole, salsa and chips. The guacamole was super smooth, like a mousse, with chunks of tomatoes and avocado. It was a really great guacamole and the salsas, of course, are terrific.  We all tried the specialty drinks...I got the fruit water, which had cucumber, lime and I think basil or cilantro. It was super refreshing...wish I had one now. A couple of folks got the limeade and one got the Rudy something, which was a tea-based drink with hibiscus.  For entrees we ordered a variety with a couple of people getting mole enchiladas, one person got skirt steak tacos, two people got the coconut shrimp (the thought it was too sweet) and I got the sea bass with escabeche sauce, rice and pickled purple onions. It was superb!  I think the sauce totally makes the dish. I added a side of fresh jalapeños and I was a happy camper.  I travel to Chicago a lot and am glad I finally tried Frontera Grill. I can check this one off of my bucket list, but that doesn't mean I can't have a do over.
Creative gourmet Mexican influenced cuisine. Had the pork loin and a blue agave margarita...delicious!

Swung by Chicago last month and made it a mission to check out Frontera.  I've heard all the critiques that Chef Bayless has gotten, I agree with a lot of them, but always appreciated his moments of openness and respect for Mexican culture/history/etc. (I'm Mexican myself).  As a Mexican person, I love authentic Mexican food, which is very regional, unique and nuanced, but I was looking forward to the spin applied on the food here.  The restaurant itself is nice, a bit kitschy, and the staff are incredibly kind and friendly.  We were seated quickly, as we had a reservation.  Our server immediately brought us to our table, and attentively described drinks, asked us for our preferences and made recommendations.  Relatively quickly, our drinks arrived, and they were fantastic.  My drink in particular, one of the mezcal drinks, was fantastic.  Everyone else was happy with their's as well.  We ordered a couple of appetizers, which came quickly.  The guacamole was great.  The ceviche trio? I believe, was okay.  I have to say that the one with tomato was particularly tasty, the others were okay, but overall, it was nothing I couldn't whip up at home pretty easily.  No offense. What I was really looking forward to was the Yellowtail Aguachile, again, I wanted to see the spin on dishes.  I have to say, I was underwhelmed.  It just wasn't much of anything.  It was spicy, limey, but really, the yellowtail just sat their, limp, and luke warm. Our dishes arrived soon after.  I have to say, throughout this, several of the wait staff would cruise by, say hello, make recommendations, etc.  THE WAIT STAFF IS AMAZING.  I ordered the Oaxacan style carne asada, and I should've resisted.  I have carne asada often, and was hoping to see a "spin" on it.  Again, nothing special, and nothing I couldn't do myself.  A family member ordered the shrimp in black bean chorizo sauce, which I debated in getting, but found it flavorless.  The sauce in particular, which would've been the "spin," wasn't much of a sauce.  It was flakey and dry.  I will say, the kids menu (taquitos and quesadilla) were great.  My kids loved them.  All in all, like I said, it was just okay, bordering on too pricey for what it was.  The "spin" wasn't much of a spin, which makes me want to recommend smaller, way less expensive Mexican restaurants.  Finally, I will say that whoever runs the restaurant (I understand it may not be Chef Bayless) should be careful with their choice in names for their drinks.  One of the drinks was called "Manifest Destiny."  I mean, you can't lift up Mexico and its cuisine on one end, and then use the theory/ideology that informed and led to the invasion and subsequent colonization of Mexico by the U.S..  It felt insensitive and a bit tone deaf.
I came to this place because I am a fan of Rick Bayless. I watched his shows on PBS and on Iron Chef America, and Top Chef Masters. The food was just ok (a little salty for my taste).

Been there a few times, lunch and dinner. You must reserve a table in advance or risk waiting an hour or more. The guac and ceviche are awesome, and worth going for again and again! Street food is fabulous....can't go wrong. My only quibble is that tables are very close together and the noise level is high.....This makes conversation uncomfortable.
The food was unique and delicious! The queso fundido was excellent!  Love the guacamole too.  Attentive server and quick service. Only issue was my husband beer was served warm.

As a Texan, I thought I knew what Mexican food tasted like. so I was surprised how much I loved this place. I wish the places in San Antonio were half this good Our meal was fantastic. We started off with a sampler app of flautas, sopes and ceviche. Everything was delicious. The ceviche was probably my favorite thing on the plate. I would definitely order that again. Flautas are my safe meal at Mexican restaurants but the flautas at frontera grill are probably the best I have ever had (sorry mom) The corn tamale- Delicious Mole trio- I love mole but this dish was not my favorite. My heart still belongs to a mole place in LA. The veggie mole which is part of the trio was not that great so consider subbing something in its place This place is so much fun. The music is great and make sure to get a table on the patio- great people watching

Boy, I was looking forward to this place.  It was OK but really not as good as I had hoped.  We had reservations for 8:30 but got there a little early and ended up sitting at the bar.  The best of all of our meals was the goat special.

One of my favorite restaurants in Chicago. Love the Margaritas. Festive and energetic atmosphere; a great place to bring friends and have a fun night out. Friendly wait staff and the food is always fresh and consistent. Truly a classic.

Went with my hubby for his birthday last night. The food, generally, was good but certainly not inspired like I would expect from a restaurant of this stature in the city.  The ambiance is one of a loud street in Mexico...including crying, unruly kids. Certainly not a place to go if conversation is on your agenda.  Also, I feel the need to express the inadequacies in the service. There was a sign listing the day's oysters. I love oysters so when the types weren't listed on the menu, I inquired. The waiter could only say they had "East and West Coast". I get more specifics when I go to Mariano's where I pay $1.25 each as opposed to here at $3 each.  Also, this is a Mexican restaurant and we weren't offered chips/salsa. Thinking it was an appetizer that needed to be ordered, I waited for menus(which took forever) and there none to be ordered.  Lastly, there was a young gentleman who appeared to be the manager walking to tables to make sure everything was as expected. He never visited our table even though we ordered drinks, oysters, main courses and deserts. He certainly had plenty of time.  We threw down $190. Unless you are on an expense account, go to any local taqueria and save $150.

Love the atmosphere. Great music and vibes. The waiter served nuts with spices just to check our spice tolerance. That was a good idea. We had Jamaican sangria and guacamole, which were delicious. We ordered ceviche trio; each one had great combination of citrus flavors. My boyfriend ordered vege enchiladas with green mole, kitchen was nice enough to make a vegetarian version of it and we ate every bite. Green mole sauce was really good. My friend ordered chicken mole, comes with side of tortillas; she liked the dish as well. For dessert we had chocolate tres leches  and rhubarb and citrus tart ice cream. The tart ice cream was the winner. It was tangy, creamy and delicious. Tres leches was just ok. It was too sweet to taste the individual flavors. Definitely  recommend to check out this spot.

All so sadly, while I crave their food, I cannot give Frontera Grill five stars; they don't take reservations and their seating configuration is, shall we say, 'too close for comfort.' Be prepared to wait: Even upon arriving 15-minutes before they opened, we still had to wait, in a line, on the sidewalk! What is this, a movie theatre? LOL You then have to wait some more indoors. After much anticipation, the hostess finally seats you almost on top of your dining neighbors. We could hear their conversations, and them, probably ours. So, being fair, this subtracts from the actual dining experience.  (Sadly, as well, I wouldn't want to bring an out-of-town family here, a business party, or even a first date--I feel it would be way too much for them to put up with.) That said, the whole reason for our visit is the food. It is exquisite! Our meals were stunning and perfect! I dream of their dishes and had a nearly impossible time choosing what to eat. I usually have a 'go to dish' at most restaurants, but not here; I never know what to choose. It's all so lip lickin' good! That's why I keep returning and put up with their strange no-reservation, pack-'em-in policy. The food is the star of the show and deserves a total five! In the words of Arnold, "I'll be back."

A year ago visiting Chicago we've tried this restaurant and were very impressed. We made sure to reserve a lunch when we returned this year. How surprised we were to receive At Rick Bayless restaurant an experience that was even worse then the average Mexican food spot would give you for a small fraction of the price we paid here. We ordered almost the same dishes that at first visit (with the exception of Enchiladas de Lengua that waiter presented as new to the menu): Ceviche trio, Mole trio, Rhubarb Tart. EVERYTHING was tasting mediocre, the entrees were just awful, warm in stead of hot (even the tortillas were not heated enough and as a result were not soft) and dessert was a weak copy of what we remembered from the last year. The food was a disappointment, but the service was even worse: SLOW not because there were not enough people or were very busy, but because they didn't work efficiently (our waiter was bubbling non stop for no reason and was nowhere to find when needed). Our lunch lasted 1 and 1/2 hours and our plans for sightseeing was nearly ruined. Needless to say we are not coming back and can't recommend it to anybody.

I normally love this place and have a great experience but I would not advise getting take out from here. I came here for lunch with two friends (it was one of their birthdays) in between classes at 12:00. We ordered guacamole and entrees. The guacamole took about 30 minutes to come out and the entrees were still not out at 12:45. We had to leave to get to class at 1:00 so we asked for our entrees to-go. Getting the food to-go then took about 15 extra minutes and the waitress seemed really annoyed with us. They did give us a scoop of ice cream with a candle for my friend's birthday.  When opening our food after leaving it was cold and looked inedible. My friend ordered a quesadilla that was turned inside out and did not even resemble a quesadilla. I was extremely disappointed and we did not end up eating any of the food. :(

Definitely a fan of this joint. I'm a bit of a Mexican/Tex-Mex junkie, I'll blame it on my Texas roots. This place does it right. The tortilla soup was amazingly good. I'd highly recommend it. I had the Pork in Red Pipian, very impressive dish.  My only complaint here is that I wasn't in town long enough to eat here more often. I would have loved to try several other dishes. Hopefully I get to return again so I can do just that.

I love this place.  The vegetable Tamales are amazing, a bit sweet in a cool and unique way. The chicken tamales is also wonderful and very different.  The service is always great and fast.  The tacos are ok, I wish they were more flavorful and more unique as the tamales. Not bad, just not as great.  The guac is awesome.  The place got energy.

Visiting from California so consider ourselves connoisseurs of the cuisine. Aside from the very peculiar 5:20 opening time on a Tuesday, we had a delightful experience. The champagne and mescal margaritas were tasty, as were the salsas and guac. We ordered queso fundito & tamales, both flavorful. Prompt, friendly service. The highlight was the amazing GF consideration. They were ON it.

Brunch, great Steak and eggs enchiladas simple but 9/10 Chilsquiles, tasty, but largely unremarkable 7/10 Spicy guacamole- 8.5/10 very subtle differences and not spicy, creamy and delicious Most importantly drinks: Mezcal Margarita 10/10 balanced smooth amazing Oaxacan gold 9/10 subtle undertones of vanilla and pineapple Paloma oaxaquena10/10 super spicy, delicious and super smooth Blue agave Margarita 7/10, good but a little too concentrated flavor tart and sweet

I just love the food options here and I always leave Frontera in a food coma. The topolo margarita is one of THE best margaritas I've had! My husband and I eat here about a couple of times a year and it's never a disappointment!

We went for Restaurant Week lunch 2016 which ended up being a pretty excellent deal. I started with a salad and then had the tamales topped with crispy kale for a main, it's one of the few veg options on the menu. All of the dishes were on the small side, especially given the price they normally are, and all were tasty, but overall, I got the feeling this place was a bit over-rated. Maybe my expectations were too high knowing it was Rick Bayless, but I felt like this was your standard upscale mexican restaurant. Next time I'll skip the fancy vibe and just got straight to XOCO which I felt like had better food for a better price.

Some of the best Mexican food I've ever eaten and a worthy champion of my 800th review! Basically I tried to get in here all week and was constantly against it in terms of getting a table (waits of hours...) but I was really lucky this lunch time and managed to snag myself a seat at the bar which was lively and exciting on a Friday afternoon! Really really great selection of Mexican street food - the super friendly barman with the super amazing moustache helped me though and suggested the empanadas, courgettes with soft tacos and an incredible cheese and guac dish.  So many great flavours, such a good vibe - I'd love to get back here soon to enjoy their full menu or maybe a tasty dinner - I will be back as Arnie said! For $25 for a full belly and a mocktail it was great value too.

For years, I have wanted to try Frontera Grill - and it didn't disappoint.  We made a last-minute decision to go there, so we sat at the bar for dinner.  The service was great, and the overall atmosphere was lively.  The three of us each ordered different meals, and they were delicious.  My vegetarian dish was particularly good. Also, we shared two great desserts between the three of us! Overall, a wonderful dinner.  Hope to get back again soon!

Wife and I went here on a Sunday night. We were seated promptly and server's attention was also prompt. We ordered our food. Appetizer Street Food Trio was out first - it was good.  After a rather long wait, too long IMO, we got our main course. It came out warm, at best. I had the Brava steak which was OK. Wife ordered a pork dish and her complaint was that meat was tough.  The best part of the meal was the appetizer, the salsa that was served with my steak, and the Dos, Tres, Quattro cake - it was delicious.  Sadly, we will not be back here. We love Frontera Fresco, but this was disappointing.

Living in Chicago affords a luxury of many restaurant choices. The hype of Frontera Grill did not live up to the expectations, seeming to ride soley on the reputation of a star chef.  Reservations made a few weeks ago, I asked for a text confirmation, but instead I received two phone calls. Upon entering the restaurant we were taken to a table, but the wait staff didn't seem as engaged or cared about helping with the order.  One nice thing, my husband is allergic to tomatoes so those were placed on the side, but beyond that, it was a lack luster experience. The appetizer was good, with the exception of too much salt tossed on one item. The main course came out and then before we could dive into it, the waiter took it away as he'd forgotten to take off the tomatoes. We were confused at first, but when he replaced the dish he mumbled something about tomato sauce. Very strange though. The wine service woman said she had access to wines from Bayless' next door restaurant, so we were excited to see what might appear on her specials. She never returned. The waiter came back, said "So you're sticking with water?" didn't wait for an answer and walked off with the drink list.  For the price point and hype, I would have liked my food warmer, the atmosphere less cafeteria feeling, and the wait staff nicer.  Luckily, there are many other restaurants in Chicago. This was a disappointing evening.

Rick Bayless is a rock star with his cuisine. I would love to go on a culinary trip to Mexico with him. We decided to come to Frontera for lunch. The place was packed by 12:30.  I started with the raspberry-lime Aqua Fresca and it was one of the best I've had. Light and refreshing yet tart and sweet.  For our mains my husband went for the street food sampler and I did the duck carnitas enchiladas. Everything was fabulous and there weren't any misses with either of our plates.  Service was friendly and efficient and overall we had a really lovely dining experience.

I will preface this review by saying I am a huge fan of Frontera Tortas at O'hare airport (they know me by name there) and also a huge fan of XOCO next door - but of this restaurant - not happy again on my second visit in ten years.  I just tried the Mole chicken Tamal and the Pork casuals tacos.  Tamal was pickeled with salt - almost inedible.  The Pork tacos were simply bland and uninteresting. I don't get it.  I have traveled through Mexico for 25 years.  It's not that tough to make good food.  Not sure what is wrong.

Went for brunch on a Saturday, and it was as good of a meal as I've had.  Delicious Frontera Ceviche appetizer was refreshing and delicious, the Sapitos were out of this world and the desserts were fantastic (the Frontera Chocolate Pecan Pie was amazing, the Dos Tres Quattro cake a little less so).   Overall a fantastic meal.  I wish I could travel to Chicago more often just to frequent Frontera.

Nice mexican restaurant, the margarita was perfect and the guacamole with tortilla chips was huge! I had an enchillada and it was nice. But I have to say that is was a little too expensif for what it was. I think is a very nice place for drinks and apetizers and so on, if you want to eat a entire meal, just be prepared to put the price!

All I can say is the food was OUTSTANDING! There was not one item that anyone at the table ordered that wasn't perfect!!! The flavor of everything item was the definition of perfection!! The shrimp was out of this world!! Carne asada was out of this world!!! The guacamole, WOW!!!!! The service was great, I wouldn't have expected anything less! I can't wait to come back to Chicago so I can eat here again!!!!

Not worth your time and money. Unless you are a tourist and have not had good Mexican food, this place is garbage. My husband and I went there for my birthday and I asked for a easy alcohol frozen margarita and my husband for a regular frozen one. The margaritas came in a martini glass, and the server was shaking the drinks in the same shaker and poured it in the glass as if we ordered martinis. The servers and hostess they say OK and they do not listen at your requests. The food was a joke. I like their fast food better located at Macys on State street. Never again. If you like to try proper Mexican food try and go to Maria,s in Rosemont. If you are limited to downtown places you are wasting your money.
Great place to have dinner with the family!! Very friendly environment!! Great job chef, I will recommend this place to my friends.

YES, I love this place, the decor, menu, staff and overal cuisne but our last visit yesterday was good but not fab as usual. The little plates we ordered were good as were two of three main dishes but the grilled shrimp were overly spicey and so -so black beans. The trio of chocolate desserts was really off--the salted ice cream had a strange texture and the cake tasteless. Of course we'll be back but disappointed

The good news: our appetizers at lunch today were absolutely delicious. I'd highly recommend the house guacamole and ceviche trio with house margaritas. The bad news: the entrees were just ok. My husbands chicken with green mile was cold and the chicken seemed precooked. My chicken mole soft tacos were cold & disappointing. I haven't asked the other two people in our party what they thought, but their lack of comment was telling. Not at all up to expectations & a bummer.

I was moderately satisfied with my experience at this restaurant. I have dined at Chef Rick Bayless' other restaurants but Frontera Grill wouldn't be my top choice. The location is sleek and festive and it was packed with working business people as well as local diners. My boyfriend and I were meeting a couple friends after work in the city and we decided to have some cocktails and dinner here. Our server seemed distracted and only appeared once we flagged him down. After ordering the delicious guacamole and chips we decided on entrees and waited. Our food was dropped off and then the server brought out our guacamole order. It would have been nice if it came before our meal as we could have enjoyed the appetizer prior to eating our entrees. We wanted to order the tres leches cake but our server was nowhere to be found so instead we took the check and headed out. The food was good but our dining experience was skewed with a not so inviting or attentive waiter.

I had modest expectations going in -- and Frontera over delivered.  It's pretty nice when that happens!  Yes, Its a giant operation lacking in soul, but the food!  Standouts were a tamale of huitlacoche, where the corn fungus was incorporated right into the masa, steamed to perfection, and served beautifully with just the right amount of mushroom sauce (nice mushrooms not buttons or brown in a beef stock) and a sprinkling of queso & enchiladas of duck carnitas.  The cocktails were wonderful too!

We've had Rick Bayless' cookbooks for years and have loved every recipe we ever made. Tonight we realized that he held the best stuff back. From the "Manifest Destiny" and the Mezcal margarita to the guacamole and the service, we couldn't have asked for more. We're so happy to have finally made it here.

Finally got a chance to try Frontera for brunch on Saturday. My friend and I lucked out because a reservation had just been cancelled and they were able to seat us immediately. Otherwise it would have been 30-45 minutes they said. We started with some basic chips and salsa before digging in to our main entrees. I ordered the Sapitos, which were 3 small corn masa cakes topped with chicken, chorizo and eggs, respectively. It was a really decadent brunch plate and something I could never dream of having made at home! The mole sauce covering the dish was really good, and gave everything just the right amount of pizzazz. Portion size was large enough to justify the $14 price but not so big that I felt stuffed after polishing off the entire thing. I highly recommend trying Frontera for brunch! There is an excellent assortment of great Mexican breakfast/bruch dishes that don't carry the high price point of the dinner menu.

Delicioso! I ordered the following (back in 2013): - Xoco Margarita - House Guacamole - Dzotobichay (tamales) - Mole Enchiladas (incredible depth & complexity) Awesome server, who was decisive, offering useful recommendations.
