Offered sample of delicate, subtle mole & coconut sorbet for dessert. Thank you! Definitely lives up to its steadfast reputation.

I've eaten and really enjoyed my meals at Xoco and at Frontera Torta at ORD so was naturally excited to eat at the mothership restaurant.  What a disappointing $85 lunch for the four of us.  The guac and chips starter was terrific and was offset by room temp entrees.  The mushroom enchiladas were borderline cold and tasted good but not great too many onions and just ok beans.  The fish taco portion was pauper like, but good.  The chicken quesadilla and sopes were very good but not differentiated.  The service was functional and we felt somewhat rushed.  Net, we've had better Mexican from local mom and pops at much better values.

Frontera Grill does take walk ins but it can be a bit of a wait.  Arrived here about 6pm on a Saturday night, party of two, and the wait was quoted for about an hour.  There is a bar area to wait and have a margarita, or in our case, it was so crowded we popped right across the street for a glass of wine.  Frontera took our phone number and texted us when the table was ready, just a few minutes over the hour quote.  Great timing! Great service, tried the mole trio, tacos and the topolo margaritas.  All quite tasty!  They have complimentary (tip only) coat check service.

I have been a follower of Mexico One Plate at a Time for decades and have had the pleasure of dinning at Frontera Grill and Topolobamba several times over the past years. On this visit from Milwaukee we were going to have dinner at Xoco, sadly they were closed so we walked around the corner to Frontera and were not disappoint. My six year old daughter tried cevchie for the first time and I had duck with a prune mole that was delicious. Saturday we will try again to est at Xoco, if not we will just need to visit Chicago sooner. Just a side note, I have never idilize athletes or movie stars. I have always concidered myself to be my own person, but if I was on a desert island and could only take three things with me, it would be a copy of a cook book from Adrian Richardson (the Secret Mear Business) , Steven Raichlen (Barbecue University), and of course Rick Bayless. I may not get off the island, but at least I would eat well.

Boyfriend and I got here at about 7 on a Friday night. Told us the wait would be an hour so we decided to wait at the bar. We got the blue agave margarita and champagne margarita plus chips and salsa. All delicious! Our table ended up being ready in 20 mins! Score.  We got the taquitos/flautas, Mexican quesadillas, mole enchiladas, and ice cream with both chocolate and dulce de leche sauce.  The clear winner for us were the quesadillas. They were more like empanadas. Gah I'm still craving those. I easily could've eaten 2 plates of them! The rest of the food was just alright. I was really disappointed with the sundae.  The menu changes almost every month, so I'd love to go back and try something new. Tip: skip the guac, it comes with most of the apps anyway!

Frontera Grill is Rick Bayless' flagship restaurant, and one that I had been wanting to visit for many years. Bayless is considered one of the top experts in Mexican food, having lived in Mexico for several years back in the 1980's. He continues to take his staff on yearly "food missions" to Mexico to this day. Bayless has won a James Beard Award for best chef, Midwest Region. His restaurant Topolobampo has 1 Michelin star. He also won Top Chef Masters, Season 1 in 2009. The meal began with a complimentary small dish of seasoned nuts, including peanuts and pepitas (pumpkin seeds). They were nicely spiced, but not hot. Warm corn tortillas were also provided with two types of salsa. The tortillas were nice and fluffy with some texture to it. The salsas had some spice to it, but again was not hot. I really liked the green salsa, although the red was also good. The Topolobampo Tortilla Soup ($8) is different than most tortilla soups, in that the broth is clear rather than having tortillas blended into the soup itself. The soup seemed to lack was good, but the pasilla chiles did not impart a lot of heat. The chicken remained moist, but the soup seemed to lack any real depth of flavor. I prefer the chicken tortilla soup by Dean Fearing immensely. The Classic Queso Fundido ($8) is a skillet of melted Jack cheese, roasted peppers and green chorizo. The cheese was melty good and stretchy, the peppers adding just a bit of punch, while the chorizo added some texture and meatiness to the dish. I really liked this dish, and would order it every time. The Mexican Street Corn was good, but was a little disappointing as it seemed too "formal". The corn was not slathered in mayo to the point of being overloaded. There was an ample amount of queso fresco however. The addition of epazote added some herbal pungency. The Chile Rellenos were incredibly huge. Battered and nicely fried, they were swimming in a pool of tomato based sauce. They were nicely stuffed with shredded pork and cheese. The dish came with a side of black beans and rice, which were also good. This is a solid dish, and is very hearty. The Carne Asada Brava included slices of perfectly cooked, tender and flavorful beef. It was paired with a sweet tamale, which could have been a little sweeter for my taste. The salsa also imparted a lot of flavor but not much heat. With my years of anticipation to eat at Frontera Grill, it fell slightly short of my expectations. The food was good, but was not "wow, what have I been waiting for all of these years!" good. I would like to try Topolobampo on my next trip to Chicago for comparison sake though.
I love a restaurant that plays mainstream Latino Music! Such a great vibe. Food was amazing from the ceviche trio, chilaquiles yucatecos, baja black cod in verde to the crepes for dessert.

Let's just say the hype was very real and delivery was mediocre .. A few friends came to visit from Arizona, one being the biggest Rick fan on the planet .. He insisted we try one of his restaurants.. We decided to give Frontera a shot .. Place was very clean and well decorated .. Great atmosphere .. Not very busy for a Saturday afternoon... Our server was very friendly yet a little obnoxious .. We asked for recommendations and he insisted on the mole after I said "I'm not a big fan of mole" lol he talked about the mole for 5 min straight .. My buddy ordered the mole with the 3 kinds .. He liked it, tasted a bit bland for me.. I order the enchiladas Verdes .. Tasty but not amazing .. And my other buddy ordered the carne asada which we all liked .. Needless to say, having 3 very Mexican people coming to a Mexican restaurant, we are bound to pick apart the menu.   Overall an ok experience. Not a place I would recommend ..
Top notch mexican food.  Mushroom tacos, tamales, chicken tacos guac and an appearance by Rick and wife.  Thats a great 21 year aniversary.  Thanks Frontera!

It was excellente'!  We had a party of seven with reservations and everyone was very pleased with the service, food creativity and quality and evening.  The noise level is a tad high, would be the only negative to list.

Fancy Mexican done right!! Food and drinks, awesome! Interior looks a bit wild, but still great. I love that the quality and the plating of all their dishes are top notch, but the price isn't overwhelming. As popular as it is, the wait can be long. I went on a Friday night around 9 and the place was really busy. Got lucky with seats at the bar and it was great. The bartender seems to be very knowledgable and came up with recommendations of special drinks that weren't on the menu.  Food:  Ceviches - I tried Frontera Cheviche and Cheviche Trio. Both really fresh and good. Go with the Trio if you want variety.  Chicken tamales - I'm not a big fan of tamales, but this one I enjoyed. Soft and flavorful.  Mexican quesadilla - My favorite! Hot cheese oozing out endlessly. I keep thinking about it once in a while.  Drinks: Blue Agave Margarita - not too sweet and has a good kick. Goes really well with Cheviche.  Benito Picoso - special drink recommended by the bartender. Not on the menu. It's spicy and tangy. It's unique. Try it if you love spicy drinks.

On a trip back to Chicago from DC this week I was able to get into the Frontera Grill with my girlfriend from DC who has never had Rick Bayless' cuisine. If you are a seafood fan the Oysters and Ceviche platter is worth every penny of the $45 price tag.  The grilled wood taco combo with duck, chicken and steak was also to die for. I know you get what you pay for, but my only complaint is $208 for a dinner for 2 including tax and tip is pretty stiff.  But part of that is Chicago taxes are bank robbery and I left a 25% tip because the service was as outstanding as the drinks and food.

Managed to get in here for lunch restaurant week and gave it a try. Seriously one of the best meals I've had in my life! The decor is adorable and stays true to the Mexican style Rick Bayless is known for. I had the corn tamales, enfrijoladas, and tres leches cake. All were AMAZING!!! The corn tamales were moist and came out perfectly warm and delicious. While waiting for our entree, our water glasses got low. A worker came by, and filled our waters and apologized they got so slow. No big deal to me, but she offered my friend and I a glass of free horchata to make up for it. I was going to say no to that! All the food is so rich and full of flavor it's incredible. And as I mentioned, the staff go out of their way to make this an amazing dining experience.  I have already booked another reservation later this month when my parents come to visit me in Chicago, and I plan on bringing anyone who visits to this amazing establishment. Reservations are limited so get in while you can. I promise you won't regret it!

Had Lunch here. Got huge expectations from this place but it was only decent. I got the Enchiladas with the Mole sauce and the chicken was a bit dry. The fish of the day dish was much better. We also tried the trio street food, wasn't bad. The ceviche was good and so was the mexico city style quesadilla. Like the Enchiladas, the chicken taquitos was a bit dry. My Oaxacan friend said it didn't live up to the hype it got. I actually like Ixacteco Grill much better than Frontera Grill. Maybe we just got the wrong dishes but we might try dinner next time to see.

When you walk into Frontera, it has the feel of a neighborhood Mexican restaurant. Though the multiple James Beard awards on the walls certainly tell a different story.  The food was incredible. We started with a trio of ceviches and trio of different masa appetizers (street food). For dinner, we shared the tacos al carbon trio and for dessert, we had flan. The only word I can use to describe the food is perfect. I don't know how I'm ever going to eat Mexican food anywhere else.

This is a very busy place! We had a 9:30pm seating on a Thursday night and got there at 8:30pm. The place was very busy. We got a seat at the bar & had a drink. Rick was in the kitchen & his daughter was working the front desk. We got in to eat at 9:15pm. We had the Chicken Crema appetizer with tortillas which was excellent! My wife had the Carne Asada for dinner which was good and very generous in the portion given. I had the Seven seas Braise which was very good. They gave me tortillas which I used. I could have used some rice to soak up the broth so it got a little messy. We left about 10:30pm and the crowd was widing down. We had a great meal and a nice time. The waiter was very helpful in his recommendations. I had mescal for the first time and liked it. We'd go back again. FYI the valet is $15.
My favorite place in town. The Margs are the best in the city. Gauc is always awesome.  You can really never go wrong with any options here.

Frontera is one of my favorite restaurants in Chicago.  Excellent margaritas, amazing ceviche, and usually great tacos.  Been here many times We ordered their guacamole and ceviche trio as a starter.  All fantastic. My main course was the duck carnitas. Normally this is one of my favorite dishes, but this time very sub par. First, the meat tasted old...REALLY old.  Second, there was a large bone in the taco that I bit into. This nearly ruined the meal for me. Finished with their specialty coffee, which was superb. Giving Frontera another go in the future because usually the place is 5-star.  Can't justify that rating based on my experience this time.

Love the ceviche. We had tacos combo and everything was just delicious! Tacos combo had chicken, duck, and steak. My favorite was steak as the meat was very tender. Drinks are really good too. I think mine was blood orange drink.

The first time I came here in August everything was wonderful (raw sampler, lamb dish I don't remember the name). Today, however, was just so-so. The oysters were good and the tuna cocktail was great! The shishito peppers and garlicky mushrooms were disappointing, however. Both lacked salt and overall seasoning/flavor. My meal 6 months ago was packed with flavor so suffice it to say, I was surprised. Also, service from the bartender with the long beard isn't great. He seems knowledgeable but standoffish. Also he spent the majority of his time chatting with a couple he knew. I sat several minutes with an empty wine glass. First world problems I know but at these prices (Food and 3 glasses of wine came to over $100 for lunch) service should be consistently top notch.
Food was just ok, not worth the price.  Went to pay and returned the bill with the a different guests credit card!   Will not come here again.

I am a fan of Rick Bayless and have been wanting to try out his restaurant for a while now. I visited last summer. We went in 5 mins after opening and had to wait about 20 mins for a seat due to a high volume of reservations. Our server was great! I can't remember the name of the dish I had, but it was fish, eggplant, and plantains in a sauce. It was delicious, but not spicy enough for my taste. Our server actually went to the back and asked the chefs for a sauce with a kick. He returned with a few different hot sauces and a small bowl of a handmade chili sauce. I loved it because it was super spicy and just the heat I was looking for. Would definitely return for the food and excellent service!

Looking for something different on Friday night, we stopped by Frontera Grill with the hope that the wait wouldn't be too bad.  Fortunately for us, it was only 20 minutes and so we grabbed a seat at the bar (which wasn't too crowded!) and had the Champagne Margarita.  OMG!  It was delicious.  I've had one before (at a different restaurant) and while I'm not a fan of champagne, the combination is delicious, and the one at Frontera was superb!  It definitely had the booze in it b/c my husband was feeling it by the time our table was ready. They sat us downstairs - which I didn't know they even had.  I won't say I'm a fan of the downstairs - it definitely feels as if you're downstairs, but I will say that I didn't feel neglected at all by the wait staff.  It is more quiet and subdued downstairs. We ordered another round of drinks to start the meal off right.  My husband switched to the Blue Agave Margarita - which he thought was okay.  I stuck with the true shining star of the Champagne Margarita! We started with the Coctel Campechano Ceviche - which was a combination of crab, shrimp, octopus, squid, and tuna ceviche in an avocado sauce.  We loved it and finished it quickly.  It's not a large portion - I will say - but quite tasty. For our entrees, we got the Pork Loin with spinach and mashed potatoes in a pasilla huilacoche sauce and the Carne Asada Brava - which was a habanero marinated skirt steak w/ salsa and onions and corn tamales.  Both dishes were excellent and there was not a drop of food left on our plates at the end.   For dessert - we got the Coconut three ways - cake, tangerines, guava frozen yogurt.  It was not our favorite.  It was fine, but after the rest of the meal, it was a bit of a disappointment to us.  The drinks, ceviche and entrees were just shining stars, that I wouldn't make my time on the dessert next time. We've been to Frontera Grill a few times in the past, and have had mixed reviews.  However, this past Friday night's experience has definitively made me a fan again, and I will be back.

This is one of my favorite places to go in Chicago.  Rick always manages to surprise and excite.  The ceviche is fresh and delicious. The flavors are always amazing with a clear point of view.  A place for culinary delight.

Frontera grill was everything I could hope for and more. Absolutely delicious. Although we had to wait almost 2 hours for a table because they don't typically take reservations. The food was outstanding and worth the wait!

Overall it was a pretty dissappointing experience.  The wait staff was kind, but our waiter completely forgot to put in our lunch order after we received our appetizers and drinks.  We sat there for an hour before he finally came by, remembered, and put our order in. Ceviche was fresh, but the portions of everything we ordered were incredibly small and the chips were a little stale.  The Tinga entree was supposed to be braised pork with house made chorizo, but neither of us detected any chorizo and it mostly made up of diced potatoes as filler... and the portion size was roughly half a cup. We spent $120 on lunch and it was neither filling nor delicious.   Not going back.

Loved the appetizers and plantains, but the shrimp de la Diabla was way too salty.  The dish didn't know what it wanted to be.  Not very citrusy, very, very salty, not really spicy, not really mole either.  Shrimp with a ton a salt and tomato mole with rice and Tortias.  Almost too salty to eat.   Get appetizers, if we come again won't bother with entrees.   Experienced the same over saltiness at xoxo,  so was hesitant to try.

My boyfriend and I went here by recommendation.  We were recently visiting Chicago for Valentines and this was also close to our hotel.  We initially strayed because it is pricey but decided to indulge because of the recommendation.  The cocktails are all super good and delicious.  They have a mixologist behind the bar serving.  We ordered the Hawaiian ceviche for an appetizer while waiting- really fresh and full of flavors.  The wait wasn't too bad for a Friday evening- only waiting about an hour.  My boyfriend ordered the steak and I got the fried chicken (they are called something else on the menu but it was in Spanish).  Really wish I would have saved room for desert because it looked delicious.  Probably wouldn't come back here unless it was for a special occassion- it is a little to pricey in my opinion.
If you are in Chicago, this is a MUST. I took two friends from Mexico City there and they were Amazed on how authentic and great the food is. I am looking forward to my return to the Windy City

So this is my 2nd time here. I came back here for restaurant week, and my boyfriend is a huge fan of Rick Bayless. When we walked into the restaurant, I couldn't help but notice the amazing smell of tomatillo. It made my mouth water. I was expecting them to serve chips and salsa/guac to start off our meal - it's too bad they didn't. Appetizers Ceviche was GREAT. Tangy and sweet. The flavors went well with the albacore. 5/5. Fresh corn tamales - meh. A little disappointed with this dish. It tasted just like cornbread. 1/5. Entrees Enfrijoladas - came with a side of rice. Overwhelming amount of beans. Not really my taste, but the boyfriend loved it. 2/5. Taco arabes - The meat was cooked PERFECTLY. I've never had tacos with such tender meat like this. 5/5. Dessert Seasonal tres leches cake - mmmm good, but a bit too sweet for my taste. 4.5/5. Seasonal sopa de frutas - pineapple flavored sorbet with diced pineapple and kiwi. The sorbet was tarty and refreshing! Definitely recommend this dessert if you're not a fan of super sweet sweets.

The real deal for quality Mexican fare. Unpretentious despite its premium real estate, a good spot for an elegant meal in the dining room or a more casual bite at the bar. The tequila and mescal selection are over the top , a fantastic cocktail and wine list. The tacos and guac are very authentic and flavorful. A dessert of gelato with fresh fruit was a super refreshing finale to a great meal. A strong recommend

I'm having very mixed feelings about this place. I've read tons of great reviews, was recommended this place from countless foodies- but my entire table and i agreed, definitely underwhelmed. I made the reservations 3 weeks in advance, we got seated right away which was great, the hostess/waiters/all staff were amazing. The ambiance was really mediocre, nothing fancy at all, and the service was good but the food was average at best. Guacamole really not impressed, just your standard with a few mixins, drinks were good, mole enchiladas we're tasty but again nothing mind-blowing. Ceviche was too watered down in our opinion and all the chips were stale, nothing fresh. And now lastly this crane asada steak platter that came highly recommended shocked me the most. The meat had so much fat, each bit took about 45 secs to take down due to texture and the taste was again lacking. The best thing we had all night were the plantains that were made well. Overall, a 3 star experience- doesn't live up the hype, food was average, and safe to say doesn't deserve to be one of Chicago's elite places to eat.

I recently visited Frontera Grill for Chicago Restaurant Week, and it was one of the best meals I have had since moving to Chigago! I highly recommend this restaurant!!! From the restaurant week menu, I chose the Fresh Corn Tamales appetizer, and then had the Enfrijoladas entree, and both were incredible. The portion size was great and presentation was amazing. For dessert I had the Tres Leches Cake which was the most beautiful dessert presentation I have seen. It was a little too rich for my liking but my friend thoroughly enjoyed it. They even gave us horchata on the house because we had to wait for our water to be refilled! I would definitely recommend stopping by if you have the chance!
Super yummy Saturday brunch but beware what the server thinks isn't spicy sure is to the average Canadian tourist! Guac was to die for and entrees were great although a little spicy for our taste.
I really liked the ceviche trio and sopes rancheros.  I wasn't too fond of the oaxacan-style carne asada and I felt it was over priced

Anyone who claims the food at Frontera Grill is bland or unremarkable has a serious taste bud problem or is just used to ubiquitous Mexican fast food. Unique, interesting, and complex flavors would describe the food at this moderately priced casual spot. Very popular because it is, in one word, yummy!!!

Yum, yum, yum!!!!! This place is amazing! I've always enjoyed watching Rick bayless on pbs cook so when I found out that he has a restaurant in Chicago I had to go!  Luckily it's restaurant week in Chicago so this is the best time to try a new restaurant for a good deal! My  experience here was beyond expectations! This is definitely my new favorite Mexican restaurant.  My husband and I decided to get the winter salad, ceviche, oaxacan style carne asada, fish in peanut green mole sauce, tres leches cake, and sorbet. My husband and I were able to share everything and we both enjoyed everything given to us. But Our favorites we're the ceviche and the oaxacan entree. The steak was creek stone meat (which is halal!!!) was cooked and seasoned perfectly! The ceviche was the best ceviche I've ever had and I don't even like ceviche! I can't wait to go back and try the rest of the menu! My husband especially liked the wide variety of sauces given especially the habanero sauce (which is good but way too hot for me personally). In terms of service our waiter and the staff were excellent! Our server was attentive and very knowledgable. The rest of the staff took our jackets, filled our glasses, and made sure to clear empty plates.  In terms of pricing it's definitely more on the higher end of the scale. But it's definitely a great meal. It's a date night or celebration type of place. I personally wouldn't take my kids here because it seems more like an adults only place and I didn't see any kids there for dinner (but it was 7:30 on a school night).  But it's a loud of enough place to take your kids if you'd like. The only cons are Chicago street parking which always sucks but we were able to find close parking meter parking.

The ceviche just explodes with flavor.  Get your margarita toppolo while you wait because you will have to wait.  This place has been opened for 29 years and still going strong. It's packed all the time.  We were served our meal at 10 pm and there was still a long line of diners waiting for the Frontera Grill dining experience.   I had the fixed price meal for $33 and the ceviche was just to die for, the duck in mole "cousin sauce" was so succulent.  My sisters kept dipping their entrees into the duck mole sauce to give their food that extra flavor.  The Saturday night rib special was also very good.  The spice came at the back end which was a bit of surprise.  The grits calmed down the spice in a nice way.  The desert tres leches was a bit of a disappointment.  The meringue although it  added a pretty look did nothing for the flavor.  It made the tres leches overly sweet.

I am a foodie, and love great Mexican food, and I have been waiting to come here but I really was not that impressed....I have eaten better street LA food....for sure...The guacamole was good so was the steak carnitas....but other then that all was quite flavorless... It wasn't bad but really was not great. The receptionist was not very helpful, we had to check in 3 times for our table even though our reservation was at 9:30. Finally a nice gentleman listened the third time and long and behold after waiting for 30 mins our table was just there.....Not cool.(not sure if that made the experience worse) Churros next door is something I must try...

As soon as we walk in, we were greeted by a rude receptionist. She told us our wait would be 1 hour 45 minutes, but told the couple in front of us that the wait would be 45 minutes minutes and then changed it to 15 minutes after they slipped her some money. That was a huge turn off to me. I ordered the the carne asada. It was ok. I've had better at other places. The rest of the food and drinks were great, but I was really turned off by my experience. Not sure I will be returning.

Great food but I was disappointed that we did not get chips and salsa with our food for the price of the food. Also was told we would have to wait an hour but actually only waited 10 minutes which was good but that was a slight miscommunication....
The food is really great. The vibe is chill. Bartender I had was too cocky and obnoxious for me but I'm guessing he's a bit jaded as this place is always busy. With good reason. The FOOD!

Rick Bayless, culinary magician. Having spent a stretch of my life in San Diego, I was skeptical at the thought of having Mexican food in Chicago as my first dinner in town. After my visit, I am convinced the food at Frontera Grill is among the best Mexican food I have had. Favorites at beginning of list: Sopes Rancheros (corn masa boats w/ shredded beef) - Absolute must-try Winter Guac - fresh take on guac dip Oxacan Style Carne Asada - packed with flavor, generous portion Mole Trio Cochinita Pibil (Wednesday Special)

My friends and I really enjoyed lunch here.  We tried the basic guacamole, chips and salsa, steak tacos, ceviche trio and street food trio plus many margaritas! The meats on each dish were delicious and tender.  The steak for the tacos was cooked to order.

Huge Fan of Rick Bayless. I've seen many of his shows, videos and guest appearances on TV. I love how he put together the Menu for Frontera Grill. He always seems to had a little spin to an Authentic Mexican dish. This is why when we were on vacation in Chicago, Frontera Grill had to be on the top of our Restaurants to eat at and we were NOT disappointed. Can't wait to try his other restaurants, which I'm sure are fabulous.
Amazing, Rick is a genius. Good service but not the best, messed up our drinks twice.

Bayless has defined Mexican dining in America and Frontera will redefine what you think of the Mexican cuisine landscape.  The tortilla soup was simple, yet absolutely amazing.  He does his name and his craft a disservice by offering the prepared food and sauces on the grocery store shelves.

Some amazing mixtures and flavors! The meat dishes we had were the 20-hour smoked Creekstone beef brisket, Oaxacan black mole, quest añejo mashed potatoes; and the Duck Tlatonile with red chile- rubbed duck cooked on wood fire, Tlatonile (ancho and arbol chiles, garlic, sesame), sesame-braised spaghetti squash and spinach). The meat from both dishes were prepared perfectly. The mashed potatoes with the brisket were very flavorful and had an amazing buttery texture. The spaghetti squash and spinach with the duck was not quite as exciting as the mashed potatoes, I think something else would be a better combination with the duck. Overall very good meal and exciting to try new take on old flavors.

I am a HUGE Rick Bayless fan, and have been to Frontera Grill on a couple of special occassions, and will be returning again to celebrate my parents anniversary and Christmas.  I was not happy when I sent my parents a gift card for their anniversary and Christmas gift. On the gift card they wrong somthing completely wrong, indicating that it was from someone they do not know. So needless to say their was a little drama revolving around this gift card. I had emailed them twice regarding the mixup, but never got a response. When they called to confirm my reservation was I able to get in touch with the person who handled this. They informed me there was nothing they could do. When I called the person back to give them the gift card number to insure this too was for the correct amount, I once again informed the woman in charge of the gift cards, she was able to confirm the amount was atleast correct. We went to dinner and not only was it superb service, they provided a complimentary dessert, which was abosolutely amazing! Love this place, and we will continue to go back!

My wife and I thought we might get lucky with wait times here when we stopped by at 10 PM on a Friday on the way to our hotel (they close at 11). They still had a 45 minute wait for a table, but plenty of space and full menu at the bar, so we were okay with that! They even held our luggage at the coat check for us. I really should stop reading other reviews before I write one. Lots of grumblers and complainers. All I can say is that my wife and I loved everything. Here's what we got:  - Blue agave margarita for her, Oaxacan gold mezcal for me. Small glasses, but potent. Mine had spicy salt, which I'll probably skip next time. The drink was good but I didn't see the point of that.  - Classic queso fundido. Lots of cheese, meat and onions and some small tortillas with red and green salsa. Very flavorful, but we had to fit a lot in those few tortillas. We managed though! Loved it.  - Old school Frontera trio for her. She subbed out ceviche for enchiladas potosinas since she's not big on fish, much less raw fish. Also came with tiny quesadillas and chicken taquitos, and fresh guacamole. She doesn't usually like guacamole but liked hers, I think because it was very fresh and not acidic at all. Mostly just avocado with a few tomatoes.  - Shrimp a la Diabla for me. I don't usually get shrimp at restaurants since it's easy to make at home (and she is allergic to shellfish) but they were perfectly made here. The sauce, rice, and spinach were perfect, simple additions. I'm still working on my spice tolerance, and definitely suffered a bit, but it was worth it.  - Flan duo for dessert. The two flans aren't identical (on purpose) and one was a bit more gooey than the other. I liked them OK. Would probably pick something else next time.  Overall we loved it, knowing going in that it's a celebrity chef restaurant downtown in a major city, which means it's expensive and you have to wait. If you can't get over that skip it. We're very glad we made this our first Chicago stop!

The food and service at Frontera are consistently top notch.  The oysters are the best - some of the freshest in the city.  Other stand out dishes include the Oaxacan carne asada, whole duck carnitas, and the chocolate pecan pie.  No matter what you choose, however, you can't go wrong. The topolo margaritas are also highly recommended!  Some complain about the wait or the price, but both are worth it.  And, pro tip, if you're willing to dine a little later your wait time will be much shorter.

We had a large group of 10: never had to ask for anything: waiters & staff were right on top of everything: drink refills, water, chips - tasting the different salsa, mole & quac! all our meals were FABULOUS: all came out together & HOT! The Xoco Margarita was out of this world!!   can't wait to go back!

Simply put, some of the best, most authentic Mexican food around. Having spent the day at the Art Institute, we decided to take a chance on getting a walk-in table at Frontera Grill. We walked over and arrived around 5:10 and were put on the list for 5:40. At 5:20, when they open the doors, we were immediately seated in the Dining Room. Bravo! Skipping the obligatory "chips and guac" we went straight to the Ceviche Trio and the "Street Food Trio". The ceviche was easily the best I've had with a nice textural and flavor progression between the three. The "Street Food Trio" was good, but clearly the Ceviche was  the star.  Next up was the Mole Poblano Enchiladas. These were perfectly executed with a nice balance between the chicken and the mole. Definitely worth trying. For Entres we ordered the Chicken in Xico Mole, Carnes al Carbon, and the Snapper al la Verecruzana. In a few words, order the Chicken! It was easily the best dish of the evening, and one of the best dishes I've ever had. With perfectly cooked chicken and a truly unique mole I can't imagine anyone not liking it. Both the Carnes and the Snapper were as expected, correctly cooked, perfectly seasoned, and nicely plated...but the Chicken is on another level. While other "Mexican" restaurants may do a few dishes better, almost none has the depth and breadth of Frontera Grill. Rick and his crew cover almost every region with consistently well executed plates and a menu that is never stale. Impressive, considering Frontera is closing on 30 years in the business! The reason is simple, Rick and Deann still have a passion for what they do and care about what comes out of the kitchen. To the point, we were there on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving and saw Rick come out of the back to walk the room. This on a night most chefs at his level would have handed it off to the crew! Next time you're in the area, take a chance on getting an early table. You won't be disappointed.

The food n drinks here are definitely upscale Mexican food such as carnivale or mercadito. The seating tho is very casual and can feel very  crowded. The food tho is very tasty and filling. The servings are different not your typical rice and beans with a meat. So I would definitely ask what all comes with your meal. My mother enjoyed the Carne asada dish and I had a version of chicken tacos. The tacos were good but it tasted like jerk chicken very spicy. I enjoyed the guacamole and drinks were amazing you should try the champagne Margarita and pear Margarita both delish. I would return to try other options. Enjoy.

I finally had the opportunity to eat at Frontera Grill for lunch recently, and while the service, ambiance, and portion size were all very good, the food and drink was less than I had anticipated.  I had the seasonal pear ginger margarita to start my meal and one of my companions had the non-alcoholic strawberry cooler.  The latter was judged very good, but the margarita was just so-so.  There was ginger flavor to be sure, but no trace of pear flavor that I could taste, and the drink was weak.  Since this was lunch I did not bother to send this back.  Had this been a more relaxed dinner, I would have returned this to the bar for  both of these shortcomings. My companions and I all agreed the food was good, but not outstanding.  I ordered the mole poblano enchiladas.  This is far above anything you are likely to get at most Mexican-style restaurants, except perhaps in New Mexico where I learned to appreciate mole enchiladas.  The mole at Frontera Grill was clearly a complex mix of spices and herbs, as expected, but it was too sweet and left a cloying taste after each bite that needed to be balanced out with refried beans.  The heat from the poblanos was just right, but the sweetness of the mole kept this dish from being outstanding.   On a more positive note, the guacamole was excellent.  Also, the bar area has great atmosphere; the dining room not so much despite great Mexican folk art on the walls.

Always great.  I've never had a dish here that I didn't like.  Even my mother loved it, and she is NOT an adventurous eater,  to the point that Mexican food qualifies as exotic cuisine to her.  While the food here is enough to warrant five stars, the service is what makes it shine.  The entire staff is very helpful and nice, from the bartenders all the way to the management.  I never miss a chance to eat here.
Great place. The service was amazing which made the night great. The food was delicious, my favorite being the tortilla soup. Can't wait to go back soon!

We ate here the other night, for the first time in a long time. Ordinarily, I guess we've assumed there would be a very long wait, and we weren't in the mood for it, but on this occasion, we decided to go early (for us) at 6:00 and just drink until we could get a table. Instead, we got a table immediately (the first diners were just getting finished).  In no rush, we ordered our favorite Mezcal Margaritas and nibbled on the free nuts and seeds while we contemplated our choices. Then the food came out for a large party seated next to us, and we realized that the menu had changed considerably since our last visit, and it all looked so good! One of the guys at the neighboring table told us that what they'd all ordered was the duck carnitas for two - the fried legs and breasts of a whole duck - crispy and delicious, with corn tortillas, a roasted salsa, guacamole, and beans topped with fried plantains. But before we ordered that, we had the Enchiladas Potosinas, and the Shrimp and Bacalao Papantla Style. Everything was marvelous, but there was still so much on the menu to try, so we vowed to return before December 1st, when the menu changes. Frontera Grill - we love you. Still marvelous after all these years.

First time at frontera. Overall, I think this place is overrated: service was slow, food was okay and prices were high for what you get. Chips, salsa and guacamole were great. For an entree, by recommendation by our waiter, I ordered the Oxuacan carne asada steak medium. Waiter told me it's by far the most flavorful and best carne asada on the menu (there were two others). He told me the menu changes frequently but this item had never been taken off the menu (perhaps it should be).  The steak was burnt on the outside and pink to medium in the inside. Worst of all, quarter of the steak was marbled fat. Definitely wouldn't recommend this dish. Dessert was okay. I had the chocolate pecan pie. Nothing to write home about. All in all, not worth the $50 I paid for my meal. Chicago had so many other Mex restaurants that are much better.
Fantastic mexican food!  The service was really good also!  Walked in and was seating immediately on a Saturday afternoon at 1:45pm.  I hear it can be much worse but wasn't our experience.
This place has some tasty food. I wouldn't mind going back here again and trying more things off their menu. I liked their ceviche and haven't had that much really anywhere else but Hawaii.

I came here for lunch on a Wednesday afternoon. My lunch companion and I got the last two seats at the bar and proceeded to order two of the best drinks we have ever had. I enjoyed the seasonal pear margarita and my sister had a cocktail that was a combo of champagne and a margarita. She enjoyed her drink and I absolutely loved mine. It wasn't too sweet and had the perfect balance for a margarita. If it was later in the day I would've had a second and third! We had the empanadas as an appetizer and I would recommend those. For our main courses we shared the mushroom tacos and the shrimp/fish tacos. Both were good but I would come back and order the mushroom tacos in a heartbeat.  The corn tortillas are hot, fresh, and delicious! Great service at the bar with decent prices overall. I will be back.
Yes, it's still the best Mexican in the city. Sorry to the haters.

Food is great.  Drinks made to order.  Dietary restrictions double checked.  Your seated promptly based on your reservation.  What's not to love!  Wish all restaurants worked like this.   The only thing that sucks is that the place is always packed that you have to wait forever to get the reservation you want or take a chance on sitting around as a walk in.

I've lived in Chicago for 8 years now, and I finally made an effort to eat here this week. My husband was home this week so we decided to go at 5 on a weeknight so bypass the lines. When we arrived, we put our names down and waited at the bar because they don't actually seat until 5:40. So keep in mind if you show up at 5, you won't actually get to start eating until more like 5:40. My husband had a mezcal cocktail called the paloma and I had the topolo margarita. Drinks were delicious, but small for 12 dollars. They shake them at your table, but you don't get to drink what's left in the shaker..they take the shakers away with them. Sad. I would have liked those extra few sips. While we were waiting we had an order of chips and salsa ($4). That's right. No free chips and salsa at this Mexican restaurant. The serving of salsa was a bit stingy. You get a couple tablespoons of red and couple tablespoons of green salsa. We had some chips left over that were feeling pretty sad over the lack of salsa. When we were seated at 5:40, our waiter was friendly and quick. We ordered the street food trio and the wood fired al carbon (duck, chicken, steak  make your own tacos) plate. The street food trio was tasty and flavorful. The tacos were kind of meh. Tasty but nothing mind blowing. We could have used a few more tortillas as well. Everything was good, but we kind of felt like the tacos at our favorite hole in the wall were more tasty and much cheaper.  We had some leftover meat from the taco platter that we took home and ate it for breakfast with fried eggs the next day so that was a nice little bonus. With drinks and tip, our bill was about 110.  Glad we tried it, but we don't plan on coming back.

We went at closing time 10 pm.  The wait staff was great and sat us anyway.  The staff was friendly and the food was some if the best I've ever had.  It was overpriced, probably because it is in the middle of Chicago, but overall a great experience.

Rick Bayless is a genius. The food here is so authentic and extremely good. I recommend trying everything on the sharing portion of the menu. The topolo Margarita is the best I've ever had. The staff is very polite and fast.

I've made many attempts to get into Frontera over the last 15 years. All have failed. This time I had an out of town business college who insisted on this is the place he must hit. So we waited at the door 4:45pm so we can get an early table if possible. It worked Cynthia was great at the hostess stand. we were seated at 5:20 in the bar area, love how the place is decorated with robust colors, very warm and comfortable. Ceviche Trio was perfect served very cold the chips were fresh! Margaritas were again delicious. Went with the Frontera Guacamole one of the best. Oaxacan style carne asada, a little bit under done ordered it medium pink warm center it came out medium rare still flavorful and good but kinda dissapointing, the plantain, black beans and guac all excellent. The Chocolate and vanilla flan was a real treat.

Took the beautiful girlfriend out to lunch while we were in Chicago. She had the ceviche trio and I had the mole trio. We were both pleased with our choices. It was a great time, not cheap but well worth it. Service was fantastic.

I've wanted to come here for a long long time.  I have not really had the chance to try it because I always end up somewhere else for whatever reason.  This time I was adamant that I would try it. I was in town on business so I was alone.  Belly up to the bar time! The Bartender was very nice and attentive and so I felt the service was awesome. (He did forget to put in my dessert, but wasn't a huge deal) The decor was really nice and gave off a fancy yet playful vibe which I enjoyed.  The bar wall was filled with various tequilas in rows (very impressive). Glancing over the menu, it was clear these were Chicago prices and it obviously did not help it is located in one of the more touristy areas.  I ordered the Daily special which was basically shredded pork with tons of spices (think carnitas) with black beans.  It was very simple, but had great flavor.  Personally I got bored half way through the meal.  It was just a bunch of the same thing.  I want to make sure I clarify....It was delicious, but it seemed to just go on forever.  Perhaps a better dish would incorporate this with other smaller items on the plate to give variety.  I was also a bit turned off by the fact they charge for chips and salsa.  Come on, what place charges for chips and salsa??   The star dish of my night was actually the dessert.  The Duo Flan came out beautiful with a traditional vanilla Flan and a very non-traditional chocolate flan that tasted more like a mousse.  They had marinated pears on top with hibiscus flower petals and chocolate sauce covering the plate.  This was a VERY good dessert.  I happily finished it all. This is a place where I wanted to give 3.5, but in the end due to service and ambiance I rounded up instead of down. Not sure I'd come back here again given all the superb options around but I'd definately not argue against joining someone here.

Dining alone meant that after a few minutes of waiting I was able to secure a spot at the bar. The service was great and quick, and I had some of the best sweet plantains ever. The street food trip was delicious. Everything was great, but it felt overcrowded and I'm not sure that this place quite lived up to the hype. However, I'd totally dine here again!

Except for the bar, this was a terrible experience.  The frenetic pace was unpleasant, the food sounded interesting but was only okay. Our server wouldn't really describe the dishes we asked about sufficiently for us to make informed decisions (his description of a shrimp dish-- "It's spicy"), not that we could hear him very well, so we just had to punt.  We waited longer for our food than we were given to eat it-- one of the servers cleared all of the plates, glasses, chips, salsas, and tortillas while one of our party was still eating, and a few others would have ordered another drink to finish off the chips and salsa. My water glass was never refilled..  We might have ordered dessert and coffee, but the menus were passed out, 2 minutes later, the server came back asked for our order, and when we said we hadn't had time to consider, he took away all of the menus. Truly terrible, pushy service from impatient and grumpy servers who had no time for making guests feel comfortable-- it's get in, get out.  The music was great, but too loud for conversation. My dish was my go-to, the chicken with mole. The mole was delicious, but there was not enough to coat the dust dry 4 slices of chicken (about 1/4 of a whole chicken breast). The squash tasted like frozen puree and there was too much of it and the crispy eggplant was soggy.  I think that carefully prepared, with some attention to each dish it might have been excellent, but it was not.  So, what did I like enough to merit two stars?  The bar. The art work and music were wonderful. The bar stools were a challenge.  The cocktail menu was interesting, the non-alcoholic beverages equally so.  My party enjoyed the margaritas and beers, I enjoyed a limeade mix (excellent), and great service in the bar.   This was my second time at Frontera (last time was many, many years ago), and now I remember why I hadn't gone back. Chicago has way too many much better places to waste time on this one.

Fun restaurant and good food. I'm not a huge fan of American Mexican food so this was a pleasant surprise. The food is clearly made with the best ingredients- the flavors are fresh and vibrant. The options are great and the portion size is perfect.

The food is delicious but the service is a problem. I called multiple times to ask for a table by the wall because I am deaf in one ear and my mother is near 80. Sure enough, the host tries to seat us at a table in the center of the room. With an open table at the wall, I ask why we cannot sit there. "It is spoken for," is the reply. So, the evening started with a fight about the wall table, and he did give it to us in the end, but why the fight when I had called? Service is sllloooowwwww. Our server was jolly and helpful but there were long gaps between being seated and ordering drinks, between drinks and appetizers, between appetizers and meal. Like hour long gaps. The brisket was terrific, as was the duck and the vegetarian option, but when I drop nearly $300 for a meal, I don't want to feel forgotten or starving before my actual meals arrives. More servers? More cooks? Attentive reception?

Creative and delicious. We had a lunch reservation, greeted warmly, promptly seated. Staff were friendly, knowledgeable and very helpful in ordering. Old Fashioned trio great starter,all of us liked all 3 items. Be sure and try the homemade lime aid, we all went for it and loved them. The food was fresh and flavorful. Worth your time and money.

Pricey for okay food and poor host service. Including a beer, a side of beans and rice, and the items below, our bill was $87. Over all, not a horrible experience, but nothing special. Service:  Hour-and-a-half wait on a Friday night, pretty typical. However, after we received a text stating a table was available, the hosts forgot about us, and seated another couple who had just walked into the restaurant. We waited another 10 minutes before a hostess asked if we wanted a table. Our waiter was attentive and friendly. Items we ordered: Guacamole Almondrado - slightly too salty, and nothing special. The portion was about 1/3 cup. Yucatecan Ceviche - described as "steamed Mexican blue shrimp and calamari". There was one shrimp, cut in half lengthwise. The total portion of seafood was about a third of a cup. Enchiladas Potosinas - supposed to be "chile-spiked" but was actually very bland. Included a dollop of guacamole. Tapas-sized portion. Torta de Elote - something like a corn custard with a tasty greenish mole. The only dish that I found interesting and flavorful. Paloma Oaxaquena - great mezcal cocktail with grapefruit bitters.

Highly recommend Street Trio (guacamole, beef on dough, and a salsa-look sauce). Best appetizer. Dough with beef and a sauce with complex flavor (kind of like warm salsa). They just made it in the right way, dough crispy enough to go with the rich marinated beef. The side sauce fresh your tongue with a long-lasting and multiple "layers" spicy flavor. And no one will refuse guacamole after this small but rich appetizer. For dinner, you get a table if you are at the front of the line, otherwise reservations take many of the seats. You will be texted if a table is available, so no worries. There is a bar and dining areas. One of the dining areas is away from the bar, but still loud cus it is crowded and tables are set very close to each other. However, you can check your bag and clothes, so there can be enough space for you to sit down. Waiters are welcoming and sweet. Price. Uh... What I had is pretty good. It may worth it. But for entry, it is like 20ish for one, really fancy one will be 30ish and almost 40.

What a huge, huge disappointment it was last night to eat at Frontera Grill. From the minute we walked in and were ignored by the hostess, were not offered a cocktail to having to send my main course back not once but twice because it was cold and then it was too salty to eat the whole experience was terrible. I will never eat at Frontera Grill again. Rick Bayless, what happened?!
On my plate a duck Tortilla, guacamole Genius, Bayless oh.  --a Frontera haiku As expected, everything excellent as I remember on my last visit 8 years ago. Huge fan, for the honesty of the plate.

Got there a bit after 5 so waited in line until they started seating at 5:30, but got a table right away. Intimidated by the nightly special of goat, so ordered the fish special and tacos. Not disappointed - the fish was wreck (Similar to swordfish) served over mashed potatoes. A tasty sauce but wasn't sure that it really should have been served over mashed potatoes. The chicken tacos were prepared well, and the sauce was flavorful and spicy. The pear-ginger margarita was a real standout! A great selection of margaritas and tequilas

So I've watched the Rick Bayless' tv show for years and thought how nice it would be to eat at one of his restaurants. Well check that box! I've had plenty of Mexican food, I live in Texas. We love the stuff. I'm happy to report I have found the best Mexican food I've ever had. Mole' enchiladas were outstanding. My wife got the skirt steak tacos, the skirt steak just melted in the mouth. The wait staff was great. Only one area for improvement--the hostesses seemed more interested in themselves than the customers. But with the rest of the experience, who cares! Next time I'm in Chicago, I'll be back.

I really wish I could remember everything we drank and ate but it was a post exam celebration, so I'm gonna have to go with feelings. We did not have a reservation and were quoted 1.5 hour wait for 4 people. That didn't stop us. Bar seating and bar area is first come first serve. We hovered and politely asked people who looked like they were getting their check if we could have their table. Scored a table within 15 minutes. Drinks. Phenomenal. Keep in mind I had already been drinking, so they must have been more than amazing if I can remember loving them. Food. To die. We got two types of the guacamole dishes and some kind of a taco dish. Beyond delicious. Beyond. I will have to go back next time I'm in Chicago and when I can remember to make a reservation weeks in advance... And when I'm sober.

It was just not all that.  Its like Mexican food, but done cleaner (read: less juicy) with different cuts of meat and/or things like duck, which sound good, but in taste, maybe not so effective.  Yes, the ingredients are sound, yes, you are not eating gristle, but the love seemed to be squeezed out of the food.  Maybe I'm spoiled by California and Southwest dishes, where taquerias are a dime a dozen with amazing offerings and 1/2 the price, but I was not overwhelmed.  I felt it was dumbed down Mexican food for the Midwest palate.  Four starts for the ambiance, fun atmosphere, service and drinks.  3 stars for the actual food, which left you hankering for more (spice, grease, something).

Went here for lunch with a reservation. I was surprised to see a pretty large line, but I did get a table as promised. Reservations are a must FYI. I really did not think this place would be even close to authentic Mexican food. I was wrong.  Okay now for the food. I had the some ceviche which was amazing. I find it real difficult to find a really good ceviche. Frontera hit the spot! Next was the chicken taquitos. That was also really good. It came with a good amount of guacamole, sour cream and salsa. It was amazing! I also ordered a cup of juice of the day, which I think tasted like cucumber and mango. I never would have  thought those two fruits would make a delicious combination.  The staff was solid.  Also, Rick Bayless was over seeing the kitchen for a couple minutes!

Arrived at 11:15am and the line was about 19 people deep once the door was open we were seated quickly ambience was nice waiters quick. I ordered from the street food category frontera trio everything was great I do have to says the puts a good twist on Mexican food. Price was a little in the high and portions small.

Came for dinner and drinks. Sat at the bar for both. Service was excellent and attentive, despite the bar being completely packed. Food was outstanding but portions are hipster small, so be prepared to order a few things. Several vegetarian options; I had the green corn tamales and a lovely peach cobbler for dessert. Chips and guacamole appetizer had about 1 tablespoon of guacamole, so I don't recommend it. Funky, trendy, hip atmosphere. Expensive if you have drinks or are really hungry!

Two words...A-mazing. Food was fabulous, service was impeccable. Rick was in the kitchen...making Mexican magic.   Had reservation, seated immediately on arrival.  Small size surprised me. I expected a larger space, it was full, but not really over crowded.    My wife had a margarita that really impressed  her.  I had my favorite Mexican beer on tap. (Negra Mondello)  Appetizer Trio was just OK, but Entrees made up for it.   I had the duck on rice with a fabulous mole. She had sea bass, that was enough for dinner and lunch the following day.  Deserts were each enough for two.  Overall the experience was wonderful and I highly recommend it.

This is Rick Bayless' restaurant.  Google him.  He's impressive!  So I expected Frontera to be equally impressive.  Alas, I was left somewhat disappointed. The wait for a table for 4 on a Saturday night was about an hour.  Not bad.  We got a nice table in the bar. The drinks were good.  Small, expensive, but tasty.  Plan for about $12 per drink.  They have a nice beer selection, including various Chicago and mid-west beers for a much more reasonable price. We ordered the guacamole, as well as the chips and salsa.  The chips were great.  The red salsa was slightly smokey, but otherwise pretty bland.  The salsa verde was better, but still not great.  The guacamole was incredibly bland.  Where is the heat?  I mean, seriously. Alright, this place is supposed to be all about the carne asada and the mole.  So, I got the mole trio and my friend got the carne.  The carne was good - tender and cooked well.  Quite nice.  The mole trio was...interesting.  The traditional mole was nice, but the other two were underwhelming.  Again, almost no heat. The chocolate pecan pie was great, however.  Probably the highlight of the meal, with a possible exception of the carne asada. My main gripe was the service.  Terrible!  20 minutes to get drinks.  More than an hour for the server to come back and ask if we wanted another round of drinks.  Want some additional chips for the guac or salsa?  Probably easier to run down to the 7-11 and get yourself a bag of Doritos.  It was a solid 15 minutes or more between visits from the server, and as much as 45 in some cases.  I'm all for not being constantly bugged, but that was ridiculous.   In summary, the food is amazingly bland for Mexican, over priced and the service is some of the worst I have ever had.  With so many other options in the city, you would do well to skip Frontera.

It's good for Mexican food in Chicago, but I had much higher expectations. My lovely wife has made many of Chef Bayless's recipes and they've always been amazing! I had the pork in black mole and it was just OK. I wonder if the flavors are toned down for Midwestern diners?

After seeing Rick Bayless on Top Chef, I was determined to visit Frontera Grill. We came in for drinks and appetizers. The ceviche was very good. It was very flavorful. It was a perfect pairing with my margarita. The margarita was a perfect blend of salty and sweet. I definitely recommend this place.

Fair experience.  Service was very poor.  Bar and clearing employees lack initiative and personality.   Chips and salsa were bland.  Sope con shredded beef was excellent.   I'm sure main dishes are great with flavor.   If employees had manners and personality I think this place would be a solid 4 stars.

Rick Bayless' flagship is definetly tough to get a spot but I would say it was worth it.  The food had unique and delicious flavor that is often missing.  Had the duck mole, side of beans,plantains, and cheese and a couple of margaritas and came away very happy.  Would absolutely come back looking to try other things.  Very happy with the duck but I feel like there is something amazing on the menu I might have missed.

The Skinny: went in for lunch and ordered the street food trio, tacos al carbon trio and the mole trio - all were okay but nothing special (3) service/ambience: it's okay - nothing special, the front desk needs to be better at communicating wait times (3) value: pricey for what it is.  I just want to get it out there before I review Frontera Grill.  I'll be honest. I've never been terribly impressed with high end Mexican restaurants. Coming from the Southwest where there are exceptional Mexican local (aka "hole in the wall") eateries for very reasonable prices, I am even more leery. But given that it was Rick Bayless with his renowned mole, I was willing to give it a shot. Ehhh... after this meal, definitely had better. We started off with the street food trio, shared the big wood grilled Tacos al carbon trio, and the mole trio. The street food trio was disappointing. The only good thing on the three was the sopes rancheros with the well seasoned meat and interesting fried texture of the masa boats. The rest were not memorable or flavorful at all. Kinda of disappointing for $17. The big wood grilled tacos al carbon trio comes with grilled steak, chicken and duck. Served with on a platter with a ton of green onions (I mean a ton!) and grilled shishito peppers, the large platter of meat was only served with a few small sized corn tortillas. Huh? WTF? I am not sure if we could ask for more but our server did not offer more at any time. The meat itself was okay - the chicken was a bit dry. The stand out was the steak with the slightly charred flavor. However was it the most flavorful meat ever? Not really. Added to the fact that the guacamole was really bland (mushed up avocado with some tomato without enough acidity makes this no es bueno) and it was served without salsa or even some cilantro/onion combo, this dish was rather disappointing and bland. For $34, there was plenty of food but it just wasn't that good. The Mole trio ($19) was also kind of a let down. The moles were kind of bland - I expected more a complex flavor profile but no... they were kind of boring. There was minimal heat, lack of aromatics and seasoning. The only one I liked out of the three was the green mole with Oaxacan green mole. The rest I could have done without.  Service wise, it was okay. Our server was pretty good about getting the orders right but kind of seemed overwhelmed with the number of tables. She didn't really check up on us regarding the food which was kind of disappointing considering the caliber of restaurant this place is supposed to be.  The host station in the front is kind of weird. We didn't have reservations but we checked in and was told that the wait times were 1 hour. They said that they would text us when the table was ready. We checked in about 45 minutes later before they could text us and we were immediately seated. Very odd. The biggest disappointment is that I've had really good Mexican before with great, bright, bold flavors. Tacos al pastor sliced fresh off a spit. Carne asada and lengua off a grill with warmed fresh tortillas. Complex salsas with different flavor profiles. This place just doesn't deliver at all. I would hate to think that people who come here after watching Rick Bayless' shows will think this is what real Mexican food is about. Because it isn't. And for that, this joint gets a 2 starred review.

The emperor has no clothes. We were told the wait for a two-person table would be an hour and a quarter. Turned out it was two hours. During that time we had some drinks and guacamole - the latter was very ordinary. After the two-hour wait, they gave us a lousy table in a barely decorated basement. The meal was a big, big disappointment. We shared the street food trio and I had Carne Asada. Neither one was anything special. Stay away!

Made reservations way ahead for this place. It's pretty hard to get a decent time any night! Luckily with my parents and uncle and aunt in town, we were okay with doing a later Thursday night dinner. We ordered a ton of food but I loved the guacamole (sooooo creamy - my dad said the and spooned it like a bowl of yogurt!), oysters, ceviche and steak. Oh, the margs are fantastic too and I don't love margaritas all the time - too tangy. Make reservations ahead of time! It's muy delicioso.

I was torn between a 4 and 5 star review, would probably choose 4.5 if that was an option.  We arrived at 5:00 on the dot and there was already quite a line - the line was for people with reservations to check in and also walk ins; same line. This would be frustrating to me if I did actually have reservations. We did not have reservations and knew we would have to wait a while since we were "walk ins". After being told that we would have a 90 minute wait, our group went to the bar to have some margaritas. The bar is pretty cool, especially once you get an actual seat. Great margaritas!  The chips were also good but you have to order and pay for them.  After 2 hours and 15 minutes (what?!?!) we were very hungry and more than ready to eat. The small restaurant was loud and hustling. No one came to acknowledge us after being seated for about ten minutes. This was kind of a bummer since we were so happy to finally be seated. Then we felt a little ignored.  The food was really good and the prices were not that bad at all. I think my expectations were pretty high and I don't know if the meal lived up to them or not. It may be that we were just so beyond hungry that we didn't have time to savor the food.... My biggest recommendation is to make a reservation. Frontera takes walk ins. Topolobampo does not. If you can't make a reservation, get there at 4:30. Frontera opens at 5:00.

Not happy!  We waited the expected amount of time (45 min), but the food just didn't have much flavor. We had Sopes rancheros, they forgot our chips and salsa, my husband has Oaxaca steak, I had shrimp with  three corn.  The portions were small for both of us and tasted bland.  We frequently use his sauces at home and they are so flavorful and good it inspired us to come to the  restaurant.  Oh, and $5 for a half cup of white rice with a pinch of cilantro on it is ridiculous! Maybe he should start using his store bought products, I don't know, for $70, no alcohol, poor service  (our server was forgetful, he forgot parts of our order and even us for a while), I just can't recommend this place. Sorry Mr. Bayliss, I think you are now just coasting.

Amazing food. I suggest their small plates for sharing. Everything was delicious.  Be aware: Their seating process was frustrating which is why they get 4 stars. The door said they open at 5 p. A women appeared with an iPad 15 minutes before 5 p and took names for seating. I was third in line. She was telling us that we would be seated at 5:20. I said the door says you open at 5 p. she said yes but we don't seat until 5:20??? Then if we wanted the main dining room I would have to wait until 5:30??? I said the resturant is empty why would we have to wait. Her reason was we don't seat everyone at once. We eat out a lot and I have never heard of a more screwed up seating system.

I've been so excited to eat at one of Rick Bayless's restaurants. The first night in Chicago we arrived at Topolobompo late around 9:30 and it was over an hour wait. We put in our name and went to find a spot at the bar at Frontera Grill. We decided to order our dinner at the bar, and immediately received a text that they had a table at Topolobompo. We decided to stay at the bar.  We ordered the 20 hour smoked brisket with mashed potatoes and vegetables; and Oaxan style Carne Asada made with Prime Steak served with plantains and black beans. I definitely liked the brisket more that the Carne Asada. The Carne Asada turned out to be a tougher piece of meat that we anticipated. The plantains were amazing. The margaritas were great!  Our bartender provided great service. I'm giving the overall experience 3 stars; and will mention the brisket, margaritas, and service was 4 stars; but the Carne Asada was a bit disappointing. Most of the menu items looked amazing, so I will want to go back and try more!

Everything was on point.  Presentation, service & cuisine....all were top notch. Huge fan of the sopes rancheros, tomato-melon salad & POC CHUC was crazy good! Many thanks to Carlos and his wonderful team(dessert chef of course!), amazing meal and night.

Over rated and over priced. For tabs over $200 per person, one should not have to stare at a blank wall with an exit sign during dinner! Food was excellent but not exceptional. The price was excessive!

Fun spot for lunch for my first Bayless experience.  Food: 3.5, Service: 4, Atmosphere: 4 Cost to worth it 3: ~$15 lunch simple entrees $~30 for others  Return worthiness: maybe Highlights: - Margaritas: not just your average versions. The topolo came in a martini glass and xoco was a refreshing cucumber one in a tall glass.   - Street trio: masa was awesome in flavor and texture, ranchero shredded beef was the best of the 3, and enchilada chile spiked masa stuffed with cheese was interesting and delicious. There was 2 of everything so you could easily share instead of have it all for one person's entree.  - Art: super colorful renditions on the wall Midlights: - Duck quesadilla: 2 big halves stuffed with duck carnitas which was a different twist. The hub didn't care for it but I thought it was fine.   Lowlights: - $3 chips and salsa: not so great. Preferred lots of other free versions in Cali better.  - Cold short rib in the trio waiter said it was supposed to be but I would've preferred it warm Cool place and I'd be up for trying xoco when there isn't a huge line.

Fans of Rick Bayless rejoice!! I was in Chicago on a business trip and couldn't wait to check out Frontera Grill. Growing ip watching his cooking shows has left me a Mexican food loving gal and so interested in the different ways Rick experiments with this  type of food. He is a household name and his restaurant is a delight. A word to the wise, they fill up quickly with reservations so call a few days early for big parties or if you are in a small group you can take a chance on one of their few tables available for walk ins. We took our chance around 6pm on a Tuesday and got a great table outside on the patio. My friend and I wanted to try a few items so we ordered 2 trios to split. The mole trio came with 2 mole poblano enchiladas with a nice dark and rich mole, my favorite of the three and then it came with two cute little bowls filled with a fresh green mole and fresh veggies and the other with pork in a tomato based Yucatecan pipian sauce. The green sauce was very tomatillo-ish and not exactly my favorite flavor but if you like tangy tomatillos this ones for you. The Yucatecan sauce was very mild and had a nice flavor with the pork. These two dishes came with a corn tortillas to put the pork and veggies in. We also ordered chips and salsa so that we could sop up the yummy guac that came with the taquitos and the tomato Yucatecan sauce, plus the chips came with 2 salsas a red and green that varied in smokiness and tanginess. For drinks we each ordered a beer, they have a fantastic list of tequilas and specialty cocktails calling my name but with out "street food" I just felt like a light beer and ordered a local saison infused with Meyer lemons, it was very refreshing! I also tasted the salted beer brewed with coriander... It was a little salty and so I passed but liked the idea. Now onto the best part--dessert!! OMG... We of course ordered two to share and i fell in love with the sweet corn ice cream served with corn tortas and caramel corn. I didn't like the tortas very much but the ice cream was amazing! I also ordered the raspberry sorbet with fresh raspberries and a mexican chocolate soup, it was served with an edible petunia and was very refreshing, a great end to a fantastic meal.
Had really good food with a lot of flavor. Tortilla soup was really good with great presentation. The street trio fell short with the empanada.

Me and my husband had been trying to come to Frontera Grill for almost a year. Surprisingly it seem to be closed all the time!! (Reason for giving them only 4 stars). After about 5 failed attempts we finally were able to get a reservation and it didn't disappoint. I have to say that the 'moles' were the star of the night, being Mexican believe me when I say I know my 'moles'. The place was packed and I really liked the atmosphere. However, for some reason everybody appeared to be in a rush.

Friday lunch 8/28/15: we read reviews and showed up early and the place was already packed.  Opened at 11:30 and were there by 11:50 and waited a few minutes for a table.  We were seated right in front of the kitchen door, yet no one brought us water, took our order or even acknowledged us for a solid 15 minutes. However, the wait was worth it.  Our server was nice once he came to the table.  The food was phenomenal!  The tuna ceviche in the trio, the guac and all the sauces are to die for!  Both trio meals and the fried plantains are a must-try!

I had always heard how great Frontera Grill is.    Well that was not my experience.  The first shock was how plain and small the restaurant is.  We were seated on time.   Our waiter was very good.  We ordered a few sampler plates and our waiter told us what each item was.   But no one could really hear him.  We also had the guac and chips and the blender had been left on too long.  We have better guac at Mescadito. My wife's chicken was the worst she has had in a long time.  Very tasteless.  The others myself included had good but not great food. I asked about dessert and was told the chocolate pecan pie has been on the menu for 27 years.  I ordered it and was very, very disappointed.  I could not find any pecans.    Overall I would not go back, there are far better restaurants, albeit less famous that Frontera Grill.

NOISY, OVERPRICED, WITH STAFF THAT DIDN'T SEEM TO CARE ABOUT MAKING CUSTOMERS HAPPY.   OK, so there's one hostess who was nice enough, but she wasn't personable AT ALL!  That's the first person you encounter, but there's so many folks going and coming at this place, it's difficult to keep that kindness going I guess.  For the price, I expect that that's not an issue however.   So the waiter takes a while to get over to get us started, though I'll admit he did say that he was trying his best to get over asap.  At one point we'd looked at the menu, closed it, and he came over to get my drink order.  I  had reopened the menu, and he just walked away...more important things to do I guess than realize I was ready to order.  We ordered the Ceviche Trio at $19...3 small cupfuls of 3 different ceviche's.  Did I know which was which?  Did the waiter offer to tell me?  You know the answers.  I will say that the ceviche's were very delicious.   Please allow me to back up.  This place is noisy...VERY NOISY!  Apparently we should have gone outside to the sidewalk patio but it was a chilly evening,  But there's another room which was quieter.  I guess we just missed the boat on that one. I ordered Katy's Sweet Corn Esquites under Street Food for Sharing.  Mr. Chef...please go to the Elote Cafe in Sedona AZ.  Try the Elote there...yum!  It wasn't awful.  It was just ok.  My g/f ordered Brazo De Reina, Frontera Style under Moles, Pipianes and Other Specialties.  Let's just say go with what you know, ok?  The consistence was pasty and flat, and the sauce wasn't anything special, although a tomato-habanero sauce doesn't seem that complicated.  May I suggest it as a dipping sauce, to cover up the taste of the tamal!

Now THIS is a restaurant! My first day in Chicago and my first restaurant experience in Chicago! The food was amazing and the prices were not geared to hurt a tourist's pocket. The drinks were excellent too! This chef / owner truly believes in sharing a beautiful culture with the masses without compromising on flavor and authenticity and shorting a patron's wallet. I fly standby, so my next trip again is Chicago and I'm headed to Frontera Grill again to try something new on the menu. Best restaurant I've eaten at in years and I'm a born and bred New Yorker! See you soon Frontera Grill!

Thought that this restaurant was going to be overrated because of the celebrity chef and was REALLY wrong. Started with the queso fundido.  I had to stop eating it just so I wouldn't be too full for my main course.  I had the  tacos al carbon with the skirt steak.  The skirt steak was tender,  flavorful and cooked just right.  The guacamole on the side was light and not spicy so the steak flavor stood out.  The corn tortillas were yummy. Service was really good.  Prompt and polite.  When the server brought me the main course, she noticed that I wasn't done with my appetizer and took my main course back.   I would give it 5 stars except for two small things: salsa was nondescript / dull. And the restaurant was extremely  loud.

Quality of food has gone down over the past few years and price has gone up. The service is beyond horrible - a member of my party had a full plate of chips and guac and was mid-bite when the busboy attempted to whisk her plate out from under her. To add insult to injury, the waiter spilled a full glass of water all over me, covering me with broken glass in the process, and barely apologized. We had to repeatedly ask him to bring napkins so I could wipe myself off, since he was mostly concerned with cleaning up the floor and table. They didn't offer to comp a round of drinks or dessert. Save your money and go to the one at the airport - this place is pathetic.

Sometimes you just luck out. We stopped by here without a reservation a few minutes before they closed for lunch. But we were warmly greeted and immediately seated. And YUM! Obviously, there are lots of reviews here so we're not saying much new, but loved everything we got. From the mixed drinks, to the chips, to the dishes. Service was prompt, water refilled, and even though we were on the late side, we never felt rushed. We enjoyed the tacos which don't look like a lot, but really were fabulous.  Just a great simple Mexican meal.  As I said, YUM!!!!

Came in for lunch with a reservation for group of 7. Unfortunately, was super loud and hard to hear. Seated in the middle of the restaurant which was not so awesome. Drinks were creative and yummy. Kids menu and crayons were a bonus for my 4 year old. I had a creative veggie dish with corn, pumpkin seeds and spinach. Heavy, but just the right amount to feel full for a veggie dish.
