Server was a bit 'too' knowledgeable.. attentive but a bit overindulgent in the descriptions and detail. However, we saw RICK behind the bar.. BIG BONUS! I recommend however, be prepared for a lively atmosphere.

Went here last month on a Saturday night about 7. Don't ask me how I got so lucky, but a friend and I were seated immediately even though the place was busy. I was seated near the bar area, which has a really cool atmosphere. Had the Mexico City style quesadillas for an appetizer. They're actually small, almost bite size and come with guacamole. Never had anything like them, but they were heavenly. Main course was duck in Yucatecan pipian. Really outstanding dish, and the pipian sauce, which is derived from pumpkin seeds, really set it off. This place lives up to its reputation as one of the best Mexican restaurants in America, and it won't break the bank, either. A must experience if you're in Chicago.

My husband and I are obsessed with Rick Bayless and we made sure to grab lunch here during our weekend trip to Chicago. The staff is wonderful and the ambiance is fun. I ordered a blackberry basil margarita and my husband ordered the tequila old fashioned. My drink was awesome - not too sweet, perfectly balanced. We ordered the guacamole and sikil pak. The sikil pak is a must try! We also ordered the street food trio and mole trio. The mole trio had a potato dish on it that was one of my favorite things we tried. I preferred the empanadas and sopes rancheros on the street food trio - so perfectly executed and delicious. We had a peach cobbler for dessert which was also wonderful. Overall, such a great experience and hoping that next time we are back we can snag a dinner reservation at Topolo.

We've been big fans of Rick Bayless for years and Frontera Grill was on our Top 5 "Must See" places for our trip to Chicago. To start off, the place has no parking (which is common for Downtown), but it has an extremely convenient Valet for only $14 plus tip.  Also, unless you want to eat outside, you'll want to set up reservations at least four days in advance or you'll end up waiting 1-2 hours.   The hostesses were professional, but not overly friendly.  Our waiter was ok, but we've had better.  The busboy (who was extremely friendly and efficient) actually did most of the work and we would have preferred just having him take our orders too. The bathroom was so small that there was only enough room for two stalls.  Every time someone entered the bathroom, the door would hit the back of the person using the urinal or completely take out someone washing their hands. The food was tasty, but the portions are extremely small for the price.  We wanted to like the place and give it a higher rating, but we've had much better food in the bordering states and in Mexico for a fraction of the cost (everything was about ten times what we normally pay for similar dishes).  Plus, $35 for a margarita is just plain silly (even if they shake it at the table).  We think that this place really caters to patrons that have never experienced authentic Mexican food and just want to try some "safe" versions.   We are torn about the rating for this place.  We go back and forth between 2 and 3 stars.  We've had better food at better prices, so it goes into the 2 category.  However, we feel that it deserves an extra star for taking a new approach to Mexican food (even if its just making smaller portions and putting micro greens on top).  It was a fun novelty, but we would never return and have no interest in trying his other establishments.  We'll just stick to watching him on TV.

We were looking so forward to Frontera Grill. There was an hour wait for the dining room but bar was first come first serve. We found a table right away and sat down. We started to notice later diners were getting greeted while we sat unattended. 15 minutes went by and we finally tapped a server for help - he said he would return shortly. 5 more minutes, finally my friend grabbed a bag of skinny pop we had just gotten from an event (it was 9PM we were starving!). At some point the finished bag slipped from the table onto the floor. Within seconds the manager was over with a snarky "is this your skinny pop on the floor?" I responded with "so you'll jump over tables to snag a popcorn bag but haven't noticed we have sat here for 20+ minutes without being greeted? Real nice." We ende dup ordering $150 worth of small plate dishes - which were mediocre at best.  I think the brand has lost its touch. It is so over saturated wtih making grocery store ready salsa it has forgotten how to treat a paying customer. I don't care how many airport express venues you have - Chili's does (or did?), too - ha!
The best Mexican cuisine you can find in Chicagoland area!!!!!!! Carne asada is very incredible!!! I also recommend trying the Mexico City quesadillas and the Oaxacan margaritas also!!!!

If you want great, inventive and fresh Mexican cuisine run to Frontera Grill. Rick Bayless keeps this place relevant and the quality great, which is why there's always a wait (they don't take reservations). Their guacamole is fantastic as are the tamales (when available). To avoid the wait, try to get there as early as possible (~5:00p?) or definitely before 6:00p if you don't want to wait an hour or more. Regardless, Frontera Grill is definitely worth the wait.

Great coffee.  Authentic cuisine. Affordable prices. Nice portions. Great service. Had to wait at the bar for 30 min, had some coffee and guacamole.  Once seated outside, we ordered two amazing dishes.  They don't serve any tacos, burritos, etc.   not your typical Mexican establishment.  Lots of unique tequila drinks but a bit pricey.

10 years ago I would have given this place 5+ stars.  At the time it may have been the best restaurant I had ever been to.  I'm not sure if I'm older and wiser now and have just experienced more fine dining since then or if it's just not as good there anymore but I was sadly disappointed on my return visit.  Don't get me wrong...it's still good, just not excellent.  The margaritas were tasty but overpriced for the amount of alcohol.  These days, it's not tough to find a high quality margarita.  Same goes for the guacamole...good, but doesn't really stand out. I may have ordered wrong this time but I got one of the street food trios and it was just ok.  The food was luke warm and just not all that special.  On top of that, the serving was very small.  I spent $70 for one person and left not all that full.  It was surprising to see that people still wait in long lines to go there given the food explosion in Chicago.

Had brunch here on a Saturday morning.  The service was great and the food was authentic.  Portions were a bit small and the flavors were okay but not excellent.  It was a good place to try but nothing to write home about

Great meal and strong drinks! What more can a girl ask for!?! We had the Ceviche Trio, Frontera Guacamole, and Big Wood-Grilled Tacos Al Carbon Trio.  We wanted to try as much as possible!  to drink, we had the Blue Agave and blackberry basil margaritas. Keep it classic and go with the blue agave.  The blackberry is fine...until you have the blue agave! The service at the bar was excellent! We'll definitely be back!

Don't see what the hypes about. Crappy smelly Mexican food. Ruined my grandparents first time experience for Mexican food. The worst mole and tamales I have ever tasted. Sorry not worth my money or time.

You're better off going to Taco Bell than this place. The waiters are rude and would rather chat with their friends or text on their phones than serve you. They will bring the food out cold and undercooked and the manager is incredibly condescending. Save yourself the money and go elsewhere. Anywhere else

This place didn't quite live up to the hype for me. We tried a few different sampler plates, and everything was good, but nothing was amazing, and for the price I wanted amazing. The drinks were fantastic though.
Food: 5 Decor: 3 Ambiance: 4 Service: 5 Value: 4.5 One of the best and authentic Mexican meals you can have. Delicious from the chips through the dessert.

I had high hopes for this restaurant but it turned out to be really disappointing. I made reservations many weeks in advance. The room was so noisy I could not hear my own thoughts, let alone my friend's voice. The black beans were dry. The fresh corn tortillas, mole enchiladas, margarita and tamales were okay, but not exceptional. The table was sticky and I was there during the first dinner service. After a few bites of each dish/drink, we asked for the check, then went somewhere else for dinner. The wait staff were very friendly and attentive and are the reason for giving Frontera 1 star.
The Saturday Special: ribs and grits, can't go wrong!  Also enjoyed the garlicky black beans, white rice and plantains with cheese. Adventurous!

Our party of 4 were in Chicago for vacation. We wanted to try out the restaurant even though reservations are not taken. We got there for an early dinner around 530. The hostess told us the wait was 45 minutes. Based on that information we decided to wait at the bar. After 30 minutes, I checked in with the hostess again and she told me the wait was now 2 hours. Apparently, you have to give her a gift to get seated. We spent $50 dollars at the bar which we would have never spent if we knew the wait was that long. We left and felt duped.
Nom nom!!! So many great flavors and options!  Even for vegetarians and fish eaters!! Check out the side dishes for some nummy small dishes.

One of the best mexican restaurants in the River North area. Rick Bayless does an excellent job mixing unique yet authentic flavors into his food. Simply delicious! I really enjoyed the family dining setting. Cocktails are amazing.

We stopped by Frontera Grill at about 12:30pm on a Saturday and were told that the wait for two people would be about 45 minutes, but it was only about 30 minutes until we were seated at a nice table on the patio. The weekend brunch menu had a good mix of breakfast options and lunch fare. All of our food was excellent -- including the guacamole, jicama salad, eggs a la Mexicana, and catfish tacos. The service didn't match the price point and quality of the food, but everything was so delicious that I will definitely be back the next time I'm in Chicago.
Fabulous margarita, ceviche and dessert with the best service. I enjoyed sitting outside and still getting great service.

I really wanted to like this place. Service was terrible, and I'm not very picky but our server was not attentive. The busser was great, he refilled my water like a thousand times. The guac was fantastic. I'll give them that. The margarita I ordered was very good. The food had great flavor, but mine was cold. The beans were cold to the point they started to glaze over and chunk up. Really........ even a quick microwave could have fixed it. Unfortunately at this point, I had been waiting so long for the food I could have cared less and just dealt with it. Two of my friends tried the Street trio, thinking it would be enough for a meal. It is not...  Very small portion size for that, granted it is listed as food for sharing. Overall:  Overpriced, good flavors, terrible service. Gimmicky. There's better mexican food in Chicago, for sure.
Four enthusiastic stars. Tortilla soup was too salty. But everything else, including the duck, was delicious. Fun and festive/colorful vibe in the place.

Excellent! This restaurant is Rick Bayless street Mexican food. Had chicken taquitos, duck carnitas, and the house margarita which was infused with cucumber was refreshing!!!! It's busy and can be loud, make sure to reserve a table!

Came into Frontera while visiting Chicago. The food was pretty good. The wait could get pretty bad but we got lucky the day we went which was a Saturday. We sat in the main dining room which was decorated nicely. The bar was also pretty nice. Food is a tad over priced but not bad at all.

Service commendable, food good...just good. Green salsa is very tart, takes a special palate. Red salsa was a nice chipotle blend. Will say the short rib tamal was fantastic, my favorite tamale by far! Tacos were meeh. Would have loved an actual spicy and tender pork as described on the menu. Not a desert lover, had the vanilla ice cream with Mexican caramel, delicious! I could eat that caramel sauce for days. Will go back, but get a better recommendation as far as menu choices are concerned.

Frontera is one of my favorite restaurants - anywhere. Some people claim it's touristy, but I am a life-long Chicagoan and visit as often as possible. Always a delicious experience.  This is real Mexican cuisine, prepared responsibly. Try the queso fundido. Server told us once that the cheesemaker delivered that day, in person. Can't get much more local than that.

This is definitely a very good place for mexican food. We had several appetizers and I was full enough that I just got tortilla soup for my entree (which was very good).  I wasn't completely blown away, but we had a good meal with good drinks and I'm glad we visited!

I've been wanting to try Frontera Grill for ages, as I'm a big fan of Rick Bayless. We decided to go around opening time for brunch, sans reservation. MISTAKE! We got there 15 minutes after opening and there was already a line out the door. Bummer. While my bf waited in line i scoped out the bar area and asked the waiter if the tables there were 'first come first serve', which they were! So i grabbed a four top and felt like a genius! The service was a little slow, but our waiter was very nice and accommodating. The drinks and food were all delicious. Definitely a higher end experience (ie not tex mex sized portions), but the quality of the food was top notch and I didnt leave feeling too full! Good for me.

Frontera is good, but overpriced. You have to make a reservation or the wait is absurdly long. The atmosphere is nice, the food is good. But it's not worth the premium that you're paying. I enjoyed a lot of the flavors but felt like I could get the same food for a lot cheaper.  That being said, it is good for lunch and during Chicago Restaurant Week specials. It's a good environment and the food is yummy.

My husband had been here years ago, and raved about the food.  We were both very excited about eating here, but we both left disappointed.  We started off with the oysters and ceviche platter.  The oysters were fresh and we enjoyed them.  The ceviche was decent as well.  The tuna cocktail really could have benefited from a pop of citrus.  Next we had the short rib tamal.  The masa was very fresh, but the tomatoes tasted canned and hadn't been cooked out enough to get rid of the tin can flavor.  The short rib inside was good though.  For an entree, I had the halibut in the green mole, and my husband had the mole trio.  My halibut was not fresh at all, and the mole was separating and had no flavor at all. The accompanying squash blossom tortitas were delicious. I ended up sending the dish back because of the quality of the fish.  I just didn't feel safe eating it.  My husband enjoyed the red mole enchilada, but didn't like the other two.  The drinks here are fantastic though.  Overall, we had better food at Xoco next door.

I was expecting more from this place.  The food was ok, nothing memorable, but the service really threw me off.  Not sure if it was because we were having lunch or what, but our server ignored us for the most part. Maybe we order the wrong thing, but oh well, there are too many great restaurants in Chicago to waste my time here.  I live in Houston, and I can find better Mexican food for half the price.  Very disappointing.

Started with the Paloma Oaxaquenya, an outstanding drink: not at all sweet, but very fresh fruit, and just enough kick to add flavor without overpowering.  The ceviche Yucatena was very fresh and tender. Good balance, not overdoing it. Similar flavors as the drink, so they pair well. The accompanying tortilla chips are house made and better than any I've ever had. Super crisp.  The Cochinita Pibil is insanely tender: seems like that pork was slow cooked for two days. Some interesting earthy flavors, almost like a light mole. Tomatillo spicy sauce is great. Pickled onions are a great foil and the black beans are out of this world, so fresh. I just had black beans from a decent takeout place in NY and they are terrible compared to Frontera. The dish was just a touch salty, but given how the portion was huge and delicious, I'll still say five stars.

Always good food at the Bayless spots. This one is no different, but it has slightly dated decor. The staff is friendly, the drinks are good. I came for brunch, sat right down at the bar. The hotcakes were okay (got a side), the egg dish I got was very good. The kitchen had some issues so the bartender offered me some freebies, and they took most of the food off my bill. It was very nice of them, I left him a big tip.

I have never been disappointed here. The price is good and you always get plenty to eat.  I love the smothered burrito with onions.  The service has always been good.  If you are in the mood for Mexican try it out.

Got there at 11:30am and there was already a line, but luckily we made reservations. We had the Yucatecan ceviche (shrimp and calamari), short rib tamal, and the Oaxacan carne asada. The carne asada was incredible. Perfectly cooked and very flavorful. The short rib was also very good. The ceviche was okay. The ceviche at his Red O restaurant in Melrose is better.

First dinner in Chicago. Really wanted to try Rick Bayless's food. The drinks were very tasty and whimsical. We ordered trio of ceviches (yum), duck with sweet mash potatoes, and short rib masa cake. Everything was fresh and delicious. Highly recommend

If you're looking for the closest thing to a high-quality, authentic, home-style meal but in a classy setting with gourmet flair: come here. Rick Bayless does NOT disappoint in covering regional mexican food. Michoacán native approved. -agua fresca de pepina y limón (refreshing drink made w cucumber and lime) - ceviche yucateco -flavorrr city shrimp and squid - pollo huitlacoche: tender chicken in a smokey and earthy delicate sauce - Carne asada brava: juicy tender perfect charred meat. -Enchiladas poblanas were delicious, the salsa was impeccable. -Chocolate dessert- i can't recall the name and it's off the menu now but This was the best dessert I've ever had in my life, it's had a lasting impression on my life, even over a year later.

We tried to go here last night around 7:30 and was happy to see a few open tables inside and out with no line or people waiting but then the hostess told us there was an hour and 45 minute wait for a table for 3. I guess we needed to make a reservation? Or they really aren't kid friendly. Either way we were disappointed.

The best Tamales....always a gastronomic delight Rick Bayless! Enjoyed all the dishes except the dessert, it was a flakey biscuit with stawberries and cream not upto the mark. I enjoy coming back atleast once year.  Please be warned about the habenero salsa its so good will make u see the STARS!!!

Well, I didn't think it would happen but I'm writing a bad review AND it isn't about the food...which usually drives me crazy.   I walked in excited to be there and said to the hostess that I was looking for a table for two, and that my cousin was in from out of town and we were looking forward to dining.  I am a friendly guy, so this is just how I act. She responded with "Oh, sure...like I haven't heard that one before.  It is an hour wait with or without your cousin (said sarcastically)".   My cousin really was in, from Sweden...and we had a great meal elsewhere.  This is Chicago, there are tons of great restaurants.  This is NOT New York, we like nice people here. To the hostess who has as attitude....my cousin says she will not be nice to you if you are ever in Sweden...and Swedish people are ALWAYS nice!  So there.

Did not have reservations however, we were greeted and seated immediately.  They were very busy and the staff was very nice and patient.  The Tortilla Soup was INCREDIBLE!!!   Quesadillas were not the traditional ones I am used to but were still good.  We also had the Tacos Al Carbon with skirt steak everything was cooked to perfection.  Very impressed.  Will absolutely visit again.

Went with a group of 8.  Service was quite slow.  Food was good but nothing outstanding.  The thing that stuck out most to me was the volume of this place.  It was extremely loud.  I could barely carry on a conversation with the person next to me.  There was music overhead that was not just super loud but the place was full and the floor is smooth, the walls are smooth and for some reason it was just very loud and not conducive to conversation.

The Frontera Grill experience really lives up to the hype. I am a pretty picky eater, but Frontera still had a ton of things on their menu that looked appetizing. I would absolutely go back to Frontera the next time I'm in Chicago. Their food tasted fresh and was well prepared. The restaurant was packed the night we went so the service was perhaps a little slower than usual, but certainly wasn't slow to the point of concern. The manager on duty even came by our table to make sure we were enjoying our experience. Can't wait to go back and try something different!

The hype is real, believe it! I'm not even a huge fan of Mexican cuisine, but what Rick Bayless does in the kitchen is magic. The sopas rancheros and the chicken tortilla soup are out of this world and the taquitos were also very good. Service was great, helpful in recommendations and very friendly. At this price point, the value is incredible. Can't wait to go back next time I'm in town.

Pros: Inexpensive, great environment, nearby (but expensive) parking garages. Great apps, great desserts, great staff. Cons: some menu items that feature cilantro as a main ingredient do NOT mention it on the menu. Being that a LOT of people can't eat cilantro (like me), this doesn't jibe well. I got the Chicken & Asparagus Crema, and wasn't expecting Cilantro to be one of the main ingredients since it wasn't mentioned ANYWHERE in the description of the item. I was unpleasantly surprised at the familiar and dreaded soapiness of the cilantro and couldn't eat most of my entree. I was, however, very happy with the braised beef tamal, the sopes rancheros, and the flan duo that my boyfriend and I shared. Overall I would be happy to come back- but please, please PLEASE remember that a lot of anti-cilantro people exist and try to be a little more forthcoming with your cilantro related items. I know it's a mexican restaurant, but this is one of the only ones i've ever seen that doesn't mention their use of cilantro anywhere.

Frontera was such a great experience. I love Mexican food, and I was amazed that I could actually be surprised from a Mexican meal.  The cocktails were top-notch, and the bartender was very knowledgeable. I'm not usually a tequila drinker, but I couldn't resist a second Tequila Old-Fashioned. Then there was the food - we had oysters and a sampling of ceviche to start. You could tell the ingredients were fresh. The we got an assortment of small plates until we couldn't handle anymore. Pork, queso, a mushroom dish, and on and on. We will absolutely be back, because we only tried about half of the items that looked good on the menu.   As an aside... we got there right when the restaurant opened. The manger was dealing with a difficult customer and I was very impressed with how he handled the situation. I don't know exactly what transpired to lead up to the event, but the customer was loud, very rude and didn't want to leave, but the manager diffused the situation quickly and got him out the door without causing a scene. Very professional, and a solid indication of the way they run things.
Another foodie's bucketlist item. The chicken in huitlacoche sauce was delicious but a little oily. The presentation was excellent.

My husband and I make a point of coming to Frontera every time we stay overnight in Chicago and have for fifteen years. There may be the slightest hint now of 'resting on their laurels', but in all those meals, weekday and weeknight, weekend brunch and lunch and dinner, we've never had a bad dish. Or a bad drink. My favorites are the street food and old school(?) trios: basically samplers of (yes, three) different dishes. And the 'gold margarita', now gone alas. Topolobampo is the attached restaurant, a bit more upscale; I've only been once so can't really address that. Dinner can be busy, especially on weekends! but we've come for lunch for the past few years, and that works. A little quieter, a bit more likely to get seated immediately.

Stopped into the bar for lunch.  The service was prompt and knowledgeable.   I tried three mole sauces, each unique and good.  The place is more authentic in taste and in atmosphere than some of the nearby competition. I counted 160 varieties of tequila and/or mezcals, dominating in that category.

I had an amazing experience. Everything was beautifully presented and so flavorful. I had a private dinning menu and our group was so impressed with the flavor. This meal was not your typical Mexican fare. What a culinary treat. A must stop when in Chicago.

Neat concept having 3 restaurants in a  row all with a different vibe and price point. We made lunch reservations here on a friday and it was definitely busy. The atmosphere is very simple and understated which I appreciated because the focus is on the food.  We had some delicious margaritas, chips, guacamole, and salsa to start which really kicked things off nicely. Between the group of 4 we had tortilla soup, and several different moles - all delicious (the pork being our favorite). The tortilla soup was also amazing.  For a "famous person's restaurant" this place was totally attainable, comfortable, and homey. Our server was AMAZING and really brought everything together nicely.
Food is superb: delicious and authentic with a modern twist. Waiting time is not as horrible as people say!

Another celebrity chef owned restaurant disappointment. I understand why Chuy was booted from Top Chef so quickly. Food is so so, guess they never heard of seasoning. The service was rude and super slow. If it wasn't for Chef Bayless tv shows, this place would be a Starbucks. I really wanted to like this place.

Definitely make a reservation - this place gets packed, even at lunch. I had the street food trio, all of which were great. The sopes rancheros were especially great. The tropical tuna cocktail had a great presentation and the soup was apparently also quite good. Portions were not extremely large - a great spot for healthier or lighter eaters.

Flawless mexican food. Everything was uber tasty: duck and chicken tacos with cebollitas, sampler ceviche. Even our drinks were exceptional. We had lunch since the wait for dinner is absurd, totally worth it.

We were approached by a host that asked us which restaurant we had a reservation at?  To be honest I still don't understand where the other restaurant is but ok.  He placed us in a table close to the bar.  The atmosphere was loud and lively and just one of the millions of reasons I love anything Mexican inspired.  They were really busy and I was instantly happy I had made reservations! Our waiter approached and suggested some margaritas (which we loved)!  We also order a version of con queso it was much better than any other queso I have ever eaten.  We both had an enchilada dish for our meal.  The entire experience was so yummy!

My friend number one restaurant in her list was this place because someone told her it had a Michelin star. We went on our first night in Chicago and I have to say it was good but in my opinion not to have a Michelin star. I order the tacos with an asparagus cream light and fresh but my favorite part of the meal was the raspberry basil margarita. I would need to give it another chance to see if in my opinion deserves a Michelin star.

There's probably not a great deal that I need to say about this wonderful, well-established gem in Chicago, but I'll say it anyway: loved Frontera Grill. Couldn't get a reservation so we showed up early and pounced on a cafe table at the bar.  The table wasn't large enough to accommodate larger plates so we stuck to the small plates and street food. Everything was delicious, from the agave margaritas to the black mole enchiladas, pinto beans, plantains, queso fundido al pastor, sopes...I don't think there was a miss in any of the 8 plates we tried (except perhaps the flan - somewhat superfluous).  Great, great place for all the right reasons. Thanks for a wonderful evening to all.

If you love Mexican food - this is truly a-mazing! Hands down to a wonderful restaurant! Make reservations (unless you want a 1-2 hour wait). Frontera provided fantastic service and most excellent dishes! Expect to put a little dent in your wallet as this isn't low-fare dining.  I had no complaints of any of the dishes our table of four ordered - some for sharing and some for our own dishes (this is a great place to order a bunch of dishes to share with a group so get to try a bunch of things).  Yum to all theses dishes: -Tropical Tuna Cocktail - Classic Queso Fondido - Black Mole Enchiladas - Chorizo Black Bean Empanadas - Fresh Corn Tamales *The last three dishes were shared between two people and the top two dishes were shared between 4 people. We all left full and loving each bite of food at Frontera. Highly recommend this restaurant!
Upscale Mexican that does not disappoint!  Went with a group and split  small plates and two entrees. The steak and chicken were amazing. The guacamole is a must!
Rick Bayless is not even Mexican. Why would I wait two hours after being in line for half an hour? I watch PBS.  I can make this crap myself.

The menu is always changing and it makes for a very fun dining experience every time. The fish here is the best. There is an amazing smokey flavor on every fish dish that is so addicting. Get the fish! Any fish! Love it.

Oh, so this is what Mexican food is supposed to taste like. @Frontera_Grill @Rick_Bayless #chicagorestaurants Husband asked why I chose a Mexican restaurant when we're from LA. I chose it because of Rick Bayless / Top Chef. I hadn't expected to have a transformative experience, but this meal truly changed my perception of Mexican food.  I typically request no cream or cheese and opt for vegetarian, because Mexican food in LA is overloaded with grease and super heavy. Chef Richard explained that's not how they make food at Frontera. All of the ingredients are fresh and locally sourced. They make their own corn masa, tortillas, salsas. The food is delightfully fresh and surprisingly light.  Menu changes monthly to reflect seasonal ingredients. The cocktails are fantastic. I loved my grapefruit mezcal cocktail and my husband's homemade gin & tonic was fantastic. They also have local craft beers.  Trio of street tacos was a great way to try a few different food items. Also really enjoyed our mushroom enchiladas.  Go and say hello to Chef Richard James. He's so nice and very knowledgable.  Highly recommend!

I had a wonderful brunch here this past week. I'd been itching to try Rick Bayless's mole sauce and it did not disappoint. It was complex, sweet and not overly bitter, though I will say I wish it came with something aside from fairly boring black beans which washed out the entire dish in black, and the pork was somewhat dry. I enjoy the Hettema Street snack with slices of pineapple and cucumber. And the grapefruit Mezcal cocktail is one of the best I've had in a while.  The guacs were refreshing and flavorful. The pork and pineapple tacos are fabulous one of the best dishes on the table. The homemade tortillas or tender and flavorful, really a stand out.  Really glad we came though the service was laughably slow.  The waiter disappeared after taking each individual item order. As in, he would take an order for coffee, disappear for a minute, before returning to the table to see if anyone else want coffee, repeating for each guest.  That said, the service was friendly.

While the food was interesting, well-cooked, and tasty, it didn't reach the expectations for  a restaurant with this much hype. To get reservations on Saturday night, you need to reserve one or two months in advance -- and I just don't understand why. Nevertheless, the night did have a grandiose moment: I was lucky to meet Rick Bayless at the restaurant and ask for a picture. Guess he drops by here and there sometimes. Very friendly guy. Definitely the better Bayless brother. On to the food...  Mole Trio: 3.5/5 -- The trio was the following: (1) veggies and potatoes, (2) enchilada, and (3) pork. Loved the pork but found the other two underwhelming.  Duck Tamal: 4/5 -- Very flavorful but not a huge fan of the tangy sauce. The duck was excellent though.  Mexico City-Style Quesadilla: 4.5/5 -- The guacamole was a perfect complement to a dish that looked more like several empanadas than several quesadillas.  Smoked Chicken Taquitos: 5/5 -- Possibly the best dish of the night. Everything just went so well together: the guacamole, the salsa, the cream. It's hard to go wrong with taquitos, but it's equally hard to be this good as well.  I now regret not trying to the flan (apparently amazing). There just seems so much to try! I will definitely be back!

I have been to frontera, topolobambo and xoco multiple times; all the appetizers, entrees desserts have been absolutely amazing.   In topo you can order a 3, 5 or 7 course meal, the courses are big; well deserved michelin star, when are they going to give frontera one? The food quality is the same in frontera, the atmosphere is festive and I really like that you can hang out and they are not rushing you to get out of there even when they are busy, if you can't get a reservation get there put your name down and go for a drink there or around the street, it always works out well.  Overall, frontera is my personal favorite restaurant in Chicago!

Frontera has a good reputation, and rightfully so; its a great upscale place if you're trying to impress or are generally stuck downtown. Its a little hard to justify (especially given the price) when there are sooo many great places in Pilsen, a short uber (or CTA) ride away but  you're looking at reviews for Frontera so that's not really on your agenda so just go and have a cocktail and some really great Mexican.

The best Mexican I have ever had wonderful guacamole, oysters the absolute best black mole I have ever had. Amazing pickled peppers. Rarely can a place live up to the hype. Frontera was even better!!!

I'm not sure what all the hubbub is about.  Typical trendy over priced Chicago restaurant with bartenders driving the cost up by spilling expensive tequila performing showy long pours!  They need some sort of bad pour collection system behind the bar.  Rick could supply one of his other restaurants with a hodgepodge of tequila from all the pours gone bad.  It depresses me to see all that good clear gold go to waste.   I was ready to call the police. My shrimp mole dish was good but sure not worth $25.  My chip appetizer were some of thickest, oily chips I have ever eaten.  Pretty bad in my opinion.  The salsa's they were served with were mighty fine but also barely there.  I found it very difficult to dip the chip in the size bowl they presented in.  Pouring them on the chip was a more appropriate method. Hate to say it Rick.  A wasted night in Chicago that I don't get many of...
So yummy!  Agave margarita was awesome...suckling pig and garlic chicken are outstanding!  Guacamole is amazing...friendly and quick service...
Absolutely awesome tequila and mescal list. The food is pretty impressive too. We were all impressed with both the quality of the portions and the size. Reservations are essential.

Had friends in from Mexico City so we took them around the town before dining at Frontera. While the city never fails to impress, our restaurant choice proved to be a letdown given our expectations. The Good:  Our server was fantastic. The salsa & chips were tasty but the serving size is small. I guess they don't want you to get too full on the appetizers. The margaritas were great. The Chicken in Green Garlic entree was delicious. The Bad: Three of our four entrees were disappointing. The Carne Asada Brava was over-spiced, something seemed wrong with the marinating and the flank steak was unacceptably tough.  The Striped Bass was overcooked and mushy and it wasn't served warm. Bad. The accompanying mushrooms tasted good and became the main focus of the plate. The Duck in Mole was also on the cold side. The taste was dominated by the chiles instead of being a well-combined set of flavors. We planned on having dessert but after the entrees we opted to go elsewhere. It was crowded and beggars can't be choosers so we accepted a table that was a real squeeze and too close to others to be comfortable, a bad feature of many of their tables. Overall: Underwhelming kind of sums it up.
It's pretty amazing.  I've been there so many times and it never gets old.  The food is spectacular and the service is amazing.  I love this place and want to marry it.

Came here for a weekday lunch and was impressed!  Great food, good service, and central location. I loved my goat enchiladas - they were super flavorful!  My dining companion really liked her tortilla soup and "street food" dish. The service was prompt  and friendly, which was great given how bustling the place was on a Tuesday afternoon. I was staying at the Aloft Chicago City Center, and this place was just a block away. Perfect place for lunch!

So good!!! Our waiter, Alber, was fantastic. Everything was great and we shared 4 different dishes (including a Street Car Trio). Must have the chicken/rice/asparagus dish. Can't remember the name. Can't go wrong with anything though. Make sure to start off with a handcrafted margarita! No room for dessert today!

Food very tasty.  Restaurant way too noisy it is difficult to have a conversation.  Extremely expensive and overpriced.  Waiter also has a bit of an attitude.  Difficult to talk to. Be careful about ordering any sides.  A minuscule bowl of rice is 5 1/2 dollars.  Other sides are overpriced.  But the food was interesting and tasty.

We lucked into finding this place from a guest we met at the hotel.  We then lucked into finding a seat at the bar because the restaurant had an hour and 1/2 wait.  Best high tech Mexican food I've ever had.  We had the pork tamales, chicken tacitos, and deep fried quesadillas--not to mention three of the yummiest margaritas I've had. Definitely a place to return to.

Oh Frontera. I was hoping I would like Frontera because of all the raves on tv and having to make a reservation to ensure getting a seat quickly but I was not impressed at all.  We got there two minutes after they opened and there was already a line so good thing we had a reservation. Our server was great. He was really friendly and fixed our rocking table.  We ordered the Just made tortilla chips which came with two different salsas. It was good. They also had a bottle of red chili pepper sauce on the table it was delicious!  My bf ordered the steak tacos sans guacamole and a side of plantains which we didn't get charged for since the server just substituted the plantains for the guac which was very nice of him. The bf said the tacos were OK. He doesn't eat beans so I was going to eat them but they were incredibly salty. I couldn't eat them. They were just too salty. The plantains were perfect! They weren't burnt or mushy, just perfect!  I ordered the chilaquiles with tomatillo sauce and scrambled eggs and a side of corn pancakes.I didn't actually know what chilaquiles were when I ordered it but I'll never order it again. It's kind of weird to eat soggy tortillas. The common thing with the dishes at Frontera is saltiness. If my chilaquiles weren't so darn salty I would have ate more of it. My eggs were salty because they soaked up the salty tomatillo sauce. The corn pancakes were salty too even with syrup on them.  The meals were typical restaurant prices otherwise I would have been really upset about my visit. The cost is the only reason I'll come back and try another meal when I'm in Chicago again.  The only thing I can say I really enjoyed here were the plantains.  You'll get one more try Frontera.

Tried to make reservations here for a Thursday night but couldn't.  So a couple of friends and I tried to do a walk in instead.  We were told the wait would be an hour and a half.  Luckily we were able to find seats at the bar within 20 minutes.   This place reminds me so much of The Mission in Scottsdale.  We asked the bartender for his recommendations and ordered each one of them.  The highlights were the Ceviche Trio which comes with chips and salsa and the Tacos Al Carbon Trio.  Everything else was also very good.  Would definitely come back here again but only with reservations.

I'm from Texas and used to great Mexican food, but seriously the best guacamole and tortilla soup ever. The atmosphere is incredible. Service staff does a great job. I ordered the flank steak and had to bring half home in a take out box. Homemade corn tortillas just melt in your mouth. Cannot wait to eat here again.

Oh man, I'm so torn here. Frontera Grill has been hyped a ton and I had super high expectations going into it. Knowing we would be in town, we made reservations about a month in advance and were seated right when we arrived. The restaurant is u-shaped with the main dining room on one side and the bar on the other. The tables are super close together, but we were lucky enough to get an end table on a crowded evening. Since we were starving, we placed orders for margaritas (blue agave & topolo) and chips and guac right away. The menu is pretty extensive and we had a hard time deciding what to order. Our server was super helpful and we landed on the carne asada brava and the striped bass in green mole, per his recommendation. I was a bit hesitant about the carne asada since it's marinated in habanero and my spice tolerance is low, but our server assured me it was a 4/10 on the spice meter.  The bass arrived first, and looked delicious, but after one bite, we realized the temperature was off. The dish was barely lukewarm and who wants to eat lukewarm fish? We asked them to bring the temperature up a bit, so they whisked it away just as the carne asada arrived. About that carne asada....HOLY HELL was it spicy! Between the heat and how chewy the flank steak was, I could barely choke it down. Again, we hailed our server to let him know and he promptly took it away and replaced it with the oaxacan-style carne asada which was a super tender rib-eye packed with flavor. The hot bass finally reappeared and it ended up being delightful, yet understated. We particularly enjoyed the mashed potatoes and maiitake mushrooms on the plate.  They comped us another round of margaritas, and we finished off the night with a flan duo. The service was top notch, but the food was just ok, given all the hype. If I'm paying $25+ for an entree, it should nearly blow my socks off....

Yikes this was a big disappointment. I've been here once before and thought the food and service were average. My husband got a gift card so that's the only reason we went back. I'm giving it one star because the bartender was really nice and he made me a great margarita with fresh lime. The dinner was such a disappointment! I have food allergies, gluten and dairy, so I told the waiter and asked for his suggestions on items that I could enjoy given my limitations. He was clueless. He provided random suggestions but wasn't confident in his responses. We ordered an appetizer, taquitos, and I asked that the dairy be put on the side so my husband could still enjoy the entire dish. Well the app showed up with all the ingredients on it. The service was terrible, I would have asked him to remake it but he wasn't around and we got sick of waiting. The evening was one big waiting game and the food was lackluster. The suburban crowd loves this place, and yeah it's a nice step up from the Olive Garden, but I won't be going back. Too many other awesome options in this city and most of them accept reservations too. I'd recommend Chilam Balam in lakeview, it's a way better option and its byob.

Having experienced many kinds of Mexican and Spanish cuisine, I still have never experienced anything quite like frontera grill. Every single item on the (rotating) menu is of absolute quality and excellence as is the service. Employees at frontera grill are eager to provide you with the best meal you will have in Chicago and potentially the best Mexican meal you will ever have. I had the pleasure of being waited on by a server who has been with frontera since 1988. He was passionate about the Chef's menu and was obviously very in tune with everything in the menu. Try everything! Because in all reality I was willing to bet my first born on whatever came out of that kitchen being fantastic. Cheers Fronter Grill Chicago!

Great meal at the bar. Bartender was attentive and helpful with drinks and food selection. Apps, main and dessert were all unique with excellent flavor. All little pricy and crowded, so I'll likely venture to the many other great restaraunt options in the area before returning to Frontera again.
This place is phenomenal.  A must stop each time we come into Chicago.  Every dish is spot on.  Flavorful, rustic, yet refined.  Can't go wrong with any of the tacos.

Yummy food! Went there for lunch with a group of friends.  We ordered the Frontera Guacamole, Guacamole Almendrado and Chips & Two Salsas to share.  They were good.  I had the Ceviche Trio (Amazing!) and Duck in Molde Coloradito (Yummy!).  Everything we ordered was very good, although, I think we ordered way too much food.  Décor was mahhh nothing special. I actually like Fontera Grill much much better than Topolobampo.  I think food is much tastier Fontera Grill.

Food, decor and service were all impeccable. Where else can you taste three different types of mole sauce from various regions of Mexico? This is Mexican food you won't find at your average Mexican restaurant. My waiter even reminisced about seeing his mother make some of the very dishes we ordered. Will definitely return here.
Would never go back!!! Pretentious and incredibly over priced! !!  Drinks are small,  flavorless and over priced.   My entree was drowning in sauce and was over seasoned.  Really disgusting

Great experience overall. Quite a selection on the menu and EXCELLENT service. Food came very promptly and drinks were refilled frequently. Was fairly empty around 5:30 PM on a Saturday, so my wife and I were seated right away w/o a reservation. A little pricey, but not bad.

1. Food: great experience.  The shrimp empanadas were light, fluffy, slightly crispy splashed with a spicy onion salsa verde that was the right amount of heat.  Made you grab your Blue Agave margarita, which you will need at least 2 of after taking a sip.  This is a purist margarita, damn good tequila with a little lime, shaken table side and a lot of salt.  Highly recommended.  The Topo Margarita has limonada, so a little sweeter, also good.  Dinner was the Stripped Bass and Carne Asada.  The green mole on the white flaky bass was delicious and the anejo mashed potatoes & mushrooms added a mix of complementary flavors.  The carne asada had a fantastic rub/marinade.  As far as steak goes, it was good, but not a steak you would get at any fine steakhouse in chicago.  Plantains with the meat were fantastic (I'm a sucker for plantains).  Dessert was the bread pudding with a very interesting queso flavored ice cream.  Also good.   2. Service: our waiter was great, describing dishes & drinks, very knowledgeable.  Food and drinks timed out well.  The key here was Kyle (manager I believe).  IF YOU HAVE A GROUPON, YOU MAY NOT HAVE A RESERVATION.  So there have been problems booking Frontera through the groupon website.  Just because groupon reserves a table for you, does not mean Frontera has accepted the reservation.  They have limited room.  THIS HAS BEEN A PROBLEM.  I don't know whose fault it is (I can guess).  BUT, Kyle took care of the situation.  I called to see if we could come a 1/2 hour early and found out, there was no reservation.  Despite my frustration (reservation booked months ago, had a babysitter, etc), Kyle was calm and collective, and re-ran our groupon through the system, and was able to confirm (the reservation had never come through on frontera's end).  They only have room for a handful of groupon reservations a night (they take very few reservations to begin with).  So we got in and had a great meal.  Kyle came over to the table to check on us as well.  Again, very professional, great customer service.  He also offered a similar package to what groupon gave us for dinner that night (if he couldn't get the groupon to work), and then we would have gone through groupon for a refund (a very realistic alternative).  It all worked out, and I thank Kyle for that (but not groupon!).
Really enjoyed we got the torrid soup with the Frontera trio. Delicious! Finished it off with the Capirotada and a cappuccino.
I'm giving the five stars for the food and service by everyone, Wilson was great even though he was busy! The atmosphere can get too loud with the happy hour crowd and families

Normally when we visit Chicago, we don't like to repeat restaurants because there are just too darn many to try. However, we made an exception and had lunch at Frontera Grill for the second time.  It was markedly less crowded than the last time we dined there (in 2013). Service was fine and the food was good.  My one complaint is how cramped the seating is. The first table we were ushered to was in such a tight section of tables that I stopped dead in my tracks and asked to be seated somewhere else.  We were ushered to another table, still cramped but better than the first one.   I realize that restaurants want to capitalize on their success and fit as many patrons as possible, but when I'm spending $75 for lunch, removing a half dozen tables would make the dining experience much more pleasant.

Had lunch at Frontera Grill and it was very, very good.  Staff was incredibly nice and attentive. Food was fresh, tasty, complex and nuanced. Really enjoyable. FG is not Taco Bell so expect to spend some money. Lucky for us I had a gift card from my unbelievably cool and generous big sister in New York.  I had the shrimp quesadillas and my wife had the steak tacos. Both outstanding. The guacamole alone was worth the trip.

Coming from California, I was super excited to try Rick Bayless' food. It did not disappoint!  My daughter who does not like Mexican food loved every dish. My ten year old son who can be picky tried everything we ordered and was delighted. The mole is impressive, the braised pork was fabulous and so well seasoned. I usually can pick out flavors and recreate dishes, but this was impossible for me to do here. The subtly and layers of flavor in each dish was far too complex to dissect. I am so thrilled when I eat out and can say that I really could not have made this at home!  Thank you Rick!  The service was superb. We had a 9:30 reservation that I made two months in advance. We called that morning to see if we could push it forward. They said they would let us know which usually is a polite way to say no. I was texted in the afternoon that they could take us at 7:30. How nice! Great experience. Oh, the decor and artwork is fascinating as well. This California girl wants Rick to move to Santa Barbara!

Short wait at the bar area and we managed to get a table without a reservation on a weeknight.  Creative drinks and an impressive tequila selection at the bar.   Menu is fairly extensive with a lot of good options to fit any appetite.  There really wasn't one thing on there that I did not want to eat.  Wasn't overly hungry so I ended up with some chips and guacamole and the duck with mole sauce.  The chips are served with a fresh made guac and a nice salsa roja and salsa verde.  The mole was obviously the star of the night and was definitely the best mole sauce I've ever had.   My only complaint is that the space is kinda tight and cramped.  We were bumped into a few times by passerbys and had to squeeze to get in and out of the tables.  Restaurant itself is fairly large and sort of a U shape.  Just too many tables packed in.   Valet parking out front.

Came here for lunch at noon on a week day and I was really expecting a phenomenal experience. Food was alright here but we had some pretty bad service while we were there.  The waiters were inattentive, slow, and clumsy! Knocked my friend's fork off and never brought a new one. Anyways getting to the food.   We had the ceviche trio and guacamole to start with.  All three were pretty good.   1) Tuna, guacamole and papaya went really well together. 2) Shrimp /citrus - was also pretty good 3) calamari vinegar and cilantro - standard As a main, I had the Street food trio which was just alright.   The shrimp empanadas were mostly the shell.  Would've been better with more filling Sopes rancheroes and potosinas were really nothing special Everyone else at my table was pleased with their dishes.  I however wasn't wowed.

Went here in early January for an office holiday party. We rented out the Library Room which served as a private dining experience. They explained and cooked the food right in front of us. The chef told us how many of his inspirations came from his mother's cooking in Mexico.  5 course meal complete with wine pairings from sommelier: 1. Ensalada de Mazana y Panela Ahumado: pretty good. A surprise of spice with the salsa macha. 2. Tostada de Camaron: reallly good. It's light, it's little and it's a bit of fun. Very tasty and you eat it with your hands. 3. Langosta en Chileatole: weird. Not bad, but weird. Chef tried to do a spin on two types of corn, but the popcorn just didn't fit. Overall the taste was decent and I liked the crispy Kale. 4. Carne Asada and Lengua: ..which means 'tongue'. Most people actually preferred the tongue over the Carne Asada. Both were good, but the tongue was flavorful and not the texture you'd expect. 5. Dessert: can't remember specifics other than it was good just had way too much cinnamon. Next time? Would probably only come back for the food/show experience if someone else was paying.

While they do take reservations, my family did not end up making any. We got there at 6 pm on a Saturday night, so of course it was busier than most nights. Ended up being almost a 2 hour wait (even though we were initially told it was 3 hours), but it was well worth it. You can hang out in the bar area and order food and drinks if you want to get your entire meal there or just have a snack while you wait for your table. Once we were seated though, the food was incredible. I highly recommend the the Street Food Trio, guacamole and the Paloma Oaxaquena if you want a drink with a kick to it.

What can I say about this restaurant that hasn't already been said? I have been watching Rick's TV shows, and so I was excited to come here. The restaurant was all I had hoped for. The staff is all Mexican/Latino except the chef. Make sure you have reservations. The chips, salsa, and guacamole were outstanding. The salsa has a smoky flavor that is complex. I could've drank it! We ordered a variety of dishes to share. The me was spicy and had the complex flavor profile that I would expect from Chef Bayless. I look forward to coming back the next time I come to Chicago!

This place is the real deal!!! From the drinks sides and entrees one thing better then the next.  Great tequila selection The tortillas could not be any fresher The carne asada was incredible cooked perfect with insane amounts of flavor The corn tamales WOW!!! I even ate kale I don't eat kale but I kept going back for more Our server was precise and so pleasant what a great experience!!

Frontera is hands down the best Mexican restaurant in Chicago. The flavors that they come up with are phenomenal and constantly keep your taste buds guessing.  I've had many meals here, but the one that stands out above the rest is the Oaxacan-style carne asada. Even knowing that I will most likely like anything on the menu, I can't stop myself from ordering it. I do sub one thing and that is the charro beans.  I wouldn't say I'm a bean guy at all but these beans make me want to become one and take all the duties that title will bestow on me.  I'm constantly preaching about this restaurant to anyone who will listen. Take a trip to Frontera soon and you will not be disappointed.

I decided to make reservations here and the woman who answered the phone with the Asian accent is really rude.  First of all it's hard to understand her so I repeated myself several times to make sure I got the date right.  Well, after checking my calendar I realized she made a reservation for may 30th instead of may 3rd.  When I called her back to clarify which date I wanted and that I had just called she waited a few seconds then yelled, "What's your name!" With such a prestigious restaurant as this I'd think someone with better social skills would be answering the phone.  Not sure I want to go here anymore.  I'd rather check out New Robozo in Oak Park.  They have great mexican food and awesome drinks, but most importantly better customer service. The owner actually stops at the table.  Did I mention they have jalapeno ice cream and several different types of mole sauce?

Had a great time at Frontera back in 2010 with Rick (aka "I'm Rick Bayless B!", inside joke).  Rick was working at the restaurant that night and initially mistook me for someone else, so fortunately for me, he shared some of his best plates with me along with some exquisite Tequila from his extensive Tequila collection.  Food is more traditional/interior Mexican.  My mother is from interior Mexico and we lived there until I was six and Spanish is my first language, so I think I know true Mexican.  Food was excellent, drinks were excellent, and what else can I say, the service from the owner of the restaurant was outstanding. Thanks Rick!  I'll be back again!!

This place is a bit pricey for Mexican food (since I'm from California) but the food was excellent.  I got the Creamy Grilled Chicken, Roasted Poblano and Spinach with four tortilla ($11)and it was amazing. It's a small portion but not small enough that you are still hungry afterwards. The tortillas were so fluffy and the flavor of the creamy chicken was oh so yummy.  My husband got the Oaxacan-style Carne Asasa ($34.50). It was served with black beans, guacamole, and plantains. It was as well amazing. So much flavor with each bite and not too spicy. It was so good.

Excellent Mexican food.  I ordered the tacos with steak, I was impressed with the flavor.  The "Just Made" chips were also very good.  For dessert I had the lime tart, which was awesome.  Pricey but worth it.

One of my favorite restaurants in the world.   Started off with cocktails.  Mezcal margarita was amazing, even though I do prefer my Margs on the rocks over strained.  Chips and salsa, worth getting. Had a kale apple salad with habanero citrus vinegarette.  It had potential but the habanero overpowered it and blew out my tastes buds. I had the chicken tacos.  Tortillas house made, marinated chicken was the best I've had, the smokey beans were perfect, and avocado was perfect. I will be flying back to Chicago to checkout some more restaurants and will def be back to Frontera Grill try everything I can.  Rick Bayless is my new favorite chef.

This place has fallen by the wayside...I hope our experience was a fluke. My date chose it, and I was excited because I hadn't been in so long. And it was not a 1st or 2nd, more like a 20th. I'm getting better people. Anyway, I was not very impressed. We sat at the bar, a favorite for both of us. My cocktail was not great, he liked his. We both got the same seafood soup, and I swear I make a better one. The fish was tough, the shrimp chewy, and it lacked carbs. Soup is hearty. It should come with potatoes or a side of tortillas. It left me wanting for a lot. The date didn't. You win some, you lose some.  I'll try it again, but on a side note, the bathrooms were gross too. Huge pet peeve.

I can think of two words to describe this place.  Overpriced and overrated.  The food was average and overly salty.  The wait for a table was long. The prices were high and the portions were small.  Decent guacamole, but nothing to write home about.  The salsa verde was good but a tablespoon in a thimble-sized vessel just wasn't enough.  Decent margaritas but I've had better and more generous ones.  No complaints on the service.  Our waiter was quick and attentive despite the Friday crowd.  I'll leave this place for to its fans and continue patronizing my favorite Mexican hole in the wall restaurants - The ones that cook with soul and aren't owned by a celebrity chef.

One of my favorite restaurants and quite possibly my favorite restaurant in Chicago, I have yet to experience a restaurant like Frontera anywhere else in the country. Over the course of a few visits, standouts have been: Tortilla soup ($8.50): remains one of my favorite soups ever, the broth is fantastic and the tortilla strips, crema, avocado and chicken come together perfectly. Mole poblano enchiladas ($12): one of my favorites, I love Frontera's mole poblano and these enchiladas are the perfect pairing to really let the dark, roasty, slightly sweet mole come through. Striped bass in almond mole ($25): absolutely loved this dish, the portion was generous and the almond mole was smooth, nutty, and slightly sweet, perfect for the tender striped bass. Squash that came on the side was outstanding. Duck in date mole ($25): Duck breast came in long tranches and was perfectly cooked. Date mole was complex with roasty flavors of date and nutmeg, very slightly sweet. Mole trio ($23): another standby, I am a huge fan of mole and especially loved the mole poblano enchiladas and root veggies in green mole. Pork in yellow mole was also tasty, but less interesting than the other two. Holiday empanada ($8): warm, flaky empanada filled with some sort of warm cranberry compote. I was blown away by the phenomenal homemade chestnut ice cream that came with it. Duo of flan ($8): traditional vanilla and coconut. Both flans were the perfect consistency, the coconut was especially delicious and the crumbled (lemon?) cookies added flavor and texture. EDIT: Frontera is now tied with Longman & Eagle for my favorite brunch in Chicago. Bajio-style eggs ($13): A creative, delicious take on eggs benedict. Instead of the standard english muffin or biscuit, these poached eggs rest on two incredible masa cakes that are slightly crispy and mealy. The chorizo on top is extremely flavorful, and the jalapeno cream sauce is absolutely perfect with this dish. One of the best, most memorable brunch dishes I've had in a while. Enchiladas in mole ($15): Make sure you ask for a side of extra mole poblano! These chicken enchiladas are always great with Frontera's signature mole, which is dark, roasty, slightly chocolatey and sweet. Even the black beans on the side are noticeably delicious, especially when topped with a little extra mole. I really appreciate this dish during brunch. Gorditas ($13) was also excellent, the black bean sauce is addictive. Their guacamoles are good, but I'd really rather pay a few extra bucks for an extra entree. Whatever tamales Frontera has on offer are pretty much excellent across the board. I also remember trying the queso fundido with duck, the street food trio, and guacamole which were all well prepared, just not as memorable. Never tried any of the taco options. Reservations are still hard to come by here, and for good reason, I'd gladly go for brunch, lunch or dinner any day.

The server earned my respect right away. I asked what he recommended and didn't suggest the most expensive, but what he genuinely thought I'd like. He was exactly right, from which margarita to the guacamole to the entree. Trust your servers! :) The Roasted Poblano-Pepita guacamole was the best guacamole I've ever had. I could've made that my meal. The Wed special, Cichinita Pibil was really, really tasty. The hot habañero sauce was very hot, but perfect. I'm a long-time fan of their salsa, but fresh is so much better than store bought jars. Don't get me started with the refried beans. How in the world can they make them so dang tasty??? Unfortunately, I was too full to try the desserts... :(

Amazing flavors, service and drinks!!  We are foodies always trying the four and five star places on Yelp to see if they really are that good.  Frontera definitely gets 5 stars from us!!!!  We tried several different things including the street food trio as an appetizer - absolutely amazing!!  We also had the chips and salsa which came with 2 different kinds of salsa.  This is a pretty small portion of salsa so don't get too excited - it was delicious though!!  The queso with the crispy bacon and relish in it is a MUST to get!!  It comes with warm homemade tortillas.   For our entree we shared the carne asada (Ribeye).  It was also outstanding!!!  The side of black beans, guacamole and fried plantains were equally as decadent!! What we have raved about the most since we left were the margaritas.  The best margaritas we've ever had!! Oaxacan Gold and the Topolo Margaritas are top notch!!! Our server did an outstanding job of explaining the flavors and taking care of us!  She also suggested the Malbec to go with the carne asada and she was spot on!!   We will absolutely return!!!!

One of the best meals I have had in my short life.  My wife & I started with the Mexican quesadillas, truly authentic tasting, rich corn flavor with a punch if creamy/warm cheese.  Ordered the mole trio for the main dish, which was phenomenal.  A tasting of three very distinct, but equally delicious mole dishes that exceeded all my expectations.  The pork apricot mole was life changing, my new last meal! (however the other 2 were a close second.). My wife had the street trio, which she said was delicious as well.   As we were about to leave I caught a glimpse if Rick Bayless himself behind the bar, but he was too quick and elusive to snap a pic.  Proof that he takes pride in his restaurants and is present at least some of the time.  He doesn't just slap his name on something and hope for the best. Awesome atmosphere, excellent service, and crazy good, authentic Mexican flavor.  Will definitely return when I'm back in Chi town!

Rick Bayliss is a flavour God.  We were so lucky to have been able to get a table at this place.  I had the arroz with shrimp, which was fresh tasting but bold and involved with flavours.  The chicken with butternut squash was divine and converted me forevermore to be a Bayliss acolyte.  I am not a fan of chicken but his dish was an explosion of flavour that reminds me of being in Mexico.  Food that transports you is magical and that is what his food does.  Did I mention that the guacamole was perfect?  The service was warm and impeccable.  Just a great experience overall and I felt casual and content.  We dreamed of this meal again and again.  I wish this restaurant existed in Toronto.  Unfortunately we have not much choice but to hike to Chicago each time.  I heart you Rick Bayliss!

Food was super cold when it came out and found a nice piece of long hair with it. Our server tried to tell us it was from the banana leaf, like we couldn't differentiate a piece of hair from a banana leaf and he just would not let it down. Kinda sucks bc we really wanted to like this place...
I would give this restaurant ten stars if I could. The food was amazing.  If I lived in Chicago I would eat at this restaurant everyday.

I came here for the first time this past weekend for Restaurant Week (lunch) with a friend, and it was AMAZING. Food: We had the kale apple salad (delicious, full salad full of flavor; tasted really fresh), ceviche (I don't like fish but my friend said it was amazing), chicken with ancho sauce and mashed butternut squash (the flavors together were perfect--so smooth and blended!), and the tres leches cake and flan (both were amazing but get the fresh leches cake; perfectly moist and honestly the best dessert I've had in a while) Service: 1000000000 starts. My friend is gluten free, corn free, and meat free and had actually made a reservation for Topolobampo because there was food she could eat on the menu. The restaurant had made a mistake and made a reservation for Frontera instead, and the Restaurant Week menu didn't have any options for her. The general manager came out, clarified her dietary restrictions, and couldn't be friendlier. She created a fish option on the spot and replaced chips with cucumbers! She was so kind, and it made our experience even better. Go go go!! And the lunch prices are super affordable (average of $15 per plate)

It matters very little how many stars I give Frontera. It is a well-lauded institution and in many ways it deserves the huzzahs. I've gone since it opened and still remember my first meal there and where I sat. Over the last few years, I've been nagged by an essential and unhappy truth about the place: no one at the front desk gives a rip about customers; in fact I don't think they even like them. They have turned the experience of walking into Frontera into a total hash-house experience and do not do one single thing to make you feel welcome or appreciated as a guest. You walk up and instead of a smile or a hello, they say "how many?" and bark out an order: go to the bar or whatever. Once at the table things improve; the service usually is pretty good and delivered with what seems like genuine warmth.  Our last visit deserves a special call out for heinous behavior by management, an attitude that pretty much squarely lands in the land of unforgivable. We were standing in line, waiting for the front door to open. It was a warmish winter day, hovering right at about 31F after an afternoon that had been sunny and mid 30s. This is only important in that it caused the snow from Frontera's awning to melt and drip to the sidewalk, causing a slick of black ice for homeward-bound pedestrians. Within a span of 3 minutes, two people completely wiped out, ass plants on the ice. Five more caught themselves before hitting the ground. We called the desk by phone to explain because the desk crew makes a game of not making eye contact with those in line; they actually hung up when we mentioned there was ice on the sidewalk. When another person fell, we finally pantomimed enough angst that someone deigned to come out. We explained the issue and he said, and I quote: "I'll tell building management to clean it."  How many ways can I say "major jackwad?" He did come out a few minutes later and scatter salt but the 'it's not my problem' attitude speaks volumes about where management's head exists at Frontera. Definitely not in a "customer first" universe.  I'll go back and as has been the case for the last 10 years, I'll scratch my head about why the top tier of people who work at Frontera hate their jobs so much. Happily, they can be left behind for the more welcoming experience that unfolds in the dining room.

I've been here before when I was young and poor and anti "weird" combinations and so I ordered something plain and cheap and didn't really get to appreciate the awesomeness of the food here. Luckily, I have returned since, enticed by a Groupon deal.  The deal provides you and your friend two margaritas, a street food item to share, and two entrees. I unfortunately could not have any of the margaritas because they all contained some form of orange liqueur and I am weirdly allergic to oranges, but my friend said he was happy to have two, and so I ordered the Paloma. The waiter described the drink to me as he was pouring it into the martini glass and told me it would be spicy because the mezcal is infused with peppers for two weeks.  Our street food item was the pork tinga tacos and we accepted the offer to have it come with some spicy salsa on the side. The pork was perfection. I nearly ruined my second taco with a healthy helping of habanero sauce, not realizing just how spicy it would be. My mouth burned. My lips swelled. But I finished the taco, and am still able to say that I enjoyed it, mainly because I felt like a badass. And the Paloma? Not spicy at all. All I tasted now was refreshing grapefruit. My entree was the Oaxacan Carne Asada. Omg. Huge piece of meat. Sweet plaintains. A pile of black beans. And guacamole. I was in heaven. Ate everything but half of the beans. Steak was cooked to my liking, the guacamole was amazing, and the plantains were a nice bit of sweetness. The tortillas that come with the meal were useful as well- to make a couple more tacos with more of that awesome habanero sauce. That's right- I became immune. My friend enjoyed his Carne Asada Brava as well, though he said the tamales were on the bland side. For dessert, I tried their dessert margarita- the Cafe Tacuba, which was a cold coffee and chocolate concoction. Strong and very, very good. We also tried the flan duo because we clearly didn't have enough food, which was comprised of a vanilla flan and white chocolate flan. I much preferred the white chocolate flan, but both were light and creamy and delicious and we couldn't help but finish them both off. My only complaint about this place was the wait on everything. Reservation was at 9, but the table wasn't ready for a good 10-15 minutes. Then we had to wait a while for our waiter. Then our drinks, which came after the app. I felt like I was in a doctor's office. Once the food comes, however, it's worth the wait. Is it also worth the price? Not for an everyday meal, but definitely for a special occasion (or with a groupon).

SO glad we were able to get a reservation and be seated right away when we got there! I love it! I loved all of it! They offer coat check, our server was prompt and the food was everything I had hoped it would be! Great mix of people! Families, friends and dates! I would love to come back and try more!

Really expensive for what it is.  I get that it's $$$ but I was really disappointed.  This was the most expensive meal we had when we visited Chicago and it was by far the worst.  To be fair it's competing with Purple Pig, Girl and the Goat, and Au Cheval.  The guacamole and ceviche were nothing special.  The mole sampler was bland- I think we kind of liked 1 out of the 3 of them.  Great service and a nice ambiance, but that was about it.

I expected to be wowed and it certainly did not disappoint. Throughout the meal the service was top notch with servers, bussers and managers checking in consistently.  I started out with a seasonal blood orange margarita. It was perfectly balanced with a hint of sweetness, perfect amount of acid and the tangy zip of the lime juice. The scary part about it is that I could have had 4-5 of them without realizing that I was actually consuming alcohol. Luckily I stuck to one. As an appetizer we had empanadas with crushed avocado and a mix of creme and hot sauce. Fantastic deep flavors and the right balance of textures. For an entree my wife and I shared the fish of the day (tilefish) and the striped bass. Both cooked to perfection with complementary sauces and a nice smokey char that fit the fish perfectly. Interestingly enough, the thing that set the tilefish off was the smoked potatoes in a cilantro creme sauce. I mean holy freaking cow that was amazing. I could literally just sit and eat a plate of that. For desert was had the duo of flan. Again perfect balance of flavor and texture. The often overly sweet custard desert was fairly mild with a sweet sauce, slightly bitter orange and a crunchy amaranth honey  crisp. Overall just an awesome meal. There were no flavors in the meal that were new or different but the dishes were assembled to perfection showing off their amazing culinary skills.

The service was top notch! The corn tamale appetizer was great. The enfrijoladas not so great. I expected the food to taste better because my husband and I are big fans of his cooking show, but they were not that tasty. The coconut tres leches cake was good! Overall okay but a little pricey for how the food tastes. I always said I would visit this restaurant if I were ever in Chicago and now I can cross it off my bucket list. I will not be revisiting again.

The food & drinks at Frontera Grill are awesome!  My wife and I recently visited and while waiting for a table I had a Champagne Margarita - if you don't do margaritas very often because they are to sweet or sour, this is a must-try for you. The brut champagne drys the sweetness out just enough to really make this a delicious drink. My wife is pregnant, so she stuck with a non-alcoholic beer.  When seated we ordered classic guacamole which came with two different salsas, all three of which were awesome with the perfectly home-made chips.  The Smoked Chicken Queso Fundido was good, but the cheese, when melted, was a little on the oily side.  Finally, my wife ordered Chicken & Black Beans for Making Little Tacos - very tasty, and I ordered the Carne Asada "Brava" which was marinated skirt steak (perfectly cooked and sliced thinly) with onions (meh, just ok) and sweet corn tamales that were out of this world!! The sweetness of the tamales went perfectly with the spiciness of the skirt steak.  I also ordered the Topolo margarita which was smooth and not overly sweet/sour...actually I had two of those : )  One important note; the tortillas. We had them with the queso fundido and the chicken with black beans, these are fantastic! We were seated in the lower dining room, which is not as nice as the main dining room, and needs some maintenance.  The following need to be addressed.  1. The light over our table kept flickering.  2. Our table wobbled.  3. The men's room urinal ran continuously and overflowed.  4. When I returned from the restroom and pulled my chair in, one of the legs started to break off (I'm 210 lbs.).  Can't give five stars to a place that needs that much TLC. Food Score = 4 out of 5 Atmosphere Score = 3 out of 5 Building Score = 3 out of 5

Definitely not what I expected.  Requested a booth when I made reservations,  which we got and was located in a semi-private area. I ordered the agua del dia, which was a delicious cucumber, lime, mint and something else juice.  We started with the guacamole -awesome. I had the enchiladas to share and the fresh corn tamales, with a side of white rice. The portions were very generous,  I took most home. The food was good, but not unforgettable.  Too much hype for the place and didn't meet my expectations. Nevertheless, it was worth trying.
Excellent food and cocktails in a casual environment. The food was surprisingly complex and even the most simple dish had layers of flavors.

Why is my review soooo bad? Sigh. I'm sorry, but nothing wowed me here except for their pineapple salsa... Which we had to ask for. What kind of Mexican restaurant doesn't just bring you salsa?  I was close to ordering the dessert. I wanted to be wow'd by something even though my stomach was going to explode... But I didn't bother. I was afraid to be disappointed again. Come on.
