It has to be worth the calories right? I tried 6 different dishes. The one I was most disappointed with is the chicken tamal(e). There was this brown sauce over it like bbq sauce consistency. It was better off being dry so I can pour salsa over it. I really tried to like this place. The good and friendly service is what's saving me from giving this restaurant one star.  All in all, not because of the money either... Based on solely my taste buds, I'd rather go to the Mexican joints down the street from me. My Man's note (who's an amazing cook by the way!):  Scallops missing a unique spice to absorb the fish flavor.  Tortilla soup on the salty side lacking full body.  Taco appears to be a steak dish losing a touch of traditional Mexican taco art.

Wow! Ever since my family started buying Rick Bayless's incredible books, and following him on Top Chef masters, we have been dying to go to Frontera. This restaurant did not disappoint! Amazing and diverse ceviche, one killer corn tamale, delicious tacos trios, and unbelievable flan, this restaurant lived up to every expectation!

This would be the place if you are seeking clean, organic Mexican fusion food. I spent $70 for lunch for 2 ppl and it was average in taste and flavor. We had the appetizer sampler which was ok, but not amazing.. ordered a duck taco as well.. I would probably go to Pilsen and get more authentic and flavorful tacos for lesser price.

I took my office team out for lunch here and the food was overall excellent.  The main courses were the highlight with our dining.  What makes this restaurant special is the unique flavors offered and the joyous atmosphere.  The starters of chips & guacamole were a little less than spectacular (although still good) and our beverages (non alcoholic) were fine but not great.  For that, not 5 stars but definitely worthy of a destination to enjoy the chef's signature fare.  We all agreed that we would come back on our own.

I was really expecting this to be a five-star experience, but for me everything has to click (or come very close) in order to do so. And things were going swimmingly until dessert. But first things first: the service was excellent, as was the atmosphere and nearly all of our food. Appetizer: queso fundido - delicious, rich, cheesy and with the right amount of heat. Entrees: my mole trio was excellent, with a great mix of flavors. My sister's taco (or was it enchilada) sampler was also very good, with another interesting blend of flavors. Her boyfriends carne asada (I believe) hit all the marks.  Dessert: We were all very full, but when I saw the Mexican hot chocolate, I thought I'd give it a go. HUGE disappointment. Not thick, not chocolatey and barely any flavor. It tasted like the watered-down stuff they sell at Wrigley when it's cold in April. Major major disappointment - especially considering Xoco has a variety of them, all reputedly good. This place had one and it was horrible. Literally left a bad taste in my mouth about the experience.

I went to Frontera Grill for dinner while in Chicago for a business trip. I had no trouble getting a seat at the bar, where there were a lot of other single diners. I started with the Tortilla soup, which was really good. They serve the tortillas hot and crispy and then pour the soup over them in front of you. The result? Crispy tortilla for your entire eating experience. The cheese was also melted, stringy perfection. For entree, I had the Tacos Arabe which were DELICIOUS. The chipotle sauce had the perfect spice level and the pork was perfectly cooked. The service was also great.  I really couldn't ask for anything more. I will definitely be returning next time I'm back.

Everything was amazing from the staff who explained everything on the menu perfectly ! Rick Bayless your restaurant did not disappoint ! If you guys love Xoco or any other you'll love this place small but you didn't feel close to anyone very romantic :)

First time in Chicago. This was one of the best reviewed places, so my buddies and I decided to come here for brunch. I had the Eggs a la Mexicana which was amazing. The atmosphere and service were also great. Highly recommended if you like Mexican food!

Remember that game, never have i ever? Never ever have i ever had to wait 4 months for a 5:45pm reservation. Granted it was for a group of 10 on a Saturday, but that is totally senior citizen dinnertime. I don't normally finish lunch until 2/3pm on the wkends. Never had gourmet Mexican; Rick Bayless is hella famous; and I do find myself at Frontera Fresco often for lunch during my hour break between classes, so this seemed like a good choice.  Food was delicious. However, the plates were tiny and way over-priced. I had to remind myself, it's GOURMET Mexican. I'm just not used to paying so much for Mexican food. I probably wouldn't pay to come here again, but would recommend to others for something different.  Warning: read my second sentence. Frontera Grill, you made it into my Guinness records book for longest wait for a restaurant.

Ok, let me just come out and say it- I've had a crush on Rick Bayless for quite some time and FINALLY made it into Frontera years lately. So. You noticed. There's a star missing and this is solely based on the reservations/host experience I had. The food and service is hands down, 5-stars. And unfortunately the star rating is about the WHOLE experience. Let me get the good stuff in here first before I complain. Our server was very helpful and educated on the food. I like to let people make decisions for me, and he was happy to do so. The salsas and guac are a must. Save room to split some of the small plates. I personally loved the sopes. For my entree I went the fish route and boy was I happy I did. Absolutely stunning and full of complimentary flavors. We finished with dessert (they surprised us with) and some Mexican hot chocolate. Then I was wheeled out to the car and brought home to decompress. One extremely special experience for us - my boyfriend and I celebrating our anniversary - was seeing Rick Bayless running the line. I felt like each dish was made with extreme care and compassion... You could taste it. Now, for the bad. I made my reservation months in advance online because it's been a struggle to get in. I got a call the day before from a host confirming my reservation for 2 and 8pm and was asked to call back - since he got my voice mail. When I called back I talked with another man who said he couldn't find my reservation. I spelled my name out, gave him all my info, told him I just got a message from someone... Finally he says, "oh ya, here you are but you made your reservation at 5:30pm." Now, mind you I have my email with my confirmation in front of me while he tells me this... I said no, I didn't. I work an hour away and won't even be home by 5:30 and the person who left the message had the correct time... I also have my confirmation email. He argues with me telling me that I made my reservation at 5:30. I persisted that I didn't and reiterated my evidence that I didn't. Finally, in a hurried and frustrates voice, he says, well I can get you in at 8:30 so I'll change the 5:30pm reservation you made, bye. I was so turned off that he spoke so rudely and acted as if he did me a favor when clearly the mistake was on his end. What it felt like was they bumped my reservation to squeeze someone else in and tried to get away with t. Totally not cool. When I got in the reservation he made for me was also for 4. Oy. Headache. Anyway that's it.  Go enjoy the food and keep your reservation confirmations- you just might need em!

One word: Phenomenal!  I mean, can you expect anything less from this TopChef Master?  I usually pick up a torta at O'Hare, which is the best thing inside that airport, but I had no idea just how fantastic my meal at Frontera would be.  If only I could have ordered one of everything! Sidenote: I got to drink a pint from Brewery Vivant.  Someone knows how to pick their Michigan beers!

Chef Rick Bayless's restaurant deserves 5/5 stars! The hype is definitely worth it. Enjoyed everything that we've ordered - beer included (by the waiter's recommendation. I recall it was a Mexican beer?) :) Service was excellent - the waiter came back to check on us in good intervals and was very friendly. CEVICHE TRIO Awesome display of food! Enjoyed taking pictures of this dish haha The seafood was very fresh - the trio was a combination of sour, sweet and savoury. An excellent start to our meal. STREET FOOD TRIO A great choice for those looking for a hot appetizer. The enchiladas potosinas were my favourite..! The guacamole was so smooth and creamy.. Craving for this already!! OAXACAN-STYLE CARNE ASADA Delicious..!! The sweet plantains stood out for me as well as the black beans.. I really didn't expect these to taste sooo good!!  The Angus prime steak paired very well with all the sides included :D

I've been here many times and have never been disappointed in the food - it is top notch!  Best margaritas anywhere.  Service can be thin when busy, which is often, but typically is good.  Get there early and prepare to pay!

We ate in the bar area and it was quieter, roomier, and nicer design than the restaurant side. We did sit very close to other people which was okay because they were friendly. The food was excelente! I had the mole trio and a negro modelo. Delicioso! Gentlemanly mexican waiters and nice atmosphere. Reasonable prices for the location and quality of food.

There is much hype about one of Chef Rick Bayless' flagship restaurants here in Chicago. The question is...is the hype deserved or is it overrated? After having wanted to dine there for a couple of years, but never finding the time during a visit, we finally made it to Frontera Grill. The resounding answer is YES, the hype is worth it and NO the restaurant is not overrated. LOCATION & ATMOSPHERE Rick Bayless seems to dominate the block where Frontera Grill is located. The restaurant is collocated with two of Bayless' other restaurants: Topolobampo (high-end Mexican cuisine) and Xoco (fast-casual sandwich concept). Frontera is in the heart of tourist central and is flanked by such exciting culinary destinations as Rainforest Café and Maggiano's! It blows my mind that there were people dining and better yet WAITING to dine at these chain restaurants when such divine culinary art is happening all around these tourist traps here in Chicago. My gain, their loss is the way I look at it. It is still very much a pain to secure a reservation at Frontera as it primarily is a walk-in restaurant. They do offer few reservations for both lunch and dinner services. If you hate to wait and being in/near lines like I do, reservations in advance is the only way to go. You can always check the day or so before and if there have been cancellations you can snag one of those reservations. FOOD & BEVERAGE So, if you go to Frontera you absolutely have to try a margarita or two. They are delicious and there is a wide variety on the menu. From smoky mezcal-inspired concoctions to more traditional margaritas - there really is something for everyone. My 'at home' margarita recipe is from one of Bayless' cookbooks and my version is damn near close to what I was served at Frontera Grill. I saved my coin and only had one since I knew I could recreate something very similar at home. I had to test it out though to confirm! The food -- the food! As one would expect, this is where Frontera shines. We opted to explore the small plates/sharing portions of the menu versus having large entrees. This was the best way to go in my opinion as we got to try a little bit of everything.  As many a reviewer behind me has said - the Ceviche Trio is a must have item for the table. Each ceviche was fresh and unique - great flavor combinations. The 'Street Food Trio' is another great item to share at the table. We ordered some of the vegetable sides and were happy with each of our choices - the Modern Black Beans, the Red-Chile Braised Kale with Local Potatoes, and the Pickled Jalapenos were great accompaniments to our meal. I'm so glad we finally had the opportunity to visit Frontera Grill and this will absolutely go on our rotation of restaurants we visit when we are in Chicago again. As I'm re-reading my review (congratulations if you made it this far!) -- I can't even believe I didn't mention the INSANELY obnoxious family beside us. The mother's voice were like nails on a chalkboard and they were all so unnecessarily loud. So you KNOW the food and drink were great for me to forget the obnoxious diners.

I was psyched to be able to get into Rick Bayless's place. You can sit at the bar and eat without a reservation, so we stood outside until the place opened at 5. Bingo! Impressive tequila list. Everything from the appetizers to dessert was delicious. Don't expect the typical cheese-smothered Mexican that's popular.

Really enjoyed Rick Bayless's signature restaurant in downtown Chicago. After a long 16 hour day-this meal was more then just lovely ambience - it was a professional restaurant experience everyone should have. From the waitstaff to the maître d', Kyle, everyone worked so hard to make our evening enjoyable and lovely. This was particularly meaningful as my husband had been so sick the week prior for his birthday. The Christmas guacamole is something I wish to keep on their menu all year round.  The moly sauce is something to be treasured. And their steaks here and chicken fajitas were sublime. If you go make sure you stop next-door at Xoco and pick up a beautiful cup of hot chocolate. The best I've ever tasted!

Walked in at around 830 on a Tuesday evening and didn't have to wait for a table :)  The food is very good. I cannot say whether they are authentic, but the quality is top notch and the flavor is quite rich. For two people, we ordered sopes rancheros for sharing (very small, only three portions), and it was delicious! We then got a feature fish in cilantro cream, and carnes al carbón with steak. The fish was okay, but the side vegetable - romanesco was the first time I ever had and it was so delicate. The tacos are stellar - guacamole can never be this fresh, and the steak is just so juicy. Love it!  On the downside, our waiter seem to be very disengaged, and did not give any recommendations. Granted, it was the night before Christmas Eve and he might be tired, but it would have been a five star had we had better service.

I've had wildly mixed experiences with Rick Bayless.  Loved Frontera Fresco, was underwhelmed by Xoco and actively disliked the Tortas Frontera at O'Hare. So how would Frontera Grill hold up? The food was quite good, but this place is crazy expensive.  With tax and tip, it ran us about $50/person.  It's slightly elevated Mexican food, man.  I feel like that total is high for what we ate. * Chips and salsa ($3) - If you've had the Frontera salsa you can buy at Whole Foods, this is the same deal.  You get a red and a green.  Sadly, they provide so little salsa.  It's like an eyedropper's worth.  I like to drown my chips, son!  The salsas are tasty, but I've had better chips elsewhere. * Classic Queso Fundido ($8) - Jack Cheese, garlicky roasted peppers, homemade chorizo.  I'm not a huge queso fundido fan.  This was alright.  Not a huge portion.  Maybe big enough for two people to share a couple bites. * Carne Asada Brava ($29) - Serrano-marinated grass-fed flank steak, salsa huevona (hand-crushed, grill-roasted tomatoes, jalapenos).  Grilled knob onions, sweet corn tamales.  This was a home run.  I speared my steak slices and shoveled them into a tortilla with a splash of hot sauce.  Very tasty.  Not much fat on the meat.  The sweet corn tamales are fairly flavorless. * Blue Agave Margarita ($12) - Milagro blanco tequila, cointreau, fresh lime juice.  Another huge score.  Smooth and strong.  This is a quality contender to the other excellent margarita in the neighborhood over at Cantina Laredo.   I was really disappointed in the look of the place.  It's cramped.  My girlfriend literally bumped into another diner when she leaned back in her chair. Frontera Grill has something of an identity crisis.  It kinda wants to slum it.  It kinda wants to be upscale.  If the food were upscale with cheap prices, that'd be one thing.  But the food can be hit-or-miss, the ambiance is lacking and the prices are high. I may return, but I've had better all-around experiences at Cantina Laredo at Illinois & State.

Stopped in for drinks and appetizers, and was not disappointed. A fresh, insightful take on dishes from Oaxaca and other parts of Mexico. The standouts were the blood orange margarita and the chicken enchilada appetizer. The enchilada was an interesting technique on a dish that most people are familiar with. They come as dumplings that are deep fried, and they are outstanding!

I was hoping for more of a meal at Frontera but it was just a sandwich place, we ordered the cubana it was smothered in a spicy chipotle sauce and the guacamole chicken tortilla soup was also very tasty.

By far one if the most delicious, memorable meals I've had in this city.  Good was great, atmosphere was nice. Our server was a little on the slower side and we had to flag her down for refills and the check, but overall a great dining experience and Will return!

Meh. After an hour and a half wait, I was expecting some really good food. Frontera grill fell a bit short. Good service, fun ambiance, but very average food. I've been here twice now, but the food always disappoints me. Will not be back.

I came in on a Thursday night and was  pleasantly surprised! I loved the decor it definitely brought out the concept of the place. Me and my friend sat at the bar. Jay took care of us he was nice and definitely left a positive impression! He recommended a spicy margarita which was delicious, but gin and tonic topped it off. They add some citrus and black tea which really.emphasizes the cocktail. They definitely accommodate to everyone, my friend can't have dairy so we ordered raw tuna and scallops it was perfection.  We had candied beetd and sorbet for dessert! At the end of our meal we saw Rick Bayless in the kitchen it's nice to see he takes pride in his restaurants, and is very involved with frontera :)

Let me start by saying we are spur of the moment travelers. We take the adventure by the minute and not planned by the day. We have been trying to get into the Frontera Grill the last few times we were in Chicago with little luck trying to make reservations without weeks of notice. Tonight we decided to bite the bullet and wait! We waited a solid hour which was to be expected and was predicted by the hostess. Once seated I had high expectations. The guac and ceviche were good, nothing to blow your socks off but good! The cocktails were among the same vein, good but not incredible. I have a rule about attitude, which is not lacking at Frontera. If you've earned it with superior food, service, and cocktails I am all about the attitude! I love when a place is excellent and just knows it! Frontera Grill has not earned it. Out of our party of five two people were satisfied with their dinners. I had the carne asada which was solidly sub par. The meat was over cooked. Edgar (our waiter) told me that the meat had to be over cooked or it would have ended up chewy which makes me wonder what sort of low quality meat they are using. I went in expecting to love every bite and I walked out seriously dissatisfied. For the money go somewhere that tries a little harder, unfortunately celebrity restaurants seem to cater to a certain type of person. With all the incredible dining options in Chicago Frontera Grill has not earned a spot on my repeat list.

Our younger son, who studied in the D.F. for a year, finds most Mexican food in the Chicago area to be very disappointing and rarely eats it, so we decided to try Frontera Grill to see what it was like. It was very good. The setting was comfortable and service  professional, friendly, and attentive.  We tried the Frontera ceviche and the guacamole, both of which were delicious.  Our son ordered the three giant tacos plate, I the carne asada, and my wife a chicken and mushroom dish.  The flavors were varied and crisp, and nothing was highly peppery; even the "venomous" pintos were actually quite friendly to human existence.   Very enjoyable place!   Oh yes, the chocolate pecan pie was delicious, too.  And the coffee had excellent body and flavor.

Amazing food and margaritas  every time I visit. The manger Carlos Alferz I must say is amazing. He makes sure everyone has a delightful experience when visiting no matter if it's your first visit or a repeat customer. If you ever plan to visit or next time you drop in for dinner just ask to meet Carlos. Then you will understand why I spend my hard earned money with him.

To welcome the women of my family to Chicago from LA, we went to Frontera and had a great time. We stayed with the street food offerings and loved everything. Service was good and the hosts were gracious in humoring us by taking pics. The sopes were particularly a hit. The sweet corn tamales weren't quite my jam but everyone else liked them. The only miss was dessert. We had a seasonal pumpkin cake that didn't quite satisfy anyone's sweet tooth. All in all, this is a good place to bring out of town guests for a fun dinner.

So this was my second time at the restaurant.  The first time I went, about a year ago, I went just with my SO and we had a lovely time. I thought the food was really good, but I actually thought it was a little overhyped. The kale enchiladas I had were just fine. They didn't have much flavor, but they were very fresh and the texture was great. My SO's dish (some sort of duck) was definitely delicious. The guacamole is great, but a little overpriced. The service was fine, and the drinks were good, but nothing memorable. The second time I went, just a couple weeks ago, I brought my parents during their visit to Chicago. They both really wanted to try a Rick Bayless restaurant so I thought I'd try it again. The food was actually much better this time (my father and I had several small dishes and my mom and SO had some tacos - the duck and steak). However, what drove me to write this review was the AWFUL service. So my mother ordered the steak tacos. She cannot eat processed corn and told the waiter she was allergic to corn tortillas and requested flour. The waiter said that was fine. Then my SO ordered the duck tacos, and also requested flour tortillas because he just likes them better.  When the food comes out, my mom mentions that her tortillas taste a little corn-ish, but she just thought that was maybe how they were flavored. After eating one, the waiter comes over and brings a second dish of tortillas to her, announcing that these were the flour she requested. He did NOT apologize for the mix up. We then realized that my SO got flour to begin with, even though my mother is the one with the legitimate health concern surrounding corn tortillas (and she DEFINITELY mentioned that to the waiter)! But no apologies were given at all, and he just acted like that was supposed to happen. Additionally, my mom ordered a margarita. She loved it, and as such, finished it before the main courses came out. However, she was never asked if she wanted another one. The waiter (and another girl, a water filler I guess?) also came around several times to fill water glasses and would LITERALLY skip my mother's glass (even though it was emptier than the rest of ours). She only got water when we loudly lamented the fact that she had been passed over for water a third time. I'm not sure if Frontera just didn't like the looks of her or what, but that was the worst service I have ever seen someone give just a single person at a table of four.  Now luckily my mom isn't deathly allergic to corn tortillas, so we didn't have to go to the ER or anything, but she definitely gets very sick from eating processed corn and she was very unhappy that she was going to get sick because of a waiter's mistake, especially when we are spending that much money on dinner. I don't remember the waiter's name at this moment, but he knows who he is because my dad left a very angry note on the table when we left. I can only hope that he learned his lesson. I will never be back to Frontera.

Excellent! Loved the food, service, atmosphere, and cocktails. I tried some ceviche and the Kale and Pear salad. Both were perfect. I was a party of 1, so the fact that they have a bar around the kitchen to seat parties of 1 or 2 was MUCH appreciated. When I travel alone on business trips, it's nice not to get seated in the middle of a crowded restaurant alone. I will come back on my next trip to Chicago!

In town visiting some friends, they took us to brunch at Frontera. It's a cozy experience, tables are close to each other but you don't feel like you're on top of your fellow patrons.  We started with a guacamole (I can't remember which)  and the sopes, which were amazing little bites of braised beef and dough and tomato sauce. I had the lamb tacos in pasilla sauce, they kindly swapped the black bean side for mashed potatoes. The lamb had brilliant flavor, and I would heartily recommend it. My girlfriend had the steak and eggs enchiladas, which were good but too spicy for her (she swapped plates with her brother, who had got the huevos mexicanos--also good, though eggs aren't particularly my thing).  Living in DC, I was struck by the prices, what would have almost certainly been a $200 meal in Georgetown was half that here, and it was just simply a great experience. Get reservations and go there.

Amazing. Heavenly food. I have never seen such a fantastic menu. Was visiting Chicago from Seattle.  The waiter was knowledgeable and easily accomodated my gluten free friend. Loved th e Sopas Ranchera. Loved it do much I ate at the Tortes Frontera at the airport on my way home.

I loved my experience at Frontera Grill.  The food was delicious, my only complaint would be that it would be nice to get more tortillas for the food, but every Mexican restaurant should include more tortillas #firstworldproblems.  I found the price to be very reasonable for my party of 5.  I was also able to walk right in without a wait which was nice after I called the location several times to inquire and I was told there's always an hour and a half wait. If you go at a reasonable hour or early on a week night I can't imagine it would be too crowded.  I'm sure on Friday and Saturday night's it's a zoo.

I'm probably not going to tell you anything that someone hasn't already said. Great spot to eat at in Chicago and fairly reasonable considering its namesake Rick Bayless. Definitely make reservations in advance. Highly recommend getting the ceviche trio; each ceviche is tasty in its own way, you'll probably end up having a favorite but won't regret tasting them all. My mouth is watering just thinking about it...

I went to the restaurant with a group of people. We ordered a couple of dishes to share. It's a good place to hang out, but the food, unfortunately, wasn't impressive. The food was just okay. However, the waiter was very friendly and knowledgable.
This place is magic - rick is outstanding . Every dish we have tried left us speechless . If I lived in Chicago that would be my in place

Really close tables for brunch!! I was excited to get a walk in Rez... But had to wonder what was going on with the weirdo table in my lap.... And there's a whole room standing empty by the kitchen... We had the bacon guac which was awesome and tortilla soup. Amazing. The quesadillas were also good.. And I felt guilty for loving them. Good service and coffee always filled.

So this is the second time we went here. We liked it the first time and we decided to invite another couple this time. While we were talking at the table my wife mentioned that she has a groupon which she keeps forgetting to use. So we asked the server how it works and he said it should be Ok. We were not planning on even using this but  simply asked the question. The server then explained which Drinks and Appetizers we are supposed to order so we did...half way into our appetizers the GM showed up. Extremely rude and loud and basically embarrassed us in front of our friends. The first thing he did was how only certain people are selected and allowed and we were not part of the selection sicne we did not go through the process. Now I understand and would have been happy if the server or even the GM just told us no. but this guy kept talking about how this process works and "people who use the groupon" have to make special arrangements. He basically made us look like cheap people even though we simply asked the served and he is the one who told us it was fine and showed us what to order. The whole time he was talking to us he scrolled on his phone showing us all their reservation and how noone basically uses the groupon except sone "people" who have prior arrangements. It was like we were asking for food stamp or something. The couple with us was just shocked on how this guy basically yelled at us about how we are cheap and uneducated about their process. I mean a simple Sorry sir the server made a mistake you cant use the Groupon would have been enough. He did not even ask us how is our food or if we have any questions. Once done with his rude lecture he just walked away. I understand this is Rick B. Place and it is busy but that does not mean uneducated and inexperienced manager like this guy should disrespect customers for asking a simple question. Horrible.

Excellent Mexican with a seasonal menu, closed Sundays and Mondays. I'm a fan of the other gring@ with extensive knowledge of Mexican cuisine-- Diana Kennedy-- so it took me a minute to get into the wiry Rick Bayless. But I enjoy his books, lots of people think he's more accessible, and I tried and enjoyed his food at an airport before. On this trip, I intended to check out Xoco based on reviews here, but it was closed, so I wandered into Frontera Grill. The hostess explained that the bar seats are first come, first serve, so I sat at the counter, facing the wall (poor choice on my part, but solo dining is sometimes awkward). I waited a while for a menu, and the server offered his disculpas.  The restaurant is full of amazing Mexican folk art: beautiful etchings, hand carved sculptures, colorful paintings, and a day of the dead alter with photos of famous people who have recently passed. Even the bathroom is pretty, with the doors to the stalls made of light and dark stained wood, with lines and cut outs.  I had the Xoco margarita, which is pleasantly sour, slightly sweet, and refreshing, made with Cazadores Blanco, Citronage, fresh lime and cucumber, and homemade lime bitters. As a weary traveler, I opted for the red chile kale and topolobampo tortilla soup (sopa azteca). The kale was served in a tiny iron skillet, and the rich, mildly spicy guajillo sauce, onions, and potatoes complemented the kale very well. The sopa was incredible: a soothing dark chicken broth, avocado, thin strips of tortilla, cream, chicken (sustainably raised), and rich, handmade Jack cheese. It had the perfect balance of heartiness and spice. The side of tortillas were fresh and soft, but definitely not among the best I've had. I thought the portions were fair for the price, similar to what you would pay at a sit-down restaurant in D.F. It's an ideal place for sharing food: I really wanted the bacon guacamole, fall version, but alas, they only offer a portion for sharing.

Went here with a group. We had the downstairs to ourselves. Lost out on the ambience. For all the hype expected more. The food was good - expected excellent. Some dishes way more distinctive than others. Mole decent. Shrimp was the best. Ceviche excellent. Queso ok. Mushroom empanadas ok. Duck was outstanding. Pork was good. Deserts were the highlight with the fruit soup fantastic...cake amazing...peanut butter flan ick...normal flan good. Service was excellent.

"Jonathan" the bartender was a great, very welcoming with excellent customer service  The ceviche was delicious "I  highly recommend the YUCATECAN CEVICHE" , the atmosphere was perfect & the drinks were great  "i preferred TOPOLO MARGARITA & i also had the blue agave which was okay :)  definitely a repeat, i had a great time note: salsa was amazing & homemade. everything is fresh !

The food is no doubt good--and a lot has already been said about that. But a review does not encompass the taste alone, but the value.  Though the staff was excellent, the portions decent, the environment was so-so, the wait was too long for a weekday (2 hours); and the price is a little off wack. Implicit in any rating is comparison to other places; other places with similar food are drastically cheaper. In essence, a little overrated.

Mexican food is one of my favorites and Chicago has a number of very good Mexican restaurants.  This is the best I've ever had. I would say this is one of the best restaurant meals I have ever had We shared the Sopes Rancheros for an appetizer and both agreed they were so good we would order them for an entrée.  My wife had a marinated rib steak, the Oaxacan style carne asada, with plantains and guacamole and it was delicious. I had the flank steak marinated in Serrano, (carne asada brava)., with grilled knob onions & sweet corn tamales.  It had a salsa on top that was incredible.  Both steaks we ordered were cooked perfectly.  Often at Mexican restaurants, the sauces are similar from one dish to another. Not here. Everything tasted different, yet all items complimented the others served with them perfectly.  We had two flans for dessert, peanut & vanilla and I would recommend them also.   Service was great and altogether one of the best dining experiences I can remember. I had very high expectations and they were exceeded.

The staff was very knowledgeable about the gluten free offerings. I had the catfish tacos and the flavors were amazing! I also loved the hot sauces that were on the table, not very hot but they had a ton of flavor. The only thing I had that wasn't a knock out of the park was the drink, but the food more than made up for that lacking!

My family and I went to Frontera a couple of weeks ago for my brother's birthday. We made a reservation about 1.5 months out for a Friday night at 9, because that was the earliest available. We arrived at Frontera at about 8:45, just in case our table was ready a little earlier, but if not we were happy to wait at the bar and have a drink. Unfortunately, this is where the problems begin. As soon as we walked in and told them our name, the people at the hostess stand were very confused about our reservation, this was strange to us because they texted my brother a reservation confirmation the day before AND he called to confirm. We thought fine, we will just wait at the bar for our table to be ready at 9 as originally planned. Well, 9 rolls around and we inquire about our table, which they say is not ready yet. Ok, I get it stuff happens, we will wait a few more minutes. Well finally, they tell us our table is ready at 9:15, but in the bar area, which is clearly not where they seat groups this big. Also, before they set up our table, there wasn't a group bigger than a two top seated there. We tell them, we didn't make a reservation 1.5 months ago to be sat at a makeshift table in the bar area. Also, throughout this conversation, the people at the hostess stand had been extremely rude and NOT helpful or understanding, even though we had done nothing wrong. One of them actually said "I am sorry you feel that way," like how else are you supposed to feel, when you make a reservation for your birthday dinner at a supposed nice restaurant and then get the run around from some nincompoops at the hostess stand. I worked in the restaurant business for about 10 years and I completely understand when stuff comes up behind the scenes that is out of your control, BUT working in this business it becomes your job to make sure the customer doesn't know about those problems and it doesn't affect their experience. If that means, comping their drinks while they wait or bringing out a free appetizer, it's a small price for the house to pay to keep the customer happy. Finally, at 9:35 we were sat at a table in the dining room. At this point, things finally started going well. Our waiter was very nice and helpful and the food was great. Don't worry we definitely tipped him 20% because what happened was far from his fault. Unfortunately, the whole experience with the host and hostesses left us with a very bad experience at Frontera, which is supposed to be a very high caliber restaurant. My advice to them would be to hire some people who are not rude jerks and have actual trouble shooting skills, so this doesn't happen again, as I've read in a few other reviews.

No doubt in my taste buds, deliciousness meter and stomach contentment monitor that this places deserves all the accolades it has received. From the "best food I ever ate" mention on Food Network to James Beard awards, the food here is quality, unique flavors and perfectly prepared magnificence. All that is not Chicago deep dish and red meat is found at Frontera.

I have to agree with Michelle's review below regarding the hype.  I've been wanting to go to this place for years.  Was finally able to get a reservation for brunch on a Saturday.  I have to say I expected to be blown away by the food. I wasnt.  It was of course not bad, but there was nothing that elevated it to the next level.  Maybe it was because we were stuck with the brunch menu and not the full dinner menu but to me it was no different then my local Mexican restaurant. One severe downside is that the room is TINY and you are sitting in a room no bigger than most peoples basement with 80+ people in close quarters.  Its hard to manuever, is not intimate and VERY loud.   The other downside is a $50 check and $22 parking.  $72 with no alcohol.  For that money we could have gone to a local place and had 2-3 margaritas a piece.

I don't usually review places that already have a gazillion reviews, but have to throw my opinion in on Frontera because it is f...ing fantastic .   Love the decor.  Service was flawless, but the food was sensational!  I had grilled flank steak stew with a very savory Serrano and tomatilla infused broth.  It contained pinto beans and just the right amount of crunchy bacon bits - unbelievably tasty!  Peg's choice was the pork carnitas enchilada - also fabulous. We went for lunch at 11:30.  Glad we made reservations because the place was packed by 12:00.

Hype, hype, hype! I mean yes, it's good, but is it that good? Nah. Maybe if I had tried something different, we'd have a different story. Or maybe I'm used to my California styled Mexican. In my book, California still has the best.  We ordered some guacamole to share. It was good, but it's hard to mess that up. We also ordered a trio appetizer to share. I can't remember what was in it, so it mustn't have been very good. For my entrée, I ordered the chicken enchiladas. The mole did have a strong, rich flavor, but I wasn't amazed as everyone else was. Others ordered the shrimp dish, which was very delicious-- probably the most flavorful dish and the only one I would order again.  Perhaps, I had too high of expectations. The food was good and the service as well, but I can't help saying I left a little disappointed.
Amazing, wonderful, creative and flavorful. If you love Mexican food that's been elevated to a whole new level this place is for you! The fact that Rick Bayless eats here should tell you everything.

Fulfilled my expectations. I like Tortas Frontera at the aiport so I decided that I had to try this place. Didn't disappoint! Their menu changes but what I tried... Old School Frontera Trio (chicken taquitos, quesadillas, ceviche tostadas) $18 Street food trio (enchiladas potosinas [fresh cheeze yumminess], a mushroom type thing hah and sopes ranches (these were reallllllllly good]. $19.75 Mom had the tortilla soup (kind of toooooo salty for my taste and spicy. The spice was fine for me but not for my mom). Shared the duo of flanes. One was the vanilla flan (delicious) and the other contained berries and flan. Both were amazing. $9 Oh yah, and get the blue agave margarita (mmmmm....) I liked having the option of the having the little bites. A little pricey for the amount but the quality is really great. Delicious little lunch. Went for my birthday and was a good choice!

Ate dinner here on a Thursday evening.  The location is great, right in downtown Chicago.  We arrived at 7:30pm and there was an hour wait, but the hostess let us know that we could eat immediately at the high top tables in the bar.  We chose that option and ordered the guacamole & the Old school favorites.  Everything was delicious.  Pricey, but I guess that is expected for the location.

I couldn't believe I came here on a week night and I could walk right in for a table! Matt J. and I had a $100 gift card to use here, and for dinner for two with a margarita or two each, that almost covered all of it, which is a decent deal for a) how great the food was and b) how strong those margaritas were! Obviously this is a Rick Bayless restaurant so it has to be up to a certain level on yumminess. It is trendy, modern mexican food and everyone raves about his mole sauces, so of course we got some, and the rumors are true. We got the duck in yellow mole to be exact, and it wasn't as rich and thick of a mole as I was used to from Mexican restaurants back home in California, but it was pretty tasty. Definitely a unique approach to mole sauces which I love. Plus, pairing that with one of their "snacks" the shishito peppers was a nice combo too. But the star of the show for us was his ceviche. Wow was that ceviche amazing. We go the trio of ceviche so we could try it all and I would go back just for the Ceviche alone (although they didn't give us enough chips at first at all for it!). There was an albacore tomatoe ceviche, a shrimp and squid ceviche, and a tuna and avocado and tomatillo one, with that one being my favorite since I am semi obsessed with anything with avocado in it. It came out in a nice little trio presentation, and was a great way to start our meal, although it definitely was a lot of food even with the $19 price tag.  And that's what I liked about this place--you get nicer food, in a great colorful environment and it really isn't that expensive for being a trendy Chicago eating spot. The service was a little slow though, so not sure if coming on a weeknight which led to our ease in getting a table is because there are fewer people working on those nights and the rest of Chicago knows that? But either way, can't wait to try the other Rick Bayless spots in town.

Chicago 9-2014 Summer guacamole is awesome. Tortilla soup is a must. Cold scallop appetizer was gross. The trio with shrimp flair as was awesome and the feta green chili appetizer was not worth getting again.

Great food, service and atmosphere.  However, Im a bit confused about the reservation system.  I could only get a reservation at 9:30pm and was told that if we came early we probably would not be seated because they usually have a 90 minute wait.  When we got there around 9pm, there were so many open tables, it was strange, yet they wouldn't seat us.

Have been wanting to come here since forever...Used our Groupon & arrived early and was able to get in before our allotted time slot. another plus since it was a weekday reservation.  Place was alive and buzzing the bar has this beautiful look with it's long flowing drapery.. along with the artwork, vibe is cool and relaxed.  We were actually quite pleased to have our waiter guide us along for this journey.. we listened to his suggestions/descriptions with enthusiasm and felt excited about his suggestions and he was spot on!  (and I can't tell you how LONG it's been since I've been to a restaurant where I felt confident in the waiter's suggestions ) quite refreshing!  Each dish and drink he recommended were stellar!   Just had an amazing dinner all around.  Can't WAIT to go back!!  This is an experience. not a dinner to rush through...
Amazing Mexican food. The plantains were incredibly tasty. Kale excellent. Summer guacamole had incredible flavors in it. The Carne asada was huge. Very festive atmosphere. Friendly staff.

Fantastic and creative spin on Mexican food in Rick Bayless' signature Chicago restaurant. Get in line early or try to score a reservation; otherwise, you could end up waiting for hours . But it would give you a chance to sample the delicious margaritas at the bar... I was recently in Chicago for business, but would only be around a few days. I started researching places to eat for dinner, and Rick Bayless' Frontera Grill came up as THE River North hot spot. I wasn't able to get a reservation (which are very limited), but I convinced my work colleagues to get to the restaurant about 15 minutes before opening on a Tuesday. We made it in to Frontera in the first group, but still had a 30 minute wait for a table.  The wait ended up being for the best though, since we got a chance to sample the delicious and fresh margaritas at the bar. I'm not usually a tequila fan, but these drinks were thoughtful and took full advantage of the Mexican flavors. Not overly sweet or tart, just fantastic.  As for the food, it was delicious as expected. The guacamole didn't knock my socks off but there certainly wasn't any left in the bowl after a few minutes. The savory-sesame chocolate tamales were unusual and delicious--the chocolate wasn't overly sweet and it just made a fantastic flavor combination. My colleague raved about the Tuesday goat special (the meat was very tender and savory), and my sirloin steak tacos had the perfect amount of spice and flavor.  The space is beautiful and fun and the service was impeccable. All in all, Frontera lived up to all my expectations...and if you can actually get in the door I highly recommend it. Also, I appreciated that the prices won't break the bank.

Ugh, where do I begin?!   Trust me folks...go to Xoco.  It's the best of his restaurants in flavor, price, ambience, etc. Came here on Friday with a 9p reserv.  Show up and they can't tell us when we will be sat.    We are in tourist hell.  30 mins and we get a text from them.   The restaurant itself is bustling.  I've been to Topolo...which is attached.  I could feel suburbia exuding around us. Server was weird.  He was very opinionated and judge-y.  He wanted us all to want what he liked...unfortunately, it didn't live up to expectations.  Not to mention, slllooooowwww service.  We tried several things off the sharing section.  Most were meh. Fundido was cold and clumpy Chirizo dish was mediocre with potatoes filling the pot Shrimp flautas....where's the shrimp?!  This tastes like potatoes All small and average at the very best.  Guacamole was good.   My chicken dish was a joke.  For $25 for a single breast...no sides, no nothing.  Oh man, this place is ridic.  I felt totally ripped off. Rick was there sitting a table away having a late night meal after he had cooked all night.  That was the highlight... Trust me...XOCO...you won't be disappointed!

Service was great but not impressed by the food especially considering the price. It would not be high on my list of places to go back to because I think there are similar places with better food at the same price or cheaper.

Frontera has recently begun running a promotion for discounted late night dinners on Groupon, which includes a specific reservation time. We walked in at 9:15, right on time for our reservation, but were told that our table was not ready. We sat down next to the host station and waited...and waited...and waited some more. After 30 minutes, the manager suggests we might want to wait in the bar.  I asked how much longer until our table was ready, and he says that he can't really say but they will come get us in the bar.   After 2 drinks and an appetizer in the bar, I check again with the hostess at 10:20 and was told my table had been ready at 9:20, and they had texted my cell phone and called me. They had never said that was how they would contact us, and I did not even bring my cell phone to the restaurant! This is ridiculous - since we were waiting within feet of the host station for over an hour! The tall brunette hostess was not the least bit apologetic, and acted very snobby and arrogant. Our server, Aleja, then saved the night and the whole experience for us. He was aghast at our treatment by the host station, apologized profusely, offered us complimentary wine with our meal dinner, and gave us great suggestions and exemplary service for the rest of the night. The manager did come to our table to speak with us and apologize for the long wait, but he had no good explanation for the host station's errors, the use of text messaging to notify us of our table, or the condescending attitude of his hostess.  Frontera's cuisine is superb, their waiters are gracious and knowledgeable, and the accolades are well deserved. The very front of the house (specifically, the host station and reservations management) is nowhere as polished as the rest of the operation, though, and Bayless' team needs to address these deficiencies to maintain Frontera's high standards and reputation.

Service- excellent! Host, Mgr, and waiter Food- excellent! Strip bass and red chile steak, you can't go wrong!  Another great creation!! Drinks- flowin.. Get the shakin @ the table margarita.  I'm still full after leavin this place an hour ago.  This is one of my top 10 restaurants in Chi

Fantastic! We decided on Frontera for a dinner celebration, and everything was simply wonderful!  We were a party of six and had tickets to an early show, so we were a bit concerned about timing.  We mentioned this to the staff at Frontera, and they were extremely accommodating.  They got us seated quickly, and made sure that we were finished dining with plenty of time to get to the theater.    Now the food....  We tried the ceviche trio (amazing), the pork tacos (amazing, especially with their homemade salsa), the featured fish (amazing), the brazo de reina (pretty good), and the guacamole (amazing). And thanks to the generosity of the manager, in honor of our special day, we also tried 4 desserts (flan, chocolate pecan pie, homemade ice cream, and the tamarind orange tart). They were all spectacular!  Service was impeccable from the time we entered the restaurant.  From the friendly and accommodating hostess to our attentive server to the manager that really went above and beyond to make this a memorable dining experience to compliment our special day.  The manager was too busy to stop by our table during dinner, but he actually walked out to the street corner to congratulate us!  I highly recommend Frontera Grill and cannot wait to return.

I was in Chicago on a work trip and was dining solo one night, so I decided to try my luck at Frontera. I was able to grab a seat at the bar right away, but I wasn't even acknowledged by a single server for a good 20 minutes.  When I was finally greeted, I got the chocolate sesame tamales and vegetable Milanesa in green mole.  The mole that came with the tamales was to die for. But the tamales themselves were too sweet and one dimensional, since they weren't stuffed with cheese or veggies or anything.  The Milanesa consisted of 6 breaded an deep fried Poblano peppers with some veggies and mashed potatoes in a green pumpkin seed mole sauce. It also came with a side of fresh tortillas. The mole was delicious but overall the dish felt way too heavy and carb-y. I craved some fresh elements on the plate to break up all the grease. I couldn't finish more than a quarter of this dish.  Overall, I wasn't impressed. I think Xoco or Frontera Fresco might be more my style.

Food was pretty good, but nothing out of the ordinary for mexican food north of the border.  I was hoping to find something on the menu with huitlacoche or squash blossoms, but you might have to go to topolobampo for that.  The table next to me had to ask to have their corn cut off the cob because they were sharing it.  Seems like common sense, but I think they focus too much on the plating here.
Frontera has a wonderful breakfast menu. I like to walk over a few minutes before it opens to beat the crowd.

Great meal. Rick Bayless makes a mean guacamole. It was too hard to choose what we wanted to try, so we split the street food trio (two enchiladas potosinas, two duck carnitas memelas, two sopes rancheros) and it was good -- especially the duck. We washed it down with good local beer and a margarita. The highlight was at the end when they brought my wife out a scoop of ice cream and cake for her birthday -- something I noted on the OpenTable reservation but never had to mention to the waitress or server.

The menu at Frontera Grill changes regularly so I don't know if the things I'm writing about stay on the menu but I'm sure everything is delicious and creative. We ordered an appetizer of chips and salsa, which featured freshly-made tortilla chips and two different kinds of salsa. The red was a three chile salsa and the green was a tomatillo salsa with serrano and cilantro. The green salsa had a mild spice and a great fresh flavor from the cilantro. For my entree, I chose the Mole Trio and, based on our waiter's recommendation, a side of Modern Black Beans. The Mole Trio included two mole poblano enchiladas, lamb in Oaxacan black mole, and roasted vegetables in a yellow mole. It was also accompanied by a dish of fresh corn tortillas. The Modern Black Beans was a dish of black beans cooked in olive oil and roasted garlic that was topped with crispy onions, queso anejo, and cilantro.   Everything was plated beautifully and looked incredibly appetizing. My first bite was of the lamb in the Oaxacan black mole. OOOOOOOO. M. G. We have a winner for Best Thing I Ever Ate: Mexican. Game. Over. There was a depth of flavor in this dish that I have a difficult time putting into words. There were meaty elements from the tender lamb and smoky, sweet spices I'd never tasted in Mexican food before. I don't know if there was any dark chocolate but it almost reminded me of a rich, dark stew with notes of cocoa. I hesitate to even guess at any of the ingredients and spices because I don't want to get it wrong and misrepresent the chef. This Oaxacan black mole offered a rich and home-y flavor that had me feeling like I was enjoying a dish of Mexican comfort food, if there is such a thing. And scooping some on a fresh corn tortilla was heavenly. I used my finger to make sure I got every bit of the mole out of the small skillet it was served in. I'm not joking and I don't even care if you're judging me right now. Not even a little bit. The mole poblano enchiladas and roasted vegetables in yellow mole were different but also very good. Not black mole good (I'm not sure it's possible), but still really good. And as the waiter suggested, the Modern Black Beans were an excellent side for the mole trio. The beans were hearty and the crunch of the onions with the soft cheese was delicious. It also served as a nice dip for our tortilla chips. You could taste such an amazing difference between everything at Frontera Grill and the food you'd find at most Mexican restaurants. There's a level of sophistication to it that elevates Mexican cuisine to a level that's on par with any other type of food in the world. The total bill was around $75 for the two of us, which is an expensive lunch, but still well worth it. It was the best Mexican food I've ever had and it ranks right up there with any cuisine. With these extraordinary dishes, it's clear to see why Rick Bayless is a world-class chef.

I had a tamale for lunch.  It was amazing.  Fresh and flavorful... Also, their salsas taste completely different (considerably better) from what is available in retail groceries.  I suggest trying this establishment at lunch time.  It is much easier than securing a table for dinner.

Amazinggg food. Wouldn't expect anything less from a Rick Bayless restaurant. They went out of their way to accommodate my dietary requirements (halal) and were very friendly.  Food was very good especially the steak carne asada and habanero infused guacamole! This is going to be my go to spot in Chicago!
Don't be afraid to walk up and ask for a seat at the chef's counter.

My friend and I came here for brunch and the food here was actually pretty good, I tend to be skeptical Mexican fusion like restaurants since a lot of the time they lose a lot of the flavors that make Mexican food good to me. While the food here felt a little Americanized, the food overall was still excellent and very well made. I enjoyed the Sopes Rancheros most, it had a good blend of flavors and the taste came together very well. My friend and I also tried the Old School Frontera Trio, which consisted of chicken taquitos, quesadillas, and ceviche tostadas. Of these, I liked the ceviche tostadas most, but I've had better ceviche elsewhere. Overall a pretty decent place, but not one I would keep coming back for if I had the choice.
Ceviche was too watery Chips were good nice ambiance, good service, but food in general was just okay...

Champagne margarita is a must. We were able to get a spot at the bar which was perfect. The guacamole was so fresh, the salsas unique and tasty. Entertaining surroundings, fun people watching as well. The pork dish was tasty as were the sides.  I would certainly return.

I had looked forward to visiting for a 2nd time since my last visit in 2012.  It did not disappoint me!  The margaritas were so fresh and perfect.  I tried Oxacan Gold with Mezcal and it was perfect balance of sweet, fresh and Mezcal.  My wife had the Chicken Mole and the Mole was SO GOOD!  I had the Duck and Date Mole and it was wonderful.  Such a unique dish!  The service was top notch!  It is not cheap, but is very good.  Lunch for 2 with drinks, tip, etc was ~$135.

If I could give this place 0 stars I would for this time. I am normally a huge fan of Rick Bayless and his cooking. I come to Chicago twice a year and always come here and I usually love the food. This time it was a very different experience. I called them up ahead of time and asked for the wait time, they said wait time was 30 mins. Within 5 mins I arrived ad the rude wait staff said the wait time is 1.5 hrs, I asked how can a wait time change so fast and they had no answers. They finally gave me a table, I ordered Enchiladas from Kids menu, after having them my daughter complained it was hot, I tried it and found there were Jalapenos in my kids food, I brought it to the notice of the server who inspite of seeing whole jalapenos said that they weren't jalapenos and that their chef knew what they were doing, I called the manager immediately and he came and changed the dish, I ordered shrimp which was good, my wife ordered mushrooms which came wrapped in butter paper,  and this was recommended by our server, the dish was below average and my wife just couldn't enjoy it, we decided not to say anything, since we already reported my kids dish. Our server was rude and terrible, he made all the wrong recommendations, confronted jalapenos on my kids meal, never ever asked for water. I called the manager before paying the bill and told gave him my feedback, I also told him that this wouldn't really matter to them since they are always busy, but I was really disappointed. As I was coming out of the restaurant, I saw Mr. Bayless walk in, I really thought about stopping him and talking about my experience, but I decided not to, I didn't want to embarrass him or myself. I am not sure whether Mr. Bayless reads these reviews, but if he does, please take care of the rude wait staff, rude waiters and listen to your customers, I come from Minnesota and come here each time and wait patiently, I have no reason to give you a bad review, but this was a really bad experience, check with your manager and he will tell you the story.

Exquisite upscale Mexican cuisine! We ordered several things and each item in each dish married perfectly. Service was outstanding, my water cup never came close to being half full.  We came from out of town and had prearranged to eat here by making reservations. Good thing we did because we arrived about 11:15am and there were several people waiting outside so we started a line and before the doors opened at 11:30am there was easily 50 people behind us waiting as well. Another reason I have to compliment the service- this place was beyond busy from the moment they opened and I never felt rushed nor unnoticed.  The food alone spoke volumes, I wanted to try many more items but I became full fast. Not because the items were heavy but because they were satisfying.  Thanks for a great meal! Will be back!
Amazing amazing amazing. Love the chicken tortilla soup, blue agave marg and chicken taquitos. Whatever you get it's going to be amazing!

This place is completely overrated, my girlfriend and I waited in half an hour for a table at during lunchtime and it took 10 minutes for someone to even come over to take our order, the chips and salsa were excellent. The chicken quesadilla was cold and my girlfriends tostadas tasted and smelled like feet. I was very very disappointed at this establishment I watch Rick Bayless's show on PBS. Don't waste your time just get chipotle Mexican Grill instead.

Love this place! From the food to the service to the interior decor, you are sure to have a fun time here.  My boyfriend and I went to Frontera on a Saturday night without a reservation. Since we arrived around 9:30pm we were seated with in minutes. Our server was very sweet. He had forgotten what we had ordered and had to ask us again. Because of his tiny mistake we didn't think twice about, he gave us complimentary drinks- a small little detail that went a long way with us :) We ordered the Blue Agave Margarita and the Xoco Margarita; both were delicious and very smooth.  For dinner we had the corn husk, guacamole, pork and the old street food sampling. All dishes were awesome. Being millennials, my boyfriend and I have had our fair share of different kinds of guacamoles, BUT Frontera's guacamole is by far the best we've ever had! I don't know what it is but its just perfect. I also loved the corn husk and how it added a fun element to our dining experience.  I will for sure be coming back here again and taking out of towners here in the future.
I love Rick Bayless. And I love Frontera Grill. Excellent food and drinks. 'Nuff said.

3.5 stars - packed, touristy but good if you have reservation came for lunch, had ceviche, guacamole, guava beer and fish tacos.  the food was all pretty good but not amazing. i've had better seafood. the guac was a little too creamy for my liking. guava beer though was delicious

2.5 Star Though I wanted to dine in one of Rick Bayless restaurants during my weekend in Chicago. But I doubt I would ever wait for a table here again unless I have a reservation. When we first arrived at 5:30 pm and put our name on the list, our hostess inform us the wait would be around 2 hours or so and would text me when our table is ready. We went for a drink and pre dinner snack and back to check with the hostess and of course our table was not ready as yet. And Finally, we got seated around 9:00 pm. I would have just say forget it and eat somewhere else, but some one in our group really wanted to eat here. So does the food worth the crazy long wait? Not really.... Margarita was weak.. I was glad I stuck with my beer. We ordered quite a few items to share, with some hits and misses and some just meh. The grilled meat plate we ordered were overcooked and tasted bland. The cerviche was a little dried. The Mole was really good, love the complex taste profile. Definitely order the dessert, which is probably the best part of the meal. I doubt I would be coming back to Frontera Grill again in my feature visit, unless I have a confirmed reservations and my travel mates are dragging me here.  Our waitress though really nice and efficient. But the whole dinner from the time we put our name down and when we got our bill was almost 5 hour long..

YUMM! YUMM! YUMM!  Rarely do I have a food experience where I feel like I've left my body and gone to culinary heaven.  This was one of those experiences!  We had gone to Xoco the night before because we couldn't get a dinner reservation at Frontera and Xoco was okay but lunch at Frontera the next day was out of this world!  As I mention in my Xoco review, I have ridiculously high standards for Mexican food and eat it at least 3 times a week.  They met my high standards and then some!   We started off with the Tortilla Soup and Chips and Salsa.  The two salsas were super flavorful with just the right amount of spice.  How do I describe the soup?  Well, all I can say is that somehow, and I'm not quite sure how, it got better and better with every bite, so that at the end you're just completely speechless and wanting more!  I felt like I found a new addiction! We also ordered shishito peppers which was delivered with our meal.  It is listed as a side on the menu but I wish they would have come out as an appetizer as you can certainly nosh on them in this fashion.  I love shishito peppers.  I only had just tried them for the first time the night before at Mercat La Planxa and so was extremely excited to see them on the menu at Frontera.  I do have to say that although they were delicious, they were much bigger than the ones at Mercat and maybe because of this (?) they weren't as flavorful as Mercat. The drinks: the margarita, which wasn't outstanding but unique and strong, albeit small.  My second drink:  The Oaxacan, also unique, better than the margarita, also strong and also small.  Last but not least: Black sands: coconut cream, rum, vanilla, nutmeg, black sesame and a couple of other ingredients I'm sure I'm forgetting.  I wish I would have ordered this one first (FYI: its a seasonal cocktail) because if it would have been possible I would have ordered a pitcher!  Oh my god, it was like a Mexican Bushwhacker (if you've ever been to Pensacola...)!  Probably one of the best drinks I've ever had! The food: SMOKED MAHI ENCHILADAS, SQUASH BLOSSOM CREMA and DUCK in DATE MOLE.  I don't what to say except for, "Are you freakin kidding me?!"  The fish was fresh, the crema was something I could drink, the duck was tender. OMG, OMG, OMG!   The dessert: How does one describe the treasure at the end of the rainbow??  Just go there!  GO! GO! GO!  Do not come to Chicago without going to Frontera, seriously!

Don't miss this place. Our last few trips to Chicago have unfortunately been on a Sunday/Monday so they are closed, but when we are in town any other day we will make sure to eat here. Have not had a bad experience or plate. The margaritas go down so quick and easy. Order two at a time

This place alone makes me miss living in Chicago, I even made it a point to come here during my last visit to town. I've never had anything bad on the menu and the service is always awesome, I've even sat at the bar area overlooking the kitchen and still had a great time with great service. The only downside of this place is that it has raised my standards wayyy too high for Mexican food, which is a huge problem once I moved away!

They have been doing it right for a long time.  Frontera is as good as it was 20 years ago, the first time we tried it.   You really can't go wrong with this menu.  I'm a sucker for the duck breast soft tacos and the Mexico City style quesadillas.  Whatever you order will blow you away and the prices are quite reasonable.
Great alternative Mexican food. Crowded, but good service. Great place to try if you can get a table. There is a place next door that serves the same food, just more causal.

From recording his tv shows to owning several cookbooks and even salsas and marinades from Rick Bayless, yeah, you could say we are fans. Of course, it makes sense that the very first meal we have in Chicago would be lunch at his restaurant, Frontera Grill. Before the restaurant even opened at 11:30am for lunch, people were already lined up to enjoy their long awaited savory experience. To our surprise, it really didn't take long for us to get seated since we lined up early. Basil blackberry margarita made its first appearance. It was like that first kiss that you anticipate. Is it going to be sweet? Is it going to be salty? Too overdone? It perfectly met the taste buds with the fruity aroma from the blackberry and the basil evened out the flavor by assuring the sweetness would not be overdone. Definitely unique. Surely worth a try. The duck quesadillas. Growing up, my mom always prepared duck and although it was one of my favorite dishes, it was always a battle between cooking the meat enough so its not too chewy and still preventing it from being so well done that it becomes stringy and hard. This duck at Frontera was incredibly tender and flavorful with each bite. It was cradled in Mexican cheese and blanketed in cooked tortillas that were crispy but still thick. No need to worry about an oily mess, because the dish was so neatly put together. The Big Wood Grilled Taco Trio. Amazing. The skirt steak became an obsession for me and I could not stop eating it. Order it medium rare on the rarer side and you will not be disappointed. The tender juiciness combined with the spiciness screamed at your senses with each bite. The pork in its red al pastor type marinade (or sauce?) also had its own powerful flavor and it was not overshadowed by the skirt steak. The Gunthorp chicken was not as spicy as its other "siblings" on the platter but still was very tasty. However, the chicken, soft in texture, and seasoned well, met the taste buds with more politeness. My hubby enjoyed that Mole Trio. It was served on a longer platter with the traditional mole in the center. The center mole was classic and every bite seemed familiar and what you expect a mole to be! The vegetarian mole on one of the ends which was actually green surprisingly one of may favorites on his dish. I did not get a chance to eat the third mole because he finished it before I did. Ho-hum, I guess I'll just have to come back some other time and try it myself!! One extremely exciting and unexpected treat was we actually saw Rick Bayless. Only the girls sitting at a table adjacent to us noticed and their gasps gave the news away. He simply was rearranging some of the pictures (or awards?) in the hallway on the way to the restrooms, just matter of factly and casually went to another area of a restaurant. They wanted a picture so badly with him, that I was almost tempted to ask him for one with them, but my hubs beckoned me not to bother him. Next time, I'm not listening to the hubs, I'm going to say "hi!"

Rick Bayless, you need to come down here and instill some quality control.  I'm afraid this place is resting on its laurels, and it is certainly not worth the effort or price to come here as it presently exists.  My story: I grew up near Chicago and wanted to impress my Californian wife with Chi-town culinary delights. I'd only had Bayless's food at ORD, but knew he was famous, trusted in the Yelp 4-star review, and made a reservation for lunch. They called to insist that I re-confirm it; I did.  We arrived a bit early and they were really nice and gave us a quiet-ish table in a noisy restaurant. It was downhill from there. The service: Total amateur hour. Took a long time to get menus and for them to take the order. Took a long time to get our appetizers. No one bothered to take our empty plates; I finally asked someone to take them, and the person took some of them but left some dirty plates. Why is this so hard? The waiter came and replaced our silverware for the next course. My wife noted that her new knife was dirty. The waiter had an extra, and gave her that. Cool. ...And then a few minutes later, he came back and replaced her clean one with another one. What? Did he see something on that last knife?  Mysterious and awkward....  More long wait for the main course.  People who came after us were eating their main courses by then. When our food arrived, we were surprised b/c my wife ordered the oysters/ceviche dish, but it only arrived with oysters. We assumed, when the oysters arrived with no ceviche, that the ceviche would come after the oysters. But it didn't--she next was served her tortilla chicken soup. So we said, excuse us, what happened to the ceviche? He said it doesnt come with ceviche. My wife asked to see the menu; he went and got one. We showed him. He then said we were right--but that he would talk to his manager. (Huh?) And then he came back and said he would bring the ceviche.    That finally came after her soup was finished.  So it was basically a ceviche dessert... We thought he would at least take my Diet Pepsi off our bill to compensate for this screw up.  Nope.  Full bill.  The food: my chicken taquitos were pretty good but were lukewarm at best. You know that feeling when you put some food to your lips and it immediately feels cold? it's not actually cold, but it's not nearly as warm as it should be.  the oysters were good with a tasty, flavorful sauce.  the carne asada quesadillas were OK. the meat was good, but there wasn't much of it, though, and the tortilla was incredibly plain, like something from a cafeteria.  wish i would have taken a picture.  the beans were barely warm. the tortilla soup had almost no chicken in it.  it was basically just broth and tortilla strips. we made jokes about being in a prisoner of war camp...   the ceviche--so long awaited--wasn't worth the wait.  the citrusy one was especially bad.  like raw fish and citrus in a blender.  Rick Bayless, please come back and fix this place!  It feels like it was filled with tourists who didn't know any better.  And sadly, that's what we were.

Have to say that my experience was underwhelming. Pros: the food was solid without being outstanding. I had the ceviche seafood starter and the pork special, both good. Desert menu had no items of appeal. Draft beer selection outstanding. Cons: slow service, especially drinks. What amazed and appalled me was the state of the bathroom. It is a weird for one and a half person set up; dirty, unkempt, In need of repair and frankly third world. There is a disconnect when charging $30 a plate and sending patrons to a dump.

Semi-unique flavors, but low quality service and exceptionally loud. It feels like a chain restaurant, dirty, and unmemorable, especially given Rick Bayless' reputation. The service is reminiscent of an Olive Garden. The noise is so loud it's as if you are in a tin can. I wouldn't go back and I wouldn't recommend. Too bad.

Truly for tourists. The room is loud, service lousy, the margaritas are very pricy and food has become quite mediocre. We were so disappointed!  Lucky enough to get a seat at the bar, the bartender ignored us after learning we were not eating at the bar but waiting for a table. After 4 $13 margaritas during the hour plus wait for a table, we couldn't drink at dinner because we had to drive after. Although we explained this to the waiter, he continued to press us for more drinks at the table. We ordered the guacamole...typical. The oysters...just ok. I was excited to try the Tuesday goat special but it was so salty that it was inedible. The waiter, obviously anticipating the salt issue brought tortilla and told us to try on tortilla which was redundant with the masa cakes within dish. The duck date mole was the best dish we ordered but not fabulous.  The volume in the dining room was so loud that my voice was hoarse after dinner from trying to have a conversation over the din...not at all relaxing or romantic.

Went here while visiting Midwest. I tried the ceviche sampler and tortilla soup. My husband got the chicken taquitos and skirt steak quesadilla. I don't understand what the hype is all about. Food is mediocre at best and service was terrible. It took us 30min before we got our first dishes and the beans were cold. Chicken tortilla soup had very little chicken. Maybe we're spoiled being from California, but food here is like going to any chain Mexican restaurant at home.

Solid four stars. Place was jam-packed on a beautiful summer Friday in Chicago, we're arriving late to lunch (around 2pm) and there's a 45 minute wait. Headed to the bar. Bartender was clearly overwhelmed, but kept it cool - which meant it was a bit slow to get service, but understandably. He was great at his job, though, and made my wife a great mojito. One of their craft beer features is a guava-infused brew called 5 Rabbit, which was good at first but toward the end of it I was ready for a change. Someone stopped by and asked us if we wanted some chips while we waited, we declined but that was a nice gesture. Wife and I both got mole dishes. She got the duck, which was delicious. I got the mole three ways, which was also delicious. After a little bit though I had wished I ordered rice, but also wish this dish would have just come with a small portion.  One nitpick: I've never ordered rice "a la carte" from any other Mexican, Tex-Mex or southwestern  restaurant I've ever been to. To me, having it a la carte is like charging people for bread at an Italian restaurant. A bit weird, and takes away from the "charm" of the place. Overall, a great place to have lunch but if I returned I wouldn't wait 45 minutes to eat. Prices are jacked up a notch too high for my liking, but my wife did grab a glimpse of the dreamy Rick Bayless emerging briefly from the kitchen, so she would probably disagree on that.
Food is really good, however pricing is a bit step for Mexican food.   Also it's very hard to get reversions so you have to wait an hour to get a table via a walk-up.
I enjoyed my experience at Frontera Grill. Solid 4 stars from me I can't wait to come back and try something different.
Simply not impressed, a $60 taco bell disappointment. we had lunch there. service friendly however i could not understand him...restaurant is completely overrated. ..Thank you RICHARD

So wanted to love this place since it had been hyped up in my head forever, and I loved Rick Bayliss on Top Chef. Unfortunately, it fell way short. The service was great, but we found the food to be over-salted and over-spiced. Not very authentic at all when all you can taste is the overpowering salt. The xoco margarita was great though, as was the chocolate cherry tart. We left feeling like we should've just tried his higher end place next door, considering the hefty price tag at Frontera for inauthentic mole.

This place doesn't even deserve a single star. Last week we reserved and the lady asked us to wait an hour and they would message us when our table was ready. They messaged us three hours later, which is ridiculous to think we would wait that long. They even asked us to just walk around or wait outside. A few days later, I called to make another reservation the day before we went. The lady who answered me was perhaps THE most arrogant person I have ever spoken to. Zero inter-personal skills and customer service skills. I called the day of our reservation to make sure and the lady who answered this time asked us to show up a couple of hours before our reservation and put our name on the waiting list.
